title: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker
subTitle: Yes, you can improve your parking-lot experience. Here's how.
promoTitle: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker
promoTeaserSmall: Yes, you can improve your parking-lot experience. Here's how.
promoTeaser: Yes, you can improve your parking-lot experience. Here's how.
keywords: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker
metaTitle: 7 Rules to Be a Better Parker - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Yes, you can improve your parking-lot experience. Here's how.

pageElements.text: 1. Don't be in a hurry. Easier said than done, but if you are not racing to your destinations, you will not have to stress out about the parking space you get (or don't get).

2. Don't break the rules. I'm talking to you with the flashers on in front of the fire hydrant while you "just run in for a minute." This is neither polite nor safe, and it adds to parking lot stress for yourself and everybody else. Don't park in a handicapped space for any reason, either.

3. Watch what you're doing. The International Parking Institute (yes, there is one) says up to 14 percent of accidents resulting in an insurance claim come from parking lot altercations. Look around you, be careful when you back up, and as always, expect bad driving from others and demand good driving from yourself.

4. Don't be an annoying pedestrian. Get out of drivers' ways in the parking rows, cross at crosswalks, and watch for cars before you step into the aisle. Temporary custody of a shopping cart does not give you 20 minutes' right of way to saunter down the center of a grocery store lane.

5. Be prepared when you get there. Carry change for meters. Also: Figure out where you think you'll be parking before you leave the house. Sometimes you can even use a parking app like SpotHero, which lets you find and reserve spots in crowded city centers around the country, even far in advance if there's a special event. Usually you can prepay and get a discount.

6. Remember where you parked. This is the trifecta: it will stress you out, get you behind on time, and make you an annoying pedestrian if you can't remember where your car is. I like to take a cellphone photo to show me the location: the level number in a parking structure and the surroundings in a surface lot. It helps.

7. Be a good driver. Obvious, but surprisingly rare when it comes to parking skills. Are you a good parallel parker? If you're not, go out and practice sometime when you're not busy. This is the skill that divides the grownup from the wannabe.

pageElements.text: I have a huge collection of Christmas music, but here are my favorite CDs. May your days be merry and bright. May you go forth and prosper. And be nice to everyone.
Love, Jean

#1

Vince Guaraldi: A Charlie Brown Christmas Original Soundtrack (Fantasy)
I kick off the season with this classic to get immediately in the spirit. Like Snoopy.
Best Track: Christmas Time Is Here
Incongruous: Nothing

#2

Annie Lennox: A Christmas Cornucopia (Universal Island Records)
An angel’s voice and an inspired playlist.
Best Track: Lullay Lullay
Incongruous: Nothing

#3

Quadriga Consort: On a Cold Winter’s Day (Carpe Diem)
A couple hundred years before Downton Abbey, but same neighborhood.
Best Track: Taladh ar Slanaighear (Our Saviour’s Lullaby)
Incongruous: Nothing

#4

Daryl Hall and John Oates: Home For Christmas (dke Records)
Blue-eyed soul kind of Christmas perfection.
Best Track: Home for Christmas
Incongruous: Nothing

#5

Leon Redbone: Christmas Island (August Records)
Nice banjo.
Best Track: Christmas Ball Blues
Incongruous: Nothing

#6

Crooner Lounge: Swingin’ Christmas (Village Square Music)
The best of the best crooners ever, singing my faves.
Best Track: Shake Hands with Santa Claus by Louis Prima
Incongruous: Nothing

#7

Jolly Old Soul (Rhino)
One of those great compilations you buy at Starbucks while you’re waiting.
Best Track: Every Day Will Be Like a Holiday by William Bell
Incongruous: Nothing

#8

Sleigh Ride Side by Side (EMI Music)
A mix of old classics with a few modern (and unusual) artists.
Best Track: What Are You Doing New Year’s Eve? Lena Horne
Incongruous: Thanks for Christmas, sung by XTC

#9

James Brown: Funky Christmas (Sony Music)
Every song a James Brown original. It’s all about the Flames.
Best Track: Don’t Forget the Poor at Christmas
Incongruous: Clean for Christmas

#10

Il Divo: The Christmas Collection (SYCO Music/Columbia Records)
Best Track: Panis Angelicus
Incongruous: Somewhere over the Rainbow

pageElements.text:
Base price:

$41,325, including $925 destination charge, for 2015 C300 shown here. Base 2015 C-Class RWD starts at $39,325, including destination. Rear-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive (a.k.a. 4Matic) versions are available.

Price as tested:

$56,820, including $925 destination charge. The car in this video has ten options. Among them: $1,515 Diamond White exterior paint; $1,480 panoramic sunroof; $1,680 Premium package that includes heated front seats, SiriusXM, Burmester Premium sound system, and LED headlights; $2,800 Driver Assistance package that includes active lane-keeping assist, Pre-Safe brake with pedestrian recognition, and active blind spot assist; $2,175 Sport package with sport suspension, sport front brakes, sport seats, flat-bottom steering wheel, and a black headliner.

EPA fuel economy:

24 mpg city/31 mpg highway with the 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbocharged engine, making 241 horsepower and 273 pound-feet of torque, and a seven-speed automatic transmission. (The C400 comes with a turbocharged 3.0-liter V-6 rated at 329 hp and 354 lb-ft of torque.)
The test car has standard Eco Start/Stop system designed to conserve fuel.

Safety:

Not yet rated by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. Not yet rated by Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
Standard safety features on this model include antilock brakes, electronic stability control, adaptive brakes, collision prevention assist.
Pre-Safe is now standard; it was optional on the previous C-Class. It monitors the traffic ahead by radar. If the system detects an imminent collision, it warns the driver with audible alerts and initiates braking, if necessary. It works in tandem with brake assist, which pre-loads brake pressure to shorten stopping distances.
Standard airbags include front-seat side airbags, full-length side curtain airbags, and a driver's knee airbag.

Chief competitors:

2015 BMW 3 Series (base price for 320i sedan $33,900 including $950 destination charge)
2015 Audi A4 (base price $36,425, including $925 destination charge
2015 Lexus IS (base price for IS 250 RWD sedan $37,475, inc. $925 destination charge
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/no1TzVGnZDs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Key Points:

  • Rear-wheel-drive and all-wheel-drive (a.k.a. 4Matic) versions are available.
  • There's no manual transmission choice.
  • Many people knew the C-Class as the “Baby Benz,” until the smaller and cheaper CLA-Class sedan came along.
  • For the new model year, the C-Class gets a little longer and much lighter, but builds on a successful formula while moving upmarket. Still is pricier than the three competitors listed above.
  • All C-Class sedans come with four drive modes (called Agility Select) that adjust throttle, transmission and steering response. Optional Airmatic air suspension.
  • Cabin is elegant. Conceived by Mercedes’s design studio in Italy.
  • The coupe carries over essentially unchanged. But a new-generation coupe, diesel model, plug-in hybrid, and high-performance C63 AMG are all coming.

pageElements.text: Alfonso Albaisa is a romantic, a dreamer, a visionary, whose twenty-five-year tenure at Nissan included several senior design positions. He became design director of Nissan Design America in 2004, then vice-president of Nissan Design Europe in 2007, returning to the U.S. in 2011 as vice-president of NDA. Before recently moving to the brand’s luxury marque, Infiniti, as executive design director, Albaisa had risen to design director for Nissan’s Global Passenger Vehicles and Electric Vehicles.

If you hadn’t noticed, Nissan Design is hanging it all out. Albaisa’s vision follows in harmony with that of his boss, Shiro Nakamura, who has been an extraordinary iconoclast his entire career. Between them, their portfolio of striking and strikingly unusual vehicles—from Murano to Cube to Juke to Murano Cross Cabriolet—has put Nissan on the map after a near-fatal spell arrested in mid-plunge by Renault.

The latest concepts for Infiniti, however, have been anything but unusual. Sensational and sensual, the new Q-ship concepts are pointing the way toward an unprecedented explosion of new products aimed at the top of the Infiniti range.

In this video, shot at the Los Angeles Auto Show, Albaisa gives me the inside tour of the Q80 Inspiration Concept, which was first revealed in September at the Paris Motor Show. Our only question: Will it make it into production?

pageElements.text: Amid the sea of people and exciting tech announcements at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas this week, there was an announcement from Toyota that is probably a pretty important moment in automotive history: the Mirai. It's Toyota’s hydrogen fuel cell car, a mid-size sedan that will be available for purchase or lease in October.

Hydrogen is clean and abundant. A car that runs on it emits nothing but water. But skeptics of the idea of hydrogen as an alternative fuel have predicted that hydrogen fuel cell cars are impossible – or at least too difficult.
But here it is 2015, and you will be able to lease one for $499 a month, including all maintenance and fuel, later this year.
This reality is brought to you by twenty years of research and thousands of patents.

“The first 100 years of automobiles were fueled by gasoline,” said Robert Carter, senior vice-president of automotive operations at Toyota. “The next 100 will be fueled by hydrogen.” Carter believes today is the beginning of the next 100 years.

For many people, the idea of hydrogen-fueled cars recalls terrifying, fiery images of the Hindenburg. But that’s merely because hydrogen needs a better public relations team. It was the paint on that famously flammable zeppelin that burned, not so much the hydrogen.
Hydrogen is a gas. It’s flammable, sure. But it dissipates harmlessly if you puncture the container it’s in. Pffft… gone.

That is, if you can puncture the container it’s in. Because one of the real problems (there is a reason for the thousands of patents and decades of research) with hydrogen as a fuel is not that it creates a pool of highly flammable gas around your vehicle in a crash –that’s a problem with gasoline–but that it's hard to contain. Its particles are so small and light that it’s hard to keep it in a container. That’s why hundreds of Toyota’s patents are for the fuel tank in the Mirai.
Another problem with hydrogen, of course, is finding it at the gas pump. But Toyota is working on that, and so are California and other states,

Another problem with hydrogen, of course, is finding it at the gas pump. But Toyota is working on that, and so are California and other states,  “We know we have to invest in the infrastructure to make this happen,” Carter told me. And that’s exactly what the company is doing. So don’t be too surprised if you start to see hydrogen fuel stations cropping up soon, first in California and the Northeast but in other states soon after.

And here is something that your fossil-fuel-burning car can’t do that the Mirai can: When the power in your house goes out in that next hurricane or snowstorm? Just plug your house into the car. The Mirai can power your house for a week as a backup generator. Try that with your current SUV.

pageElements.text:
1. MyQ Wi-Fi Garage Door Opener

$129.99
Did you just leave the garage door open–with the bikes, kayaks, and dive gear in it–when you left on your commute to work? D'oh! But there is no need to drive home to check. With MyQ, just look at your phone, tap to close the garage door, and carry on. It’s easy to install. Plug the connector dongle into your existing garage door opener to connect it to your Wi-Fi network. Download the app to control the garage door from your phone.

2. KeyFree

Pricing and availability not yet announced
Lose your keys. Go ahead. Don’t worry about it. Just don’t lose your phone. Because once you install the little Bluetooth dongle in your car and download the KeyFree app, your smartphone is your car key. You can open the car automatically as you walk toward it, remote start the car while you sip coffee in the warmth of your house, get car diagnostics delivered to your phone, and even send a key to someone else so they can drive your car if you aren’t around.

3. Satechi BT Home Button

$24.99
Admit it! You can't resist looking at your phone to ask Siri or Google Now a question when the driving gets boring. The asking is a sign of an active mind. The looking at your phone is dangerous. Attach the Satechi BT Home Button to your dash, tell it what you want it to pull up on your phone, and just press a button next time to hail answers from the oracle. Eyes on the road! The BT stands for Bluetooth, and the gadget will become available later this month.

4. Life360

Free
How many times a day do you ask your spouse or kids where they are? There is an easier way. Install the Life360 app on your Apple, Android, or Windows smartphone, and you can just look to see if he left work, if she made it to school, and how far away she is if you want to start dinner. You can message each other within the app, too. And it’s all fun. (And you can easily go incognito if you’d rather keep your current location–ahem–mum.) Ford recently partnered with Life360 so that if you get into your Ford with Sync, it will automatically tell everyone in your circle you are driving and not responding to texts. It will also automatically let them know when you arrive and are available again. That’s a good message to send to teen drivers.

5. RemoteLink

Free with OnStar
Do you drive a car with OnStar? Lucky you. Download the RemoteLink app right now! (If you haven’t already.) You can turn on the heat before you get to the car, lock the doors without going back outside to check, see if the car needs gas before you get out of bed to drive, or unlock the car for your teenager when she locks the keys inside not for the first time. Free (and so necessary) if you already have OnStar!

pageElements.text: The Consumer Electronics Show this year was all about the future: Cars that drive themselves, 3D printers, drones, and slick wearables. But that thing that seems ever so possible and that you want every day (Right now! Today!)? (That, for this geek anyway, being a Wi-Fi connection in my car.) That was not everywhere you look.

Not unless you are looking at cars with OnStar, that is. In that case, it’s wherever you look. By the end of 2015, 4G LTE will be standard in pretty much all General Motors cars. Even the $12,000-range Chevrolet Spark comes standard with a six-month OnStar plan.

Lots of cars have connectivity. (Well, mostly high-end cars. But lots of those.) A connected car is awesome! It can access a server for updates to its telematics or core car functions. Or the car itself has an Internet connection so it can access online maps or surf the Internet from the in-dash telematics system. Or that in-dash telematics system connects to your phone, and uses its connection to the Internet, so you can use the apps you love right from the car’s dash. In one way or another, this is what BMW’s ConnectedDrive, the Audi A3 (which has Google in the dash!) with Audi Connect, and Ford Sync do.
The car connects. But the car doesn’t connect you.

A subtle distinction? Not when you are sitting in the passenger's seat trying to file a story to your editor while flying down the freeway at 80 mph and that story is on a laptop that needs Wi-Fi. Not when the teenager in the back seat sighs melodramatically for the thousandth time and asks “Are we there yet?” to remind you that his tablet is just a dead weight with no Internet connection. Not when you have to answer e-mail on your phone for an eight-hour drive even though your laptop is sitting right there.

I love a car with connectivity. I think it’s an important feature to shop for. But I’d really love it if the car would share that connection with everyone in the car so we can use all of our devices when we are on the road, just like when we are at home.
Aftermarket, you can get that kind of connectivity through some aftermarket additions such as the Delphi Connect ($200 plus plan).
But drones and 3D printers are cool, too.

The show has already begun for automotive journalists, who've been treated to advanced previews of some of the vehicles that will be hitting the show floor in two days. An auto show without a knockout surprise is a sad auto show indeed.

title: Buick Avenir and Cascada
subTitle: Striking flagship sedan concept, along with 2016 Cascada convertible, greeted the media in Detroit.

pageElements.text: Buick has just rolled out a pleasant surprise for anyone who may have found the General Motors brand a little boring in recent decades. The Buick Avenir concept is a very attractive flagship sedan that was greeted with approving interest when it drove onto the stage to face the media at the Eastern Market in Detroit on Sunday night.

Buick Avenir Concept

The Avenir is a rear-wheel-drive, four-seat sedan with a next-generation V-6 engine and a nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters. The sedan’s exterior was designed in Australia, while the interior is a U.S. design. The cool cat-eye center infotainment screen is a desirable touch, while the two passengers in the deep rear bucket seats get USB ports and video screens of their own.

A full set of LED lighting, 20-inch wheels, and driver-selectable suspension damping are among the highlights. The grille brings back Buick’s three-color look from the past, and there’s a smooth-looking variation on the traditional Buick portholes.

The concept’s name is French for “future,” although the automaker gave no hint on when or how it will produce the Avenir.  But the desire to do so is plainly there: Mark Reuss, executive vice-president for global product development, called it “pure essence of Buick,” and design chief Ed Welburn mentioned the Avenir in the same breath as the Y-Job, the classic Buick concept from 1938.

People born in 1938 or earlier could love this car, as you’d expect from any Buick, but if the next production flagship from Buick looks anywhere near this sleek, its appeal will cross a lot of age boundaries.

2016 Buick Cascada

In the realm of cars you’re likely to see on the road soon, Buick showed off its 2016 Cascada, a convertible that will go on sale next year. This will be the first Buick convertible in a quarter-century – the last was the Reatta – and it should appeal to people who like cars like the Volkswagen Eos or Beetle convertibles or the Audi A3 Cabriolet. It has a soft convertible top that goes up or down at the push of a button in seventeen seconds, at speeds up to 31 mph.

The Cascada is a front-wheel-drive car, powered by a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine that makes 200 horsepower. It comes only with a six-speed automatic transmission. Heated seats and steering wheel are among the amenities. It also has the HiPer Strut front suspension that is already on the LaCrosse and Regal, and GM president Dan Ammann pointed out that Buick buyers want “special attention to acoustics and refined ride.” Pricing hasn’t been announced yet, but somewhere in the mid-$30,000s is likely.
If Buick is looking for a younger, more style-conscious buyer, which we know the GM division is, these two new designs should go a long way toward getting those people to look at the product lineup.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Volt
subTitle: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.
promoTeaserSmall: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.
promoTeaser: Electrifying news: an all-new Volt, plus a long-range Bolt crossover concept.

pageElements.text: The introduction of the all-new 2016 Chevrolet Volt is big news for General Motors. The company is rolling out its second-generation Volt at the Detroit auto show this morning. But the hybrid's debut is being overshadowed by reports that a larger crossover concept, the Chevrolet Bolt, will be there, and it’s claiming 200 miles of range on electric power only.

The Volt will go on sale later this year, delivering up to 50 miles between charges, which is 30 percent greater range on electric power only than the current model. Between its new four-cylinder gas engine and its battery power, drivers can expect to go about 1,000 miles between trips to the gas station, Chevrolet says. A thousand miles, they say? Low gas prices or not, that’s enticing.

The Chevrolet Volt was big news when it came out in 2010, but how has the mid-$30,000 sedan actually done in the market? Well enough to make it the biggest-selling plug-in on the U.S. market, according to GM, although it has certainly received nowhere near the adulation you’ll see for Tesla’s electric cars.

As for the upcoming crossover, sure, the long-range Bolt will make heads turn. But as a consumer, if you’re looking for alternative energy here and now, you’ll want to look at the Volt, which goes on sale in the second half of 2015 looking a lot more like the Impala and a lot less like a quirky EV. That’s by design, Chevrolet says.

We got an early look at it at the Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant last week, and Chevrolet design chief John Cafaro was right when he said it’s just that little bit more aggressive and sexy than the outgoing model. “It doesn’t look like a jellybean” is how he put it.

The new Volt gets LED daylight running lights, a pair of eight-inch touchscreens, GM’s 4G LTE with Wi-Fi, and a redesigned back seat that now has three sets of seatbelts, although there’s absolutely no leg space for the center passenger. Like the outgoing model, headroom in the back seat is marginal.

But back to the range issue. You can drive more miles on electric only, now up to 50 miles from the previous 38. Fuel economy is 41 mpg combined or 102 MPGe using a combination of electric power and the new 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine, the first North American use of GM’s new small engine family. It makes 101 horsepower and runs on regular unleaded fuel.

The unleaded gas, the fifth seat, and a move toward a smoother and quieter driving experience are part of Chevrolet’s response to its close study of Volt owners’ feedback. Executive chief engineer Pam Fletcher called it “about the most customer-inspired car you’re going to see launched” because owners were exhaustively polled.
Those owners wanted “mainstream,” according to Volt chief engineer Andrew Farah. The roofline is lower and a bit sleeker with a handsome shark-fin antenna on top,  the hood and liftgate are aluminum.

New for the 2016 model are a set of Michelin energy saver tires specifically designed for the Volt, and an upcoming infotainment system that will be shared with several GM vehicles, to be described in detail in the spring at the New York Auto Show.

Chevrolet’s moment in the spotlight as the Detroit auto show media days open on Monday morning will make it clear that the brand intends to plug in for the long haul. Pricing on the Volt, and official details on the Bolt, will be announced shortly.

pageElements.text: It’s fair to say that for all its virtues—solid construction, plenty of power, plenty of capabilities—Nissan’s Titan has been all but invisible in the full-size pickup derby.
Fifth in a field of five, the Titan’s share of the full-size pickup market hovers around one percent.
But far from giving up, Nissan is renewing its challenge to the pickup establishment with an all-new truck that the company characterizes as the toughest, most rugged-looking of them all.

You’ll make your own decision about cosmetics, but the revitalized Titan will have at least one major bragging point: the only diesel V-8 engine option in its class. It has two more cylinders than the Ram 1500 turbo-diesel V-6 and 5.0 liters versus 3.0.

But with 310 horsepower and a whomping 555 pound-feet of torque (the Ram’s diesel delivers 240 and 420, respectively), the Cummins turbo-diesel V-8 puts the Titan into heavy-duty territory. Nissan claims maximum payload will be in excess of 2,000 pounds, and maximum towing will be 12,000 pounds plus, depending on equipment.

Nissan furnished no EPA numbers for the new engine, other than to say it anticipates a 20 percent fuel economy advantage versus a normally aspirated gasoline V-8 of comparable displacement. The current Titan V-8 is Nissan’s gasoline 5.6-liter, with EPA ratings of 15 mpg city and 19 mpg on the highway.

Although Nissan refrained from details, a gasoline V-8, probably the 5.6-liter, will continue in the Titan lineup, which will also include a V-6 for the first time. But the first new Titans to reach showrooms—late this year—will all be crew cab versions, propelled by the new Cummins diesel. The other engine choices won’t come along until later.

All engines will be paired with an Aisin six-speed automatic transmission, and four-wheel drive will continue to be an option. Nissan is aiming to satisfy buyers who want heavy-duty capability without stepping up to one of the really massive Big Three HDs.
That may sound like a pretty tight marketing window. But, even though it has only a one percent market share, Nissan thinks it's worth a try.

pageElements.text: Today was a good day to look in to Volkswagen's world. The automaker won the coveted North American Car of the Year award for the Golf, and company chief Martin Winterkorn and board member Heinz-Jakob Neußer (shown here) introduced the Cross Coupe GTE concept, a five-passenger SUV that's part of a massive crossover/SUV initiative planned for U.S. buyers.

Interestingly for such a large vehicle, VW made it a plug-in hybrid. It has a 3.6-liter V-6 engine making 276 horsepower, two electric motors, and all-wheel drive, and its estimated fuel economy is 70 MPGe. You can do even better, VW says, if you run it in E mode, where it will go up to 20 miles on electric power alone. At the other extreme is GTE mode, billed as "extremely sporty." There's also the default Hybrid mode, Off-Road, and a battery charging mode.

As a production model, VW says the Cross Coupe GTE "can be realized with every conceivable drive type," meaning a standard gasoline-engined or diesel-powered version could be in the lineup.

The Cross Coupe GTE is still in concept form, but VW calls it "the protagonist of a new Volkswagen design language developed for the USA." It seats five, but it will come out at the end of 2016 as a seven-passenger vehicle, built in Chattanooga, Tennessee. For people who like Volkswagen's style and technology but need (or want) to move up in size from a Golf, here's an option that, as VW says, shows how "German design and engineering merge with the American way of life."

title: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Spider

pageElements.text: The classic definition of a sports car is an open two-seater that can, in a pinch, be raced. No extras. Absolutely no frills. Pure purpose.

That description probably predates World War I, about the time Anonima Lombarda Fabbrica Automobili (A.L.F.A.) came to be. The genre has obviously become far more civilized since then. But among contemporary automobiles characterizing themselves as sports cars, it can be argued that none come closer to the classic definition than this one.

The Spider was introduced in concept form at the 2014 Geneva Auto Show. It has all the attributes of the 4C coupe, with the exception of a fixed roof. Same 1.7-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine (237 horsepower, 258 pound-feet of torque). Same six-speed twin-clutch automatic transmission, capable of lightning (130 millisecond) shifts. Same surgically precise steering, unfiltered by power assist.
The only major distinction is the removable carbon fiber roof panel. Strictly speaking, with the panel off, the Spider looks more like a targa than a roadster, but why be strict?
Also, the Spider includes a canvas top, handier to stow than the carbon fiber panel and useful for occasions when a pleasant day of motoring is threatened with the heartbreak of cumulonimbus.

Compromises? Minimo. Removing the roof from a unibody structure can result in a chassis rigidity index similar to that of tofu. But thanks to its carbon fiber body shell, that doesn’t seem to be an issue here, at least according to Alfa. The Spider gets a carbon fiber windshield surround, but that’s just about the only change from the coupe.

Convertibilization can also lead to increased mass, as the engineers try to restore lost rigidity. And in fact the Spider is heavier than the coupe, although only by a modest 22 pounds. But at 2,337 pounds, the power-to-weight factor is essentially the same, and owners can expect the Spider to match the coupe’s 4.1-second 0-to-60-mph sprint.
Other distinctions are equally subtle. The Spider is a smidge taller than the coupe—46.7 inches vs.46.6, but its static ride height is closer to mother earth: 4.4 inches vs. 4.5.
With or without a hard top, the 4C is one of those rare cars that become an eager extension of the driver’s will.
On sale this summer at the 100-plus FCA dealers carrying Alfa cars.

pageElements.text: Good news for the planet! There were some huge electric announcements at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit this week. In fact, there was something for everyone: economy, everyman, and luxury.

Chevrolet Bolt Concept
This concept car stole the show at NAIAS. With its promise of a 200-mile range and a price of $30,000, it got a lot of stares. But then, open the doors and this is the interior? Wowsa! Sexy, space age, and within fiscal striking distance? Sign me up. Rumor has it that this concept will be reality next year.

2016 Chevrolet Volt
A Tesla for the people? Well, some might think so. The original Volt hit the market four years ago. And the folks at Chevrolet have been refining the battery, style, interior tech, and everything else customers told them they liked and didn’t like about it. (Volt owners are cultish in their devotion.) Now out in a 2.0, this sweet electric ride has a range of 50 miles on a charge, a suite of driver awareness and assistance technologies – including forward collision alert – and tons of tech such as 4G LTE in the car, an inductive charger for your phone, and lots more. More on this car here.

2016 Mercedes-Benz C350 Plug-in Hybrid
Green luxury has arrived! This plug-in hybrid is sporty and fast. It's comfy and luxurious on the inside like you’d expect from a Mercedes C-Class, but with less gas-consumption guilt and up to 20 miles of range on electricity alone. In fact, that luxe interior will no doubt benefit from the quiet of an electric ride. Finally the high-thread-count crowd gets a plug-in ride.

2016 Hyundai Sonata PHEV
This is a plug-in hybrid version of Hyundai’s already popular Sonata. And this car is a lot like the fossil-fuel-sipping Sonata but with some aerodynamic improvements, netting it an electric-only range of 22 miles. Connect the car to your phone via Bluetooth, download an app, and you can connect to the car for a health report and to schedule charging it when rates are lowest.

pageElements.text: I hate crashing. I hate sliding off the road and into a ditch. I hate that sick feeling when you feel your tire adhesion give way as the snow falls and weather dips below forty, one of the most dangerous times to be driving on all-season tires. I’ve seen it all, and I finally got religion.

We put winter tires on the family Volkswagen Jetta last year. Winter tires have deeper treads to dig down into the snow. They have a specific tread pattern and thousands more sipes—little tire slits—to chainsaw through the snow and push it out of the way. And they are made of high-tech compounds the keep the rubber much more pliable and at lower temperatures. They work like crazy.
But rather than tell you about it, watch this little video, shot on center ice at Denver’s Pepsi Center, home of the Avalanche hockey team.

Bridgestone, makers of the famed Blizzak winter tire, and Tire Rack, famed in its own right for its comprehensive testing of all the major tire brands it sells, took a group of bloggers to the hockey rink for a graphic test of all-season versus winter tire performance. The tests were simple and eye-opening. Have a look.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/iHg43iGPSi4" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Two BMW sedans line up at the starting line. The silver BMW has all-season tires; the red one has Blizzaks. The cars are flagged off, and they race to the finish line ahead. Actually, only the car with Blizzaks races. The BMW with all-season tires spins and spins, eventually stopping much later, and overshooting the finish line by a potentially deadly distance.

Switching cars and running the course again proves the point.. Then my favorite test: a simple drive down the ice to an easy, open right curve marked by cones. At a fairly low speed, the silver car loses steering as the tires give up, and it slides off course, plowing through cones.
It’s all harmless fun.  Until I go home.
I’m getting winter tires for the Suburban.

pageElements.text: After three-plus years of teases, the production-ready version of the Acura NSX was finally unveiled on Monday at Detroit’s North American International Auto Show. Even Jerry Seinfeld was there to watch its introduction. The original NSX, which trickled into the U.S. between 1990 and 2005, is still a hot property in the used-car biz, and it’ll be interesting to see how those values hold up when its twin-turbo, hyper-hybrid sequel finally hits showrooms later this year.
But it’ll be a whole lot more interesting to drive the new one, which should be possible by midyear. .

Like the original NSX, the revival is a mid-engine two-seater. But the parallels pretty much end right there. The original NSX was propelled by a 3.0-liter V-6 of rather modest output (270 horsepower). This new NSX is a hybrid, with a twin-turbo V-6 augmented by a trio of electric motors, one powering each front wheel and the third grafted between the engine and transmission.

The transmission is a nine-speed automatic, with manual shifting (via paddles) that can be race car quick, depending on operating mode. There are four: quiet (electric only), sport, sport+, and track.

Total system output is over 550 horsepower, according to Acura. Curb weight: Acura isn’t saying. The NSX’ s combination of carbon fiber, aluminum, high-strength steel, and composites is aimed at minimizing mass, but this is a substantially bigger car than the original, and we’ll be surprised if the new car weighs in under 3,500 pounds.
In terms of styling, the second-generation NSX has evolved during each auto show display since its 2012 concept  debut, each revision looking more wicked than the last.
“It’s just badass,” said Acura senior vice-president and general manager Mike Accavitti. “In a luxury kind of way.”

Luxury implies expensive, and here too the new NSX strays from its forebear. At about $60,000 in 1990, the original was a bargain compared with the cars it targeted, like the Ferrari 348. The new NSX has all the hallmarks of a supercar, and when it goes on sale in late 2015 it will wear a supercar price tag—“in the mid-$150,000 range,” according to Accavitti.

If you really need to know, you could call up Seinfeld. He’s set to become the owner of the first production NSX, a distinction he achieved versus Jay Leno. Maybe the issue was resolved by a rock-scissors-paper marathon that set a Guinness world record. It's fun to think so.

title: 2016 Toyota Tacoma
subTitle: Toyota steps up its game in the face of new competition in the mid-size truck market.
promoTeaserSmall: Toyota steps up its game in the face of new competition in the mid-size truck market.
promoTeaser: Toyota steps up its game in the face of new competition in the mid-size truck market.
metaDescription: Toyota steps up its game in the face of new competition in the mid-size truck market.

pageElements.text: Toyota has observed the “ain’t broke, don’t fix it" rule with the Tacoma for the better part of a decade, an approach that’s enhanced profitability through a long run of dominance in the mid-size pickup segment — about 60 percent of that market.
But with the impending arrival of GM’s new Chevrolet Colorado and GMC Canyon, Toyota’s Tacoma truck troops were galvanized (and funded) into action, generating an extensive redesign.
Engineered in Michigan, styled by Toyota’s Calty design operation, and slated for assembly in Texas, the new Tacomas will begin arriving in dealerships in the fall.

A key component in the revitalization is a new 3.5-liter V-6 featuring Toyota’s D-4S induction system that varies engine nourishment between port and direct fuel injection: port for low speed operation, direct fuel injection for higher speed horsepower. Toyota wasn’t ready to provide output numbers or fuel economy ratings, other than to say the new engine is expected to deliver improvements in both mpg and horsepower versus the current 4.0-liter V-6, which is rated for 236 horsepower and 266 pound-feet of torque.
The base engine will continue to be a 2.7-liter four-cylinder, currently rated for 159 hp and 180 lb-ft.
V-6 buyers will be able to choose between a six-speed automatic and a six-speed manual transmission, both described as new to the lineup.

Other Tacoma upgrades include more extensive use of high-strength steel, chassis stiffening, a modest little spoiler integrated with the tailgate, which also features damped opening (no more slam-downs) and lockability.

Suspension components have been retuned across the board. On the Toyota Racing Development versions (there are two, TRD Sport and TRD Off-Road), there's a new selectable terrain system that tailors throttle mapping, brake response, and traction control to operating conditions. There’s also a crawl feature, for steep downhills, as well as limited-slip and locking differentials.

The TRD Off-Road version has a standard GoPro camera mount near the rearview mirror, which is the kind of feature that can really put this vehicle high on the shopping list of an adventure-bound truck customer.

Cosmetically, the Tacoma draws heavily on the styling of the full-size Tundra pickup, with a new hexagonal grille, a higher hood, and macho fender flares. The redesigned interior should be quieter, thanks to a new acoustic glass windshield and more sound-deadening materials.

The model lineup will continue to include five choices. In addition to the two TRD versions, there’s the SR, a basic work truck; the sporty SR5; and the fancier Limited. Even more choice for a mid-size truck marketplace that has grown a lot this year.

title: 2016 Cadillac CTS-V
subTitle: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.
promoTeaserSmall: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.
promoTeaser: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.
metaDescription: The V denotes velocity. A lot of velocity.

pageElements.text:
So you say you have a need for speed? Cadillac addressed that by introducing its 2016 CTS-V super sedan at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit on Tuesday. Let’s just cut to the chase: it's a rear-wheel-drive, five-passenger luxury sedan that is capable of 200 mph in standard trim.

That puts the third generation of the CTS-V in some pretty rarefied company, especially among sedans. Particularly among American sedans, where this car's only rival will be the Dodge Charger with the 707-horsepower Hellcat V-8.

The new Cadillac, compared with the Hellcat, gets to 200 mph with a mere 640 horsepower (and 630 pound-feet of torque), huffed up by a version of the new Corvette Z06 6.2-liter supercharged V-8. That’s a serious gain versus the second generation, which was rated for 556 horsepower.

The supercharged eight sends power to the Caddy’s electronic limited-slip rear differential via a new eight-speed automatic transmission, which can be operated in manual mode with paddle shifters. Its use of a torque converter distinguishes it from the dual-clutch manumatics dominating the high-performance market, but Cadillac claims its up- and downshifts will match the best of the Euro competition.
As proof, Cadillac offers an impressive 0-to-60 mph claim: 3.7 seconds. Pretty brisk for a luxury sedan weighing more than two tons (4,145 pounds).

To get that much mass stopped from high speed, there's a robust new Brembo brake system, although there's no carbon-ceramic rotor option. Cadillac says extensive bracing has improved rigidity by 25 percent, suspension components are stiffer, the ZF variable-ratio electric power steering has been tweaked for better feel, and the latest generation of Cadillac's magnetic ride control continuously adjusts the suspension according to road conditions and driving style.

Visually, the V is distinguished from tamer members of the CTS clan by dedicated front and rear fascias, aero splitters fore and aft, a higher carbon fiber hoodline (to accommodate the supercharger) and an air extractor to mitigate underhood heat; and wider fender flares to accommodate those meaty Michelins.
There’s also an aero package option that adds downforce, at the expense of that 200-mph top speed.

While this and more add up to a formidable sport sedan package, Cadillac hasn’t neglected the luxury element. Division boss Johan de Nysschen claims the new super sedan will be as quiet and docile for everyday driving as any of its stablemates.

The bottom line: This is the most powerful Cadillac in the division’s 102-year history, as well as the most capable sedan. Like you, we’ll be looking forward to becoming better acquainted. However, that may be some time coming. The new CTS-V won’t be in showrooms until 2016.

title: 2016 Lexus GS F
subTitle: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.
promoTeaserSmall: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.
promoTeaser: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.
metaDescription: With 467 horsepower, the newest Lexus F aims at high-performance sedan market.

pageElements.text: It’s no secret that luxury performance sedans are earning an increasing share of the vehicle market, so it should come as no surprise that Lexus wants to increase its share of that increase.

If that does surprise you, the GS F provides yet another verification of the corporate strategy. This rear-wheel-drive high-performance sedan was presented to media at Detroit's North American International Auto Show this week. It is the latest addition to the Lexus F lineup, a relatively new sub-brand devoted to higher performance.
The mid-size GS sedan already has an F variant, the GS 350 F Sport, but this newly introduced GS F promises to provide a much more compelling (and fast) experience.

The key distinction between the two can be found beneath their hoods. The 350 F Sport's 3.5-liter V-6 generates 306 horsepower. Allied with the new eight-speed automatic that became available in 2014, a rear-wheel-drive GS 350 F Sport (also available with all-wheel drive) can be reasonably expected to reach 60 mph in a little over 5.5 seconds.
That’s respectable, but not enough to challenge in the realm Lexus wants to invade, a milieu populated by rides like the BMW M5, Cadillac CTS-V, Jaguar XFR, and Mercedes-Benz E63 AMG.

To that end, the GS F brings a much bigger punch to the free-for-all: a 5.0-liter V-8 rated for 467 horsepower, channeling thrust to the rear wheels via the new eight-speed automatic.The V-8 is the same engine that powers the Lexus RC F coupe, a certifiable thrill ride.
Although most of the benchmark competitors bring more power to the game, Lexus claims the GS F will be about 300 pounds lighter, give or take, than its rivals.

Other upgrades include structural stiffening and firmer suspension tuning. Also, the Lexus Torque Vectoring Differential (TVD) is standard equipment, enhancing transient response and reducing the angst of arriving a little too hot at a decreasing radius corner. Plus, it has unique orange brake calipers.
How will it hold up against its powerful competitors? We'll find out after the 2016 Lexus GS F goes on sale in the fall.

title: 2017 Ford GT
subTitle: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.
promoTeaserSmall: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.
promoTeaser: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.
metaDescription: It will take Ford back to Le Mans, but first, let's just look at it a little longer.

pageElements.text: The 2015 North American International Auto Show was chock-a-block with heart-pounding  new rides—the long-awaited Acura NSX supercar, the 200-mph Cadillac CTS-V sedan—but this one should have rolled out with auxiliary defibrillators.
Pulses raced, respiration was halting, and eyeballs bulged as the GT rotated in Ford's display area at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.
It was no surprise when the Eyes on Design judges, a panel composed of top automotive designers, anointed the Ford GT as the show’s best production vehicle.

At a glance, this might have seemed a little specious, since Ford billed the GT as a concept. But Ford fully intends to build this blue bullet, in order to qualify for a return to the Le Mans 24-hour race, the crucible that produced the immortal GT40 and four straight Le Mans victories in 1966, ’67, ’68, and ’69.

To enter the race, Ford must build at least 100 production examples. There will certainly be more than that—hard to make a business case for 100 cars, unless the plan is to price them at about $1 million each. As an index, production of the previous GT, conducted between 2004 and 2006, came to about 4,150 cars.
But we digress. Here’s what we know.

The GT is mostly carbon fiber, passenger compartment and body panels, with aluminum subframes to accommodate suspension elements, which are also aluminum. Racing touches include in-board shock absorbers, activated by pushrods, and carbon-ceramic brakes.

Ride height is adjustable, as is the active rear spoiler, which can be varied for both height and pitch. The doors are scissors style, as in a Lamborghini, rather than the gull wings of the earlier GT. The swoopy shape shows wind tunnel sculpting, although Ford refrained from furnishing any values, such as coefficient of drag.

Nor was there any reference to curb weight. However, we do know that the minimum weight for the GT’s Le Mans class—where it will be opposed by cars like the Ferrari 458, Chevrolet Corvette, Porsche 911, and Audi R8—is 2,745 pounds.
The engine will be an updated, twin-turbo version of an EcoBoost V6 (EcoBoost is how you say turbocharged at Ford) generating “over 600 horsepower” according to Ford engineers.

The racing plan targets the 2017 edition of the 24 Hours of Le Mans. Production is due to begin in late 2016. But you can probably open a dialogue with a selected Ford dealer sooner than that. Tomorrow might be good.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Somehow, Ford kept the reveal of the exotic GT a secret until show day. We heard whispers, we hoped, we prayed that it was coming. There were no early glimpses of prototypes or drawings to be found anywhere on the Internet. And then out it popped on Monday morning to the collective gasp of the crowd.
Who knew it would be this stunning?
Moray Callum, global head of Ford design, knew. And he was awfully proud.

He and the Ford stand were mobbed during the entire two-day press preview. Sightings around the rotating display included the world’s top designers and CEOs, who had to have been just a wee bit envious.
Moray’s brother Ian has been on quite a roll of late as head of Jaguar design. But this year will be all Moray’s.

pageElements.text:
1. Maserati Alfieri

The Alfieri’s rear is one of the sexiest at the show, sporting the flamboyant signature of Alfieri Maserati (named after his brother who died at the age of one), founder of the iconic sports car company in Milan, Italy, in 1914. I’m besotted with that signature. Alfieri – the car– was inspired by another famous Maserati, the luscious 1954 A6 GCS. Although we’ve called it out for that lovely going-away view, the Alfieri is beautiful from every angle.

2. Ford GT

What’s not to lust after? The first thing about the Ford GT that drew me to it was the rear. More specifically, my eyes locked on the steampunk-looking taillamp, looking for all the world like a bare light bulb stuck in a socket – the most beautiful bare light bulb you’ve ever seen.

Those bright round lamps are open in the middle and actually part of the cooling of the car. Imagine! The exhaust exits out through the taillights. The dual exhaust is right in the middle of the car, and the serrations inside it are repeated around the outside of the taillamp connections. Beautifully executed flying buttresses add to the strength of the GT’s rear view. I couldn’t take my eyes off it.

3. Mini Superleggera Vision

Finally, we get something from Mini that isn’t a Mini. This concept is an appropriate entry into a lineup that has had a few missteps, including the not so gorgeous Roadster two-seater. Mini just needed something a little more beautiful. No surprise, the Superleggera Vision (previously shown at the Paris and Los Angeles auto shows) is the work of the venerable Italian design house Touring. It’s whimsical, simple, and memorable. Love that shark fin in the back!

4. Infiniti Q60

The Q60's rear end is a beautiful representation of the design direction that Alfonso Albaisa has brought to Infiniti. The Q60’s rear is harmonious, deliberate, perfect. To me, the beauty of the rear view is the juxtaposition of the graphic layering of the dramatic roofline, the organic deck-lid spoiler, the Angry Bird taillights, and the dual exhaust. While the side of the car looks like it was chiseled, the rear looks like it was molded from a smooth piece of clay. When it goes into production as expected in 2016, the Q60 will finally be the epitome of what Infiniti has been trying to achieve since the brand was launched twenty-five years ago in 1989.

5. Lexus RCF GT3

Who doesn’t love a big-ass wing? What’s cool about the RCF GT3 is not only the giant wing (which is wider than the car and makes it look like a jet), but the four down-facing stabilizers hanging underneath like massive Veg-O-Matic blades. You wouldn’t want the RCF GT3 to stop fast in front of you. And what kind of person would you find behind the wheel? Other than me, I mean.

6. Hyundai Santa Cruz Concept

We haven’t seen a little trucklet (truck-ute?) as funky and fun as the Santa Cruz Concept since the Subaru Brat exited the market in 1993. Twenty-one years later, Hyundai quietly sneaks out the Santa Cruz in the darkest corner of its show stand in Detroit. It’s a concept that evokes the same northern California vibe as the town of Santa Cruz, with hieroglyphic logo typography that adds to the overall funky feeling. The rear of the Santa Cruz is hard to separate from the wholeness of this backpack on wheels. I love the idea that the bed could slide open like a refrigerator drawer. That would be awesome to see in production. It will go into production, won’t it?

7. 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Spider

Anything Alfa is trending right now, and a glance at the rear of the Spider shows you the reason. Everyone was talking about the Alfa Spider – this was such a hot car at the Detroit show that this is one of the press kits you could find on eBay before the day was over.

To really appreciate the rear of the Alfa, you should be on a balcony where you can get more than just a straight shot of the bold round taillamps and the logo; the overhead view puts everything together. As a piece, the 4C Spider is wildly sexy.

title: 7 Best Features for the Dog Owner
subTitle: If you travel with pets, you'll want to look for these when you shop for your next vehicle.
promoTitle: 7 Best Features for the Dog Owner
promoTeaserSmall: If you travel with pets, you'll want to look for these when you shop for your next vehicle.
promoTeaser: If you travel with pets, you'll want to look for these when you shop for your next vehicle.
keywords: 7 Best Features for the Dog Owner
metaTitle: 7 Best Features for the Dog Owner - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: If you travel with pets, you'll want to look for these when you shop for your next vehicle.

pageElements.text: Who is more important than your family when you're shopping for a car? You want a vehicle that's fun to drive and appeals to your senses, of course. But you also must be driving a car that's safe, comfortable, and easy to use well. That goes double for people with pets who come along for the ride. It's not as if your dog can tell you he's uncomfortable, but if your dog is not safely or comfortably placed, he'll find other ways of making that clear.

At the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, we were on the lookout for features on new models that can make travel with pets easier and more pleasant. Here are seven we loved. Look for items like these when you are shopping for your next ride. And check out our friends at VetStreet.com for more pet-related advice.

1. 2015 Ford F-150: A Boost for Pets and Equipment

Ford’s all-new, aluminum-bodied F-150 pickup is a big change for the most popular vehicle on the U.S. market. It’s lighter and more fuel-efficient, and there are also some improvements for those of us who load mega-bags of dog food and other pet equipment into the back. The four-door Crew Cab will accommodate your pets inside the cab, where they’re safest, with a spacious and practical back-seat area. Loading heavy objects or utility equipment into the truck bed is a snap with a new set of integrated rails that pull down from the left and right side of the bed.

There’s also an improved pull-down step and a box step on the side of the box. Result: Even short people can make maximum use of the carrying ability of this truck. The F-150 starts in the mid-$20,000s but can be optioned up to almost twice that number.

2. 2015 Land Rover LR4: Adjustable Seating That Is Truly Adjustable

Sure, lots of vehicles have seats that fold, but this is one SUV with truly practical seating when you’re loading in four-legged passengers and their gear. The individual seats are tall and narrow, although pleasantly upholstered. You can choose to fold only one seat in the second row for ease of access. You can do the same with the third row, leaving room for a crated pet to sit next to a comfortably seated human.
The model we checked out was the LR4 HSE Lux with V-6 engine, priced in the $60,000 range, but you can get an LR4 starting just over $50,000.

3. 2016 Kia Sorento: Cool and Comfortable in the Wayback

The safest place in the car for a dog is all the way in back, preferably in a harness or safety cage. Downside: It’s hard to find a vehicle, even one with three rows of seats, that has a set of climate controls to regulate the temperature back there. The all-new 2016 Kia Sorento does.

Whether you keep the third row seating up or fold it down, you can help your pet chill out with its own A/C  settings. The feature is standard on the EX, SX, and SX Limited models, all of which have the larger V-6 engine, and optional on the mid-range LX. Equipped as we saw it at the Detroit show, as the SX Limited with all-wheel drive, it cost around $45,000.

4. 2015 GMC Yukon/Chevrolet Tahoe and Suburban: Open the Liftgate with No Hands

Ford’s hands-free liftgate has been out for a couple of years on Ford’s small C-Max and medium-size Escape crossovers, and now the big utility vehicles from General Motors have it, too. Available as an option on the 2015 GMC Yukon and Chevrolet Tahoe and Suburban, this feature lets you just waggle your foot under the tailgate and, presto, it pops open. Your pet can clamber in while you keep your hands firmly attached to the bag of groceries you’re carrying.

The luxurious big Yukon and its even bigger Yukon XL sibling are priced starting around $65,000. On the Chevys, the hands-free liftgate is part of the LT model’s Luxury Package, or standard on the top-end LTZ, which starts around $62,000.

5. 2015 Subaru Outback Limited: Mmm, Toasty Warm Heated Rear Seats

Heated rear seats are found on many luxury cars, but the new Outback is one practical mid-priced model that has dual-stage heated seats in the back seats. Subaru product specialist Angie Ransdell told us that she even ordered these on her older Subaru Baja as an aftermarket add-on. “The older dogs like to relax. It’s good for their arthritis, and I have a seventeen-year-old Pekingese,” she said.

Rear seat heating is found in the top Limited model, which also has the benefit of a power liftgate with memory height. “It’s kind of slow to lift,” she says, “so just be aware of that when dogs are running in there.” The 2015 Subaru Outback Limited starts around $30,000.

6. 2015 Toyota Highlander Hybrid: Walkaround Space in the Second Row

What I always loved about my old minivans was the ability to move around freely between the seats. This Highlander SUV has a truly practical center console/cup holder in the second row. Made of sensible hard plastic, it snaps down to be a secure and stable place to put things.
Just as quickly and easily, you can fold it up to be completely out of the way. The 2015 Highlander starts around $30,000. The Hybrid we saw at the Detroit show is priced starting at $47,500.

7. 2015 Ram ProMaster City: Fear No Shedding with a Broomable Interior

If you are serious about taking a lot of pets, a lot of gear, or both out on the road, maybe this is more the kind of vehicle to consider.

The Chrysler division Ram doesn’t just make trucks; it makes this ProMaster compact utility vehicle that can be broomed and scrubbed out easily and has no velour seats to gather dog hair. Not fancy; just fabulous. The Ram ProMaster City starts under $25,000.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

pageElements.text:
Price: $63,575 (including destination charge)
Engine: 2.0-liter AMG turbocharged four-cylinder
Transmission: Seven-speed AMG Speedshift dual-clutch transmission with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/29 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: AMG engine
Option I can’t live without: Panorama sunroof ($1,480)
Notable standard features on this model: Eco start/stop, collision prevention assist, Attention Assist
Notable options: Red brake calipers ($300); Multimedia package ($2480); AMG performance seats ($2,250)
To borrow a phrase from my dear friend Nelly, “It’s getting hot in herre." [sic]

The introduction of the Mercedes-Benz GLA45 AMG into one of the hottest segments in the U.S. market—compact SUVs—is cause for celebration.  All the more so because this little whip is specifically going after the performance slice of America’s pie.

Quick history lesson: AMG began in 1967 as an independent engineering company that tweaked the performance and look of Mercedes-Benz vehicles. In 1990 Daimler-Benz took a controlling interest, and in 2005 the automaker became sole owner of AMG and operated the entity as a high-performance division of Mercedes-Benz. In the near future, it will actually be a separate marque. The three brands will be: Mercedes-Benz, Mercedes-AMG, and Mercedes-Maybach.

For the time being, AMG remains under the Mercedes-Benz umbrella. But to you and me, that is just semantics. For us, the important consideration is that this vehicle is a sports car masquerading as a sport-ute.

The GLA is built on the same platform as the wildly successful entry-level sedan, the Mercedes-Benz CLA. The Audi Q3 and the BMW X1 are the obvious competitors. However, the AMG version’s lofty price and superpower blur the lines, and buyers may be more likely to consider a competitor such as the Porsche Macan.

The base GLA45 AMG is $48,300, but the one we tested had options that added $14,350 to that price. Our only performance-enhancing option was the $450 performance exhaust. Our other options are; for aesthetics ($300 for red brake calipers, $850 for 20-inch wheels), safety (blind spot assist, $550), and luxury (upgrades that include infotainment, racing-style seats, park assist, and a fabulous panorama sunroof). That is a big chunk of change, but if you can stick with the base model and forgo some of the luxury, you can meet your needs for both cargo space and excitement at a more reasonable cost.

On the other hand, if high performance is your number-one criterion for your new compact sport-ute, and money is incidental, step right up. As far as performance, the GLA45 AMG comes out of the stable with a four-cylinder, 2.0-liter turbocharged engine with 355 horsepower and 332 pound-feet of torque. The seven-speed transmission with shift paddles adds to the pleasure of piloting the GLA45. The AMG is only available with all-wheel drive, although it remains in front-wheel drive unless a slip is detected. The engine note is the perfect reminder that this is not only a luxury sport-utility vehicle, but it has the kit to turn Clark Kent into Superman.

The GLA45 AMG is a very good-looking vehicle. The front is low to the ground, so low in fact that it is considered a car by the government. The twin blade on the matte titanium gray radiator grille is the first giveaway that this is an AMG model (that is a signature AMG design detail). There is also an AMG badge in the louvers of the grille, just to make sure everyone knows. The bi-xenon headlamps are standard. The hood has long vertical bulges, or in Mercedes lingo, “twin power domes.”
The optional Recaro performance seats cradle you like a nut in its shell. Warning to friends of the Kardashians: Your badonkadonk might not fit.

The rear is equally impressive with a titanium gray diffuser that race fans will recognize from the racing world. Its mission is to improve the vehicle's aerodynamics, smoothing the transition of the underbody. Built into the diffuser are two chrome-plated tailpipes. The difference in appearance from the non-AMG model is similar to Gerald Butler pre- and post 300.

Our GLA45 AMG was tricked out with the optional Recaro performance seats ($2,250) that cradle you like a nut in its shell. Warning to friends of the Kardashians: Your badonkadonk might not fit. There is an adjustment to widen the seat, but it seriously hardly moves. For those who do fit, it is a lovely cabin.

If you have seen the interior of a CLA (or been inside), it is very similar. The look is modern, right down to the iPad-like infotainment screen, which is oddly stuck on the dash and actually appears to be an aftermarket addition. I would prefer to see it more integrated into the dash. Since the GLA shares components from the entry-level CLA, some of the details border on cheap. Although I appreciate the design of the fans, the plastic looks more like it belongs in an economy car. The back seat is actually quite roomy, and the optional panorama roof makes the entire cabin seem very roomy.

With the addition of the panorama roof, the rear seat is actually a decent place for full-grown adults. The trunk will hold enough cargo for a weekend for four, and for two, you can pack the hatch for an extended romp.

Even though the GLA is fitted to tromp the competition at an illegal street race—Mercedes boasts a 0-to-60-mph time of 4.8 seconds and a top speed of 155 mph —this Mercedes has impressive fuel economy. At 23 mpg city and 29 mpg highway the tree huggers will leave you alone.

But to pony up the extra dollars for the GLA45 AMG over the base GLA250, which starts under $32,000, it is all about that performance. I found the added horsepower and torque exciting enough to make the upcharge a serious thought.

The exhaust note barked as it hummed down the road but without an embarrassing “look at me” pronouncement. The suspension is tighter than the standard GLA and delivered the smooth ride the luxury buyer demands.

The turbo engine supplied the boost for owning the highway, while the acceleration and tight steering were perfect for frogging my way through thick rush-hour traffic. Once I exited the highway and hit the twisty country roads, the GLA45 really shone. Unlike other vehicles that have stuffed a horse farm under the hood, the GLA married the equine load with a calm, luxurious ride. I did find the road noise a bit loud. In fact, I checked several times to see if I had inadvertently left a window down.

The Verdict:

This vehicle has hit the sweet spot of the SUV buyer who is jonesing for power rather than size. $48,000 buys a ticket into the exclusive Mercedes performance club, and that may be enough to entice some buyers to take a test drive. For the family of four that wants to make the drive to Grandma’s feel like a hot lap, the GLA45 AMG is ready for the trip.

Peanut Gallery:

Jean Jennings: AMG has become the soul of Mercedes-Benz, and that is so heartwarming to me because the performance division perfectly matches the basic Mercedes-Benz tenet: the best or nothing.

The sport-utility vehicle category has now filled out all the gaps between entry-level and luxury-sport. There is now a wide range of very well-built, useful, and fun sport-utes at the lower end of the price spectrum. I love this vehicle; but speaking for people who buy sport-utility vehicles based on their utility, I have to point out that for $68,000, you can find a lot of excitement and a whole lot more utility.

I know that's not what this vehicle is about. It's also not for "normal" people. It's for a segment of people who want a really special compact sport-utility vehicle. Maybe it's a second car; maybe it's a third car.

They'll be thrilled that there's one made by Mercedes-Benz, and they'll be double thrilled that AMG has waved its magic wand over it.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: I like the idea of a car that drives itself. I know the rest of the world is not 100 percent with me on that. But I’ve watched a lot of science fiction movies. In those, if you engage autopilot, you get to do fun things in your bunk instead of keeping your hands at ten and two. I want that. Every year at the Consumer Electronics Show, the self-driving car gets a little closer. This year it got within striking distance.

There is a lot of technology to work out still, and even more legal implications to argue. But a car that can take over the helm is coming at us fast. In fact, it’s coming at us in increments, hoping we won’t notice. One thing that’s not as difficult to solve as a car that can drive itself is a car that can stop itself before slamming into something. It doesn’t have to identify what it’s about to hit. It doesn’t have to take decisions away from the driver. It already knows you don’t want to smack anything. (Because of that, a few 2015 cars will stop, or nearly stop, when they see that a head-on collision is imminent.)

So while the world sorts out the technical and legal issues around sentient cars, great strides are being made in not-so-smart cars that don’t smash into things. I drove a BMW i3 outfitted with technology—still in the research stage—that could stop itself before I dinged any of its adorable exterior, no matter how bad I was at close-quarters driving. I couldn’t back into anything, sideswipe anything, or ram anything head on, even when I was trying.

BMW had a course set up on the roof of the SLS Las Vegas Hotel. Someone handed me the keys to that sweet ride and dared me to try and hit something with it. I wasn’t allowed to go faster than 15 miles per hour, because that is the point where this technology engages. But other than that? “Go ahead,” the researcher guarding the technology said. “Try to hit something.”
He was confident that the 360-degree laser cameras that protected the car would engage the auto-stop function without incident.
“Go ahead,” the researcher guarding the technology said. “Try to hit something.”
And try, I did.

I tried backing into a wall, which is more difficult than it sounds. I had to practice stopping myself from stopping the car first. But I quickly arrived at the perfect technique: close my eyes and floor it. The car kicked in, braking hard at the last minute and completely stopping before impact. I tried a sideswipe (just look away to accomplish this one): nope. The car came to a complete stop to protect its own side mirrors. Forward impact? Complete stop within kissing distance of the obstacle.
It was fun. I tried my best to be the worst driver in the world. But the car covered my gaffe every time.

This may not be quite as good as kicking back and watching a movie while the car drives I-5 for me, but I want it.  I certainly want it in any car my teenagers drive. And I suspect the insurance savings would go at least partway to justifying the purchase of a BMW.

pageElements.text:
When the Buick Avenir concept rolled out at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit, there was a collective gasp among the jaded journalists present. The beauty of this concept begins with the fact that it's rear-wheel drive. It's so much easier to make a rear-wheel-drive car beautiful because you can have good proportions: a short rear end and a long front. It just looks right in a way a front-wheel-drive car can't.

The young lead designer, Warrick Leach, really understands that, and he did an incredible job of creating a beautiful shape with lots of evocative Buick touches, including the boattail, stylized portholes, and the side spear.

Lisa Wetzel, head of Buick interiors, has been with General Motors design for years and comes from a multi-generation GM family. She has created an exquisite interior.

Just to wrap the whole thing up, the stand itself had design assistance from GM designer Chris Webb, who is a master of color and materials.

pageElements.text: I admit to having been completely amazed when I discovered that a woman, Michelle Christensen, was the chief designer of the 2016 Acura NSX. I can't think of any other aggressive two-seat sports car with a woman as its chief designer.

Michelle is a graduate of the Art Center College of Design, and her mentor there was Dave Marek, who is global creative director of Acura Design. He has been teaching there for years. Apparently it’s a really good thing to do, because you get to see all the hot talent first. So Dave brought Michelle to Acura in 2005, as the first-generation NSX was ending its run, and then gave her this assignment.

The front is surprisingly aggressive, and I like the layers of materials and textures. Still, it’s a little bit controversial, but controversy isn't always a bad thing. Michelle explains in the video.

This car would have been the star of the 2015 North American International Auto Show if there hadn’t been a surprise appearance by the Ford GT. A Ford spokesman claims it was a pure coincidence, but as the NSX was being revealed, Ford slowly rolled the GT down the aisle past the back of the NSX stand on its way to Ford, causing hundreds of heads to be diverted from the NSX’s big moment.

title: Millennials Love Cars After All
subTitle: Five fun facts from a new MTV study. #4: They like driving even more than Baby Boomers do.
promoTeaserSmall: Five fun facts from a new MTV study. #4: They like driving even more than Baby Boomers do.
promoTeaser: Five fun facts from a new MTV study. #4: They like driving even more than Baby Boomers do.
metaDescription: Five fun facts from a new MTV study. #4: They like driving even more than Baby Boomers do.

pageElements.text: Have you heard that the current generation of young adults is not interested in cars? Don’t listen to the conventional wisdom. Sure they do! An MTV study, just released, confirms it. The youth-oriented station’s survey shows that Millennials find their cars so essential, they’d even rather give up their beloved social media and texting (at least temporarily) than their cars.

The Millennial generation, considered to include people born between 1981 and 2000, is distinguished from older generations by the kind and amount of technology they use and how comfortable they are with it. Pronouncements from groups like the University of Michigan Transportation Research Institute, the Washington Post, and Time magazine have claimed that the kids just don’t want to drive cars anymore; they’re just fine with staying in touch with other people online instead.
Wrong, says MTV’s study, which studied 3,600 people aged 18 to 34 and found the following:
1. If they had to choose between a day of social media or a day in their car, 75 percent would give up the social media;
2. How about a longer challenge? 72 percent would stop texting for a week rather than stop driving for a week;

3. Yes, they’re not driving as much as older generations, but as they approach their thirties, they are definitely interested in car ownership, the study finds.

4. They also enjoy driving a lot: 70 percent of Millennials surveyed said they like to drive, versus only 58 percent of my age group, the Baby Boomers.

5. The surveyed Millennials also made it clear they want their buying experience to be easier and more technologically oriented: 80 percent want the buying process to be quicker, and 87 percent want a “more transparent” buying experience.
MTV presented these results at a meeting of the National Auto Dealers Association (NADA), telling them dealers should be working to make the shopping experience more desirable for Millennials.
But really, people of any age would like a quicker, easier experience when they shop, wouldn’t we?
Wondering whether you're in the same mental space as this age group? The Pew Research Center's quiz lets you find out: How Millennial are you?
