pageElements.text: We keep saying every year, there can’t be another Mustang. But here it is, the 2016 Ford Shelby Mustang GT350R.

That R? Well think of it as Racer with a capital R. This particular Mustang was designed for pure performance. It’s interesting to hear Chris Svensson, Ford's design director of The Americas, describe, in this video, how design impacts a performance car, or how critical the designer’s role is in creating a better performance car. All of that AND creating a striking presence.
So now for just one more Mustang, okay? Because, according to Svensson, this particular Mustang is The Best One Yet. He makes his case in this video. I’m totally buying it.

pageElements.text: All you need to know about the Infiniti Q60 Concept is that I think it’s absolutely exquisite, and I'm not the only one. It's a tour de force with its elegant, understated, but decisive deign.

Okay, maybe that’s not all you need to know. For instance, the Q60 Concept is very much the car that will come into production in 2016 minus a few show car flourishes. But it was clear that the body panels were stampings and insiders nodded in the affirmative when I quizzed them about the beautiful, quilted leather interior and luxurious console and dash.

It will go head to head with luxury sport coupes such as the Mercedes-Benz C-Class, BMW 4 Series, and Audi A5, and will undoubtedly start around $40,000 and go up from there.

Sadly, Infiniti executive design director Alfonso Albaisa’s voice had all but given up the ghost five minutes before I showed up to do the walkaround with him at the show. We waited a few hours to see if the hot tea helped, but by then his voice was totally gone. (See the walkaround here of the Infiniti Q80 Inspiration Concept, which I did with Albaisa at the Los Angeles Auto Show last fall.)

I soldiered on without him, sycophantic in the extreme. He’ll probably want me to do all his designer walkarounds from now on.

metaDescription: Small, urban friendly, and sassy. But is it really a Jeep? And is it right for you? Read our review of the 2015 Jeep Renegade on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text:
2015 Jeep Renegade Trailhawk

Base price: $26,990 (including destination)
This car: $33,830 (including destination)
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 180 horsepower
Transmission: Nine-speed automatic
Fuel economy: Not yet announced
My favorite standard feature: Selec-Terrain four-wheel drive system
Options I can’t live without: Four-wheel drive, blind spot monitor
Notable standard features on this model: Select-Terrain five-mode 4WD; additional ride height; underbody skid plates; auxiliary oil cooler; seven-inch instrument panel color information display
Notable options on this model: Navigation, satellite radio, trailer towing group, removable power sunroof, Premium group (heated power leather seats, heated leather-wrapped steering wheel, windshield wiper de-icer, 40/20/40-split rear seat with cargo pass-through)
You might also be considering: Buick Encore, Honda HR-V, Kia Soul, Nissan Juke
General George C. Marshall referred to the original World War II Jeep as “America’s greatest contribution to modern warfare.” Wonder what he’d think about this one?

But let’s start with a more serious question. Is this newest addition to the Jeep family worthy of the name? It certainly looks like a Jeep, with that unmistakable grille, just rugged enough in appearance to avoid cuteness.

But to really answer that question, we must reflect on the essence of Jeepness: the ability, when properly equipped, to navigate terrain and/or conditions that would make lesser vehicles plead for mercy.

It’s not unfair to say that there are a couple of vehicles wearing Jeep badges that are a little marginal in terms of this metric. But the Renegade is not one of them. With four-wheel drive (a $2,000 option), the Renegade is happy to keep going when the pavement ends. And in the top Trailhawk trim, it displays the sure-footed mountain goat capabilities that set most Jeeps apart from other off-road wannabes.

While the Renegade measures up as best in class on the go-anywhere scale, it’s a major departure from Jeep’s all-American tradition, a function of Fiat’s ownership. It was designed and engineered in the United States, but it’s assembled in Melfi, Italy, and has been on sale in Europe since last fall. The optional 2.4-liter Tigershark four-cylinder engine (180 horsepower) and nine-speed automatic transmission come from Michigan, but the standard 1.4-liter turbocharged four (160 horsepower) is from the Fiat inventory, and the structure is adapted from the Fiat 500L.

This is not only the newest of Jeeps, it’s also the smallest: 15.4 inches shorter than the compact Cherokee, 7.2 inches shorter than the Patriot. But it’s at the bigger end of its competitive spectrum of subcompact crossover sport-utilities. (Jeep prefers the word  “small” to subcompact.) Interior designers are increasingly clever at making the most of tight exterior dimensions, and that’s true inside the Renegade. Like others, the new Jeep is rated for five passengers, which is optimistic if the center rear occupant is much beyond five years old. But there’s enough room for two adults to reside back there in reasonable comfort.

This smallest of Jeeps also provides cargo capacity that’s at the top of the charts in this class—18.8 cubic feet behind the rear seats, 48.4 with the rear seat backs folded forward. Interior materials look to be durable. The instrumentation is straightforward, augmented by an information display tucked between the speedometer and tachometer, and the designers solved the problem of accommodating a pair of cupholders in the narrow center console by installing an electric parking brake, rather than the traditional mechanical type, operated by a handle.

However, while the interior reinforces the Renegade’s toughness, some of the surfaces—the upper dashboard in particular—could use a little soft-touch material, and the front seats could use a little more under-thigh support.
Back on the positive side of the ledger, the Renegade offers a navigation option, and of course there’s a menu of the infotainment and connectivity features using Chrysler's Uconnect technology.

Driving: As you’d expect of a vehicle with more ground clearance than anything in its class, plus the option of two sophisticated four-wheel-drive systems (the basic Renegade is front-wheel drive), the new Jeep is fully at home on the range, far more than any vehicle in this class. And with the Trailhawk option, there’s even more ground clearance, more suspension travel, and a unique (to this class) menu of off-road operating modes.

Off-road prowess comes as no surprise. But the Renegade’s pavement behavior is, and a pleasant one at that. Its size, short wheelbase, and firm suspension tuning make it one of the more nimble vehicles in this class. Its responses are eager, with modest rock and roll, and like all the small scale crossover SUVs, its size makes it handy in urban traffic—not to mention urban parking.

The only downside in urban traffic is substantial rear-quarter blind spots, thanks to the beefy rear roof pillar, although this can be mitigated by the optional blind spot warning system. (Jeep cites an array of up to 70 Renegade safety features, standard and optional.)

In highway driving, the electric power steering doesn’t provide much tactile information, although the power assist diminishes with speed, and it’s one of those things that owners can become acclimated to over time.

There are two engine/transmission combos to choose from. The 1.4-liter, 160-horsepower turbo is standard on the lower trim levels of the Renegade. It comes with a six-speed manual transmission that’s very precise and reinforces the driver’s sense of engagement with the vehicle, which, to some, adds up to more fun to drive.

The base 1.4-liter engine has plenty of grunt, provided the driver keeps the engine turning at 2000 rpm or more. Below that level, the engine is lifeless. The electronic management of an automatic transmission would keep the engine operating closer to its sweet spot, but that’s not an option with the 1.4. The more powerful 2.4-liter, standard on the Trailhawk model, is automatic only, the nine-speed. It's the personification of smooth operation, but the combination does add up at the bottom line.

The bottom line: checking option boxes is always something to be approached with care, but that’s particularly true with the Renegade. At $24,290, a mid-grade four-wheel-drive Latitude model is an attractive proposition, but loaded versions of the top-of-the line models such as the Limited or Trailhawk soar past $32,000.

The Verdict:

There are several possible competitors if you're looking for an SUV this size. If a luxurious small crossover is the objective, the Buick Encore is worth a look—handsome interior, quiet, refined. And if the objective is more performance (on pavement), the Nissan Juke lineup offers lots of horsepower and aggressive handling options, maxing below $30,000.

But discretion in the purchase process will get the buyer into a well-equipped Renegade, including even the Trailhawk (from $26,990) at less than $30,000.  It’s a combination of cheeky styling, urban handiness, all-around usefulness, and unbeatable off-road competence that gives it a special niche in a growing market segment. And yes, it’s really a Jeep.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text: Craig Metros, Ford's exterior design director of The Americas, is a native of Dearborn, Michigan, graduated from the College for Creative Studies in Detroit, and has been all around the world with Ford. Now he's back to bring us the 2017 Raptor version of the F-150 pickup.

The Raptor used to be a spidery little truck that you could imagine bouncing around in the desert. Wait a minute. It DID bounce around the desert, down on our southern border of Mexico in the hands of immigration agents.
This new Raptor still looks like an extreme race truck, but now its front end looks like it was chiseled out of an ingot of steel, fender to fender Ford.
No, you don't have to guess who made the truck following you. And God forbid you you be hit with it, because the back of your car would be embossed forever with "Ford," written backward.

contributors.bio: I was born a suburban Detroit gal where the preoccupation with cars is practically genetic.  As a young adult I kicked around motor-racing, training to drive while I worked at a Brands Hatch satellite in Miami.  I've been race staff at the Detroit Grand Prix, worked TV coverage of Formula 1, Indy and NASCAR and done the occasional ride and drive program.  Eventually my racing aspirations gave way to a long held interest in filmmaking and I got my B.A. from the University of Michigan's burgeoning film program.  U of M taught me to write and introduced me to my excellent husband.  We spent five adventurous years in Los Angeles in the entertainment and publishing industries before returning to Ann Arbor where our lovely daughter came into the world.  Personally, I expend a good deal of energy on K-12 public education advocacy.  Professionally, I've been a freelance writer for the last ten years specializing in health issues and automotive content from a lifestyle perspective.  There's a lot more to auto life than zero to sixty.

pageElements.text: Super Bowl XLIX, or, as they like to make people call it, the Big Game, happens this Sunday, Feb. 1. A much-anticipated part of the festivities is seeing the over-the-top commercials, with automakers' ads usually high on the list of favorites.

Increasingly, you can see all or part of the ads ahead of time. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles announced on Thursday that it will be running three as yet unspecified ads during the game; will Eminem be featured? we wonder.

As for those that are viewable now, we've conveniently assembled the clips here for you. Which are your favorites? Comment below!

1. Toyota

Toyota Camry’s pre-bowl #OneBoldChoice campaign features NFL players, along with regular Joes, reflecting on the experience of fatherhood. The extended cut is so touching, even the iciest of hearts will feel a little thaw.

Just as moving is the actual ad that will air Sunday under the title “How Great I Am,” featuring Paralympian Amy Purdy. Drums riff in the background as Muhammad Ali boasts: “I have wrestled with an alligator. I done tussled with a whale…” Shots of Purdy in a Toyota Camry are intercut with a progression of training trials and personal triumphs. Linking the reliable everyman’s Camry with the likes of Ali and Purdy, two badass originals in the first degree, is a bold choice.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/PjUfygo5mzw" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

2. Mercedes-AMG

“The Big Race” campaign by Mercedes has taken an interesting tack in its Super Bowl ad buildup. Four advance spots tout an epic showdown between that fabled pair, the Tortoise and the Hare, along with a viewing party contest, have been creating anticipation for a special advertising event on Super Bowl night. The actual commercial (revealing the race winner) premiered on Ellen DeGeneres's talk show on January 26, undercutting that Super Bowl thunder somewhat.

Here's one of the four Tortoise and Hare advance ads.



The game day commercial itself is a polished piece of animation from Maleficent film director Robert Stromberg, and the race begins just as the old story goes. Then we learn there’s something powerful and mysterious in the woods: the Mercedes-AMG GT S. You can guess which competitor ends up behind the wheel.

3. Nissan

Nissan hasn’t run a Super Bowl commercial since 1997, so the pressure is on to make this reentry memorable. The automaker will run a 90-second ad, only a brief clip of which has been released ahead of time. To generate excitement for its corollary #withdad campaign, focusing on fathers’ struggles to balance work and family, Nissan solicited the help of YouTube videomakers to capture dad moments. Check out the video selections to see what these video dads came up with. Word is the Murano may make an appearance during the game night spot.

4. BMW

Putting the spotlight on the BMW i3, the “Newfangled Idea” commercial might be the most clever use of cultural memory since Volkswagen introduced us to little Darth Vader. To highlight the revolutionary nature of its all-electric vehicle, BMW employs a real clip of NBC Today Show anchors Katie Couric and Bryant Gumbel. filmed circa 1994, in which the anchors are completely bewildered by a new thing they call Internet. This pitch-perfect ad has pros Couric and Gumbel befuddled once again, 20 years later, by another new technological concept.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/U1jwWwJ-Mxc" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

5. Lexus

To announce its turbo/hybrid NX, Lexus's “Make Some Noise” piece is energetic and moody at the same time. It blends ambient car sounds (the rev of the engine, the whir of the moonroof, the squeal of the tires) with percussive images of maneuvering Lexuses and dancers. It’s all about the young up and comer vibe in this spot that directs the viewer, “Be seen, be heard.”

6. Kia

Veteran James Bond Pierce Brosnan learns that action-adventure doesn't have to mean explosions or car chases, while he brings class and romance to the 2016 Kia Sorento.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="//www.youtube.com/embed/rSqqCI0LNHs" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

7. Volvo

Then there’s Volvo, which isn’t even airing a commercial Sunday night but rather running an online campaign it calls Volvo Interception. Its ad asks viewers watching the Super Bowl to tweet the name of someone worthy to win a XC60, using #VolvoContest, every time they see someone else’s car commercial. To nominate someone you must also explain in your tweet why that person is so deserving of a new SUV. Volvo seems to be thinking that, while other car companies are talking about themselves, Volvo wants you to know who is important: you.

pageElements.text: Lincoln caused a stir in the industry when it stole hot young designer Max Wolff away from Cadillac in 2010 to be its first chief designer. But it didn’t pan out.
Lo and behold, Lincoln found a talented replacement right at home.

Actually, David Woodhouse—who was slotted in over Wolff in December 2013—is a Brit, but he’s been working his way through all sorts of Ford design jobs for the past fifteen years. He’s family.
 
The sleek MKX that Woodhouse showed us in Detroit has produced the first real buzz Lincoln has enjoyed as it struggles back to its feet. All the rest of the buzz up to this point has been about when it was going under.
It’s funny to me that the signs of life at Lincoln are emanating from an SUV rather than a car. Then again, the MKX has the width to finally give those tortured Lincoln wings some space to fly.
In this walkaround, Woodhouse shows us a few more design details that give the new MKX its distinctive flair.

title: 5 Reasons to Want LED on Your Next Car
subTitle: Here's why they do more than just give a car a pretty face (and rear view).
promoTitle: 5 Reasons to Want LED on Your Next Car
promoTeaserSmall: Here's why they do more than just give a car a pretty face (and rear view).

keywords: 5 Reasons to Want LED on Your Next Car
metaTitle: 5 Reasons to Want LED Lights on Your Next Car - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: Your next car will be better off to have them, and here are five reasons why. Read about LED lights on JeanKnowsCars.com.

pageElements.text: Like many features you’d now consider indispensable, LED lighting is a bit of technology that was seen first on luxury-level cars. But that’s not going to be true for long; it will eventually become something you’ll see on cars and trucks at a wide variety of price points. In fact, there are already affordable vehicles that sport these eye-catching lights in front, in back, and even inside.
Other than looking pretty as a design element, and sparkly and brilliant to a passer-by on a dark night, what is the point of LED lighting, and is it worth trying to get on your next car?
Here are five things to know.

1.

You can see better with them. Light-emitting diodes, or LEDs, are much brighter than traditional halogen or incandescent lights, yet they’re closer to the experience of seeing natural light, so they’re not as hard on the eyes. They’re also more capable of precision: In the Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class, for example, there are 24 individual LEDs inside each headlamp, so light distribution can be precisely controlled.

2.

People can see your car better. Audi claims LED head- and taillights activate as much as 10 times faster than incandescent lights, letting other drivers spot your brake lights sooner. Many vehicles that haven't gone full LED for the headlights do have LED daytime running lights, making your car more visible during daylight hours as well: this 2015 Dodge Charger, for instance.

3.

They are good-looking and, because individual LED lights can be laid out in various shapes, can become an important style element. On the Acura MDX, for example, there are five LEDs in each headlamp, laid out in a row in what the company calls a “jewel eye” design.

4.

They’re more energy efficient. LED lights don’t have a filament like traditional headlamps, so they’re more durable. They’re also less of a power drain, and they can last much longer before they burn out. For example, Ford lighting expert John Teodecki says the LED headlamps in the 2015 F-150 pickup use 63 percent less energy than halogen bulbs and are expected to last five times longer.

5.

Going LED is becoming more affordable as popular models adopt the technology. For example, even the base model of the 2015 Toyota Corolla has LED low-beam headlights with halogen high beams and LED daytime running lights.

pageElements.text: First, the good news: You may have less chance of being killed in a car crash these days. If you are in a car or truck built in the past few years, your risk of dying in an accident has gone down by a third in the past three years alone. That’s according to the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an independent research group that just released a new study on the subject. The study covered 2011 models and measured death rates by model through the end of the 2012 calendar year.

The safety increase is mainly due to improvements in how cars are built, with more safety features and better structural design, IIHS says, but also to the increase in numbers of large vehicles, including SUVs.

Let’s just roll that idea around in our heads for a minute. A one-third reduction in deaths in newer cars. In clearer language: Just using the numbers from 2012, there are 7,700 people alive today who wouldn’t have been, if cars were still built the same they were in 1985.

Next, the really good news: There are nine models that showed driver death rates of zero. IIHS explains that the death rates are calculated per million registered vehicles from 2011. Earlier models going back to 2009 were included if they weren't given a major redesign in between.

Which leads to the bad news: The death rate varies widely depending on what car or truck you’re driving. Not surprisingly, very small cars tend to have higher death rates, while large SUVs tended to show lower rates in the study.

Now, what does this mean to the car buyer? Not that you should automatically pick the biggest car out there. Instead, as a shopper, consider this as one piece of information among many to help you choose tradeoffs between how much car you need, what you can afford, and what safety features your particular choice has on board.
One thing’s for sure: studies like this one are an important way automakers are nudged to improve their products, which is good news for everyone.

subTitle: The hottest version of the critically acclaimed car. Is it for you?

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-door, all-wheel-drive hatchback
Price: Base price $37,415; as tested $39,090 (prices include destination)
Engine: 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder, 292 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed dual-clutch automatic
Fuel economy: 23 mpg city/30 mpg highway; uses premium fuel
My favorite standard feature: DSG automated manual transmission
Options I can’t live without: DCC adaptive suspension system, navigation
Notable standard features on this model: All-wheel drive, leather seats, bi-xenon headlights
Notable options on this model: DCC adaptive suspension, navigation, 19-inch alloy wheels with high-performance tires
You might also be considering: Audi S3, Subaru WRX STi, 2016 Ford Focus ST

What could be more useful and fun to drive than a 2015 Golf GTI? For folks familiar with the evolution of Volkswagen’s family of compact hatchbacks, now in their seventh generation spanning four decades, the answer is easy: the 2015 Golf R.

But there’s an asterisk. The GTI, dating to 1983 in the U.S., is the company's traditional hot rod, with more horsepower and sharper responses than the standard Golf. The R series, which traces its beginnings to 1981, amplifies both those attributes and adds all-wheel drive.

Two catches: it may be a little extreme for many. And it may be a little more than you want to spend.

The Golf R brings 292 horsepower to the party. That's 82 more than the GTI and 36 more than the previous R version. It’s basically the same 2.0-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine employed in the entire gasoline-powered Golf lineup, fed by a bigger turbo and fortified by a number of internal enhancements.
That’s big punch for a compact hatchback, amplified by the slightly lower curb weight of the latest generation Golf.
Volkswagen calls it the fastest Golf ever sold in the United States.

Of course, there’s more to the driving experience of the Golf R than increased engine output and sheer speed. The R rides a bit lower than the GTI, and its suspension tuning is firmer. There are more driver-selectable operating modes, particularly with the optional DCC, which includes adaptive shock absorbers that automatically adjust to operating parameters: Comfort, Normal, Individual, and Race. The brakes are the biggest of any Golf and provide formidable stopping power.
VW anticipates a 0-to-60-mph sprint in 4.9 seconds, about a half-second quicker than the 2016 Golf R with a six-speed manual transmission, available sometime this summer.

There's equally formidable power flowing through VW’s outstanding DSG dual-clutch six-speed automatic transmission to all four wheels via the company’s 4Motion all-wheel-drive system. VW anticipates a 0-to-60-mph sprint in 4.9 seconds. That's about a half-second quicker than the upcoming 2016 model of the Golf R with a six-speed manual transmission, which will become available sometime this summer.

There isn’t a lot of exterior distinction between the Golf R and the GTI. The R has its own bumpers, side sills, headlamps, and rear diffuser, but the distinctions are subtle. The wheel styles are the most visible difference, along with the four tailpipes (the GTI has two).

Inside, the R’s leather-clad heated bucket seats (standard) provide track-worthy lateral support, and the center-dash touchscreen offers an extensive menu of operating options. In the upper-level Golf R with DCC & Navigation, as the name suggests, there's also a nav system.

But the most vivid distinction is the one that’s communicated by the driver’s backside and hands. The R accelerates with gusto and hangs on in fast corners like a bat in a wind tunnel. Its steering is both racing-car quick (less than 2.2 turns of the wheel from extreme left to extreme right) and laser precise.

The Verdict:

For drivers who like to exercise their cars at track days or autocross events, the Golf is a great choice: a hot hatchback that inspires instant confidence at the first set of fast turns.

But, as high-performance compact cars go, the Golf R also includes an unusually high practicality index. It shares that trait with the rest of the lineup. Like other compact hatchbacks, it’s a design capable of swallowing far more cargo than comparable sedans. For example, with its rear seatbacks up, the Golf’s cargo space is almost 23 cubic feet, whereas the trunk of a Volkswagen Jetta, the Golf’s structural cousin, is less than 16 cubic feet. Fold the Golf’s rear seatbacks forward, and capacity increases to almost 53 cubic feet—room enough for a couple of weeks of groceries, a mountain bike or two, and a big flat-screen TV.
Also, the R’s performance doesn’t extract a big fuel economy penalty. It’s EPA rated for 23 mpg in the city, 30 on the highway, a 3-mpg improvement on the highway cycle over the previous Golf R.

On the other hand, the GTI is rated for 25 mpg city, 33 highway with the DSG transmission. (Both models burn premium unleaded.) And the R’s ride quality may be a trifle stiff for some tastes, particularly in four-season climates, where winter makes mosaics of the pavement.

Then there’s the bottom line. With a base price of $37,415, the R costs about $6,000 more than a GTI. Choose the Golf R with DCC & Navigation, and the price gets perilously close to $40,000. That base price will come down by about $1,200 sometime this summer, when a manual-transmission version becomes available for the 2016 model year.

So how compelling is your need for speed? If it’s strong, the Golf R offers a very compelling proposition, a super hot hatchback with few rivals, mainly its cousin once removed, the Audi S3, and the upcoming 2016 Ford Focus RS.

But if that need is only moderate, the GTI delivers plenty of driver gratification, and it's kinder to your wallet.

title: Moving Backward
subTitle: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.
promoTeaserSmall: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.
promoTeaser: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.
metaDescription: Jean's grandmother saw the downside of turning in a horse and buggy for a car.

pageElements.text:
This story was written by my father, Automotive News editor Robert Lienert, in 1980.—Jean

My parents were products of their time and place, and when they were married early in 1906, the automotive age had not yet reached Nebraska.
My father farmed with horses and gave them up reluctantly when tractors took over, much later.

As a bride, my mother had her own horse. It was a "buggy" horse. That is, it was not so big and awkward and cumbersome as a draft horse. When she wanted to visit a neighbor or go to town, she'd whistle for her horse and he'd come to the barn.
She could harness him and hitch him to the buggy and be on her way. As a result, she was more independent than were many farm wives.
My parents were married about fifteen years before they bought their first automobile. For my mother, the car did not lead to freedom or open the way to a mobile society.

As the family acquired cars and the "modern" age burst upon her, the private "buggy" horse was displaced. And my mother never learned to drive a car. I never asked why. But I recall that riding in a car made her nervous, and it would have been in character for my father to feel that only men drove cars.

My mother thus had to depend on someone else to take her when she wanted to go anywhere. And since my father often didn't wish to go places, my mother spent a lot more time at home in her mature years.
The automobile, rather than freeing her, confined her more than ever.

Here in the Ice Belt, where Jean Knows Cars does business, our quality of life currently involves dealing with winter weather. We have just tested something that, for the price of a nice lunch, can make your whole winter experience better if you’re a street or driveway parker.

The iceScreen Magnetic Ice Shield covers the windshield of your vehicle, stays on with no drama, pulls off with no hassle or struggle, and gives you a perfectly clear view with absolutely no shoveling or scraping. It’s sold online for $29.95 to $40 (depending on whether you get the standard model we bought or the deluxe version that has a reflective sunshade on the reverse side). There’s even a large-format Ice Shield for trucks ($29.95).

There’s still lots of winter yet, but the iceScreen people are currently selling these for 50 percent off on their website. Such a deal even at the list price.
How to use it:

On: Put the Ice Shield on the windshield. It takes seconds, and with the aid of several strong magnets, it’s foolproof. Side flaps get closed in the front doors to keep the shield from flying away in a high wind--or being stolen. Hint: Tuck in the flaps iafter you’ve completed installing the shield; it’s an exercise in futility to try to slam them in the doors while the shield is loose.
Off: Don't remove the Ice Shield until you remove snow from the rest of the car, so you don't undo the work the magic screen did for you.

title: 2015 Chicago Auto Show Preview
subTitle: 10 new models and concepts we look forward to seeing at this week's media days.
promoTeaserSmall: 10 new models and concepts we look forward to seeing at this week's media days.
promoTeaser: 10 new models and concepts we look forward to seeing at this week's media days.
metaDescription: 10 new models and concepts we look forward to seeing at this week's media days.

pageElements.text: Next week, the automotive spotlight is going to shine on Chicago—not because of its legendarily miserable February weather, but because of its 107-year-old auto show. While it may not have the glamour of Geneva or the high profile of New York, the Chicago Auto Show is actually the largest and best attended in the country. We’ll be there, in a crowd of more than 3,000 journalists from around the world, and we’ll be showing you these new models and concepts in more detail. Meanwhile, here’s a glimpse at 10 that will be worth waiting for.

1. 2016 Ford Police Interceptor

First things first! The handsome teaser photo at the top of this page tells the story: Ford's Chicago-built cop car is all new for 2016. Actually, it's a cop utility vehicle, as the photo shows. It's only fitting it makes its debut in Chicago. (I'm trying really hard not to make a Blues Brothers reference here.) The Ford Police Interceptor also comes in a sedan version.

2. 2016 Acura RDX

The compact crossover gets an update. No images have been released yet (we're showing the 2015 model here), but the 2016 is expected to add more creature comforts into an already pretty swank product: It already has V-6 power, leather seats (heated in front), and a rearview camera, all standard, but look for a luxury upgrade with the 2016 model. Acura says some “desirable” safety features will also be added.The current model is priced just under $35,000. The new one is expected in dealerships in the summer.

3. 2016 Honda Pilot

The eight-passenger Pilot is all new for 2016. Honda wants you to know that it was designed, developed, and will be built entirely in the U.S., where we love our SUVs. The automaker is promising a “dramatic” change to the somewhat dull current design along with new technology and better fuel economy (the current model, priced starting around $30,000, tops out at 18 mpg city, 25 mpg highway). It will be in dealerships this summer.

4. 2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata

Chicago is where the very first Mazda Miata was introduced way back in 1989. The new Miata, shown here, has already been revealed, but in Chicago, Mazda will announce important details like: how much horsepower does the U.S.-market Miata get? There was a bit of excitement when it was briefly stated, possibly incorrectly, by the show organizers that the new Miata will have 155 horsepower. So stay tuned.

5. 2016 Chevrolet Equinox

This five-passenger crossover is already very popular. In fact, it's Chevrolet's second-best-selling vehicle, after the Silverado pickup. At the Chicago show, Chevrolet is rolling out an updated 2016 model. The current Equinox is priced economically, starting in the low $20,000s, although top-end versions sell in the mid-$30,000s. It comes with four-cylinder or V-6 engine choices and competes in a tough area, against such big sellers as the Honda CR-V, Toyota RAV4, and Ford Escape.

6. 2016 Ram

Details on this introduction are sketchy, but the automaker is offering a public live feed of the rollout, so let's just say that it's important, and pickup customers who liked the news about the new Ford F-150 should want to watch this as well. The introduction happens on Thursday, Feb. 12, at 2:30 p.m. ET, if you're interested.

7. 2016 Toyota Avalon

An all-new model of Toyota's most luxurious, and some might say most staid, sedan will be rolled out in Chicago. Expect to see a modernized version and, if the teaser photo is an indication, some LED lights and a more aggressive-looking grille. The current Avalon comes in V-6 and four-cylinder/battery-electric hybrid versions and sells starting at around $33,000.

8. Kia Trail'ster Concept

If you already enjoy the cheerful wackiness of the Kia Soul, you'll love this off-road, electric-powered concept version. The Trail'ster concept has it all: it's an EV. It has a canvas roof that folds all the way back. It has all-wheel drive. Will you someday be able to buy a version of this go-anywhere Soul? Hoping so! But even if not, points to Kia for another cute idea. (Demerits for the bad punctuation, though.)

9. Nissan NISMO Street Concept and GT-R

Fresh from its star turn in the “With Dad” commercial during the Super Bowl, the NISMO GT-R racing car will be in Chicago to greet the public, starting on Feb. 14. After that? It’s on to the 24 Hours of Le Mans. By its side will be a new NISMO street concept, which will be unveiled as part of a whole NISMO (Nissan Motorsport) performance-car display featuring NISMO versions of the Juke, 370Z, and GT-R.

10. 2016 Toyota Camry and Corolla Special Editions

These bread-and-butter cars are getting more interesting, thanks to special edition models that will first be seen at the Chicago show. The Camry, shown here, was already all new for 2015, and the 2016 Special Edition will have smoked taillamps, a power moonroof, a sport gauge cluster, sporty seating with contrast stitching, and more. It will be sold in a limited edition of 12,000 starting in August.

As for the smaller Corolla, it also gets special touches including a black-and-red theme inside, push-button start, and optional moonroof and premium audio/navigation. Only 8,000 Corolla Special Edition models will be built starting in August.

pageElements.text: You've probably heard a lot about the danger of leaving children and pets in a car in hot weather. But this time of year, when it's below freezing in much of the country, has dangers of its own. Here are four rules never to break.

1. No leaving kids and pets in a cold car.

Just as it gets hotter in the car in warm weather than outside temperatures might indicate, it can be colder in the car than you think. It should be obvious that you don't leave children unattended, but just last week a couple in Washington, D.C., left a toddler and a baby in their car in cold temperatures while they attended a wine tasting. They're staring down a hefty fine, a possible jail term, and loss of custody during court proceedings. And rightly so.

2. No bulky outerwear in the car seat.

Now this is hard to do, because it could mean strapping an un-coated child into a chilly car, but you've got to make sure the car seat harness is snug for safety. Put your child into a warmed-up car without the snowsuit or parka. Once he or she is safely strapped in (with no more than a finger's pinch of give in the strap), you can put the heavy coat, or a blanket, over the top for warmth. This is important because, in a crash, the squishy fabric of a winter coat will compress, leaving your child too loose in the seat. High-end car seat maker Britax shows you how it should look.

3. Clear snow off your windows, roof—and tailpipe.

A few unfortunate cases in the Northeast ought to convince you that carbon monoxide asphyxiation can happen too easily to a child sitting inside a car while it idles. The first thing to clear on your car is the tailpipe. Then do the windows. Then you can put a child in the car while you finish up. Carbon monoxide poisoning does happen this way. Think it can't? Here's an example of a time it did, while the parent was still shoveling out the car.

4. Supply your car in case of delays.

Have a winter kit in the car with snacks, drinks, and changes of clothes. It will be much easier to sit in a traffic backup, or manage a weather-related delay, if you and the kids aren't starving, cold, or wet. Those of you with diaper-age children, it goes without saying that you need to carry a supply of diapers, wipes, and somewhere to stash the used ones. Refer to our comprehensive winter preparation list here.

contributors.bio: When I turned sixteen, my dad brought home the very first-generation Ford Escort wagon, and it just so happened to have a manual transmission. Since—like every other sixteen-year-old—I knew everything, I was sure that I would just get behind the wheel and effortlessly shift gears. Visions of screeching into the school parking lot with my shiny red "world car" and impressing all the burnouts who hung out near their Detroit muscle cars danced in my head. All of those dreams were quickly extinguished in the first fifteen minutes of my driving lesson from my dad. Although he has a teaching certificate, patience is not his strongest skill. The subtle foot-hand coordination escaped me, and we were jerking around the subdivision like the contestants in a game of Red Light Green Light. I blamed my dad, and he blamed me. To my astonishment, he decided it was best to abandon ship and allow me to figure out how to get home. Somehow I managed to limp home without needing therapy for whiplash. After our wounds had healed I did end up learning to drive a manual on that trusty steed. I ended up driving my Escort to Northern Michigan University in Marquette, in Michigan’s frigid Upper Peninsula, where I obtained a BFA, with a concentration in Graphic Design, and a future husband. I joined Automobile Magazine at the tender age of twenty-eight and fell in love with the energy and passion for automobiles and the way they enhance our lives. Later, I took a five-year hiatus and boned up my design and web skills and am now turbocharged to be a part of the Jean Knows Cars team. Many years have passed, and now my sixteen-year-old only child is poised to learn to drive a manual, and I can’t help but be transported back to my teens. Unlike my parents, I am a helicopter mom. Riding in the passenger's seat with her behind the wheel is like waterboarding. I want to order her to pull over and allow me to drive and throw her in the back seat with airbags strapped directly on her. Many of her peers will not learn to drive a manual, but I believe that it is the building block for a good safe driver. It is a perfect synergy watching my daughter learn to drive and helping Jean Knows Cars celebrate and embrace the automobile and how it is woven into our lives.

Type: Five-passenger, rear-wheel-drive sedan
Base price: $60,400 (including destination)
This car: $66,400 (including destination)

Transmission: Eight-speed automatic; Drive Mode Select with Sport, Normal, Comfort, and Snow settings

My favorite standard feature: Heated steering wheel
Options I can’t live without: Power reclining rear seats
Notable standard features on this model: Lexicon 17-speaker surround sound, heated front and rear seats
Notable options on this model: Head-up display
You might also be considering: 2015 Lexus LS460 ($73,445), 2015 Cadillac CTS ($46,340), 2015 Infiniti Q70 ($50,755), 2015 Acura RLX ($49,370) (prices include destination)

Hello, America: Kia makes luxury cars. Forget your preconceived notion that Kia produces entry-level sedans and boxy SUVs. The 2015 Kia K900’s mission is to change your mind about the brand. It's priced (including destination charges) at $55,400 for the Premium version and $60,400 for the Luxury model we drove. This rear-wheel-drive sedan is all first-class, and its stunning good looks should help put the 1993 Kia Sephia way, way, far away in your rearview mirror.

The K900’s designer is the automotive rock star designer of the Audi TT, Peter Schreyer. He has been steering Kia’s design studio since 2006, and much of Kia’s success rests firmly on his shoulders. When it comes to luxury brands, the competition starts at the grille, and Schreyer’s signature tiger-grille look has been tweaked to make the K900 sit comfortably next to its competitors. The LED headlights complement the grille and establish an upscale feeling. The perfect proportions of the short front overhang and the long sweeping rear with elegant chrome details make for an impressive silhouette. Kudos to Kia for putting the brand in the hands of this German designer.

Inside, the K900 feels like a design show that I'd watch on HGTV. The attention to look and feel is actually turned up a notch once you enter the cabin, and the styling is very modern. The standard push-button start brings to life a full digital gauge cluster. I like this direction, but I immediately wondered how much it would cost to replace once the warranty is over.

The back seat is roomy and comfortable for full-size adults. When I took a turn back there, I immediately flashed back to being ferried around New York City in the back of a Lincoln Town Car in the 1990s. The current car-for-hire industry seems to have fallen in love with the large SUV, but in my mind they should seriously consider the K900. It is a most lovely place to spend time. Heated seats and a panoramic sunroof are standard. Hidden inside the center armrest are climate control buttons and rear window sunshade controls. But for those opting to add the VIP package ($6,000), the rear seats are also cooled; they recline and have lumbar controls. Kia’s ad campaign shows LeBron James retreating to the rear seat of his K900 in his driveway to escape the chaos of his life. I think those ads are spot on.
If you can’t get a comfortable seating position in this car, you may need a visit to a chiropractor.

The Luxury model comes standard with a list of amenities that should make the competition blush with embarrassment. The most luxurious item to me on a single-digit winter day when I drove the K900 was the heated leather-wrapped steering wheel. Those of you who do not live in cold climates will never understand this luxury. The interior is swathed in high-end leather and wood trim, specifically walnut in the VIP-appointed version. A head-up display (HUD) is included in that package, and it is truly worth a test drive just to experience this feature. Vehicle speed, turn-by-turn navigation, blind spot detection, and the lane departure warning system are all integrated into the color HUD. Right ahead of you, conveniently displayed on the windshield, you see a graphic depiction of vehicles that are on the road around you. The blind spot detection system will still give an audible alert if you engage the turn signal if a hazard is detected. Heated and cooled front seats come standard, and the VIP package adds a 16-way power seat with a cushion extension. If you can’t get a comfortable seating position in this car, you may need a visit to a chiropractor.

The audio system and the navigation share a 9.2-inch screen that can be accessed through the steering wheel or a control in the center console. The standard Lexicon surround sound made me think of my colleague Laura Sky Brown, who likes to listen to Beethoven's Symphony No. 9 cranked up to eleven in the car. If she closes her eyes in the reclining rear seat, perhaps she will think she is at Carnegie Hall. Both front and rear cameras are standard.

Front and rear park assist sensors are standard, as is rear cross-traffic alert,  which provides an audible warning if cross traffic is detected from the rear while the vehicle is in reverse. The VIP package adds a Surround View monitor that has four wide-angle cameras.

Also included in the VIP package is Kia’s advanced vehicle safety management system, which includes electronic stability control and multiple warning systems to alert the driver to danger,pre-pressurize the braking system, and activate the pre-safe belt system when needed. The K900 comes standard with many features that you'll find as options on competitor vehicles, but this level of safety is becoming a must in the luxury segment.

The K900 is equipped with Kia’s first V-8 and came paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission. The car delivers a very smooth ride, and there is plenty of power at your disposal. It is most happy humming down the Interstate, where it offers an ultra-library-quiet ride with very little road or engine noise creeping into the tranquil cabin. Twisty roads expose the K900’s weakness. It quickly loses its composure, and you can feel body roll almost immediately. Then again, the K900 is built for luxury, not to be a sports car.

The Verdict:

The K900 is up against stiff competition by the established incumbents in the luxury segment. The big dogs of German luxury cars may swat Kia down with their big fat tails, but the K900 is a serious contender for the other Asian marques and in contention to nip into Lincoln and Cadillac sales, too. If your top priorities are luxury and comfort, if you spend long hours commuting on the Interstate, or if you drive others for a living, and want to do it in style, you will be happy with an investment in the K900.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: The Kia K900 is a full-on luxury car, aimed at people who are considering a Mercedes, BMW, or Audi. But I think it’s going to be more attractive to people moving up to the luxury segment from a Hyundai, Honda, or Toyota sedan, and especially to people who would otherwise be shopping a Buick or a Cadillac. It’s for you if you’re the person who likes that living-room-sofa feeling with all the creature comforts—but step on it, and you’ll realize it also has a very assertive V-8 under the hood. You’d have to be confident in your standing among your fellow citizens to spend $60,000 on a car with the Kia badge on it. This Korean brand’s stature will only grow as time goes on, but right now it has little of the cachet that people pay for when they spend big on a car. If you don’t care too much about that stuff, there’s a lot to love about the clean, elegant, well-laid-out K900.
I don't have to tell you how beautiful the Kia K900 is because you can see that for yourself.—Jean Jennings

Jean Jennings: I don't have to tell you how beautiful the Kia K900 is because you can see that for yourself. The interior is equally gorgeous: the horizontal layout of the dash gives the interior a spacious and elegant look complemented by luxurious leather. If you thought Kias were cheap entry-level cars, the K900 should disabuse you of that notion.

Driving the K900 gives you the feeling that you're in a very substantial vehicle complete with all the safety bells and whistles. But I'd like to pick out one particular feature that I'm absolutely enamored of: the head-up display.

There are two pieces of information on the HUD, both critical to me. First is my speed, which I am in desperate need of keeping track of at all times. The K900's HUD shows speed in a small, clear, easy to read, unobtrusive number in the periphery of your field of vision. Thank you.

Second is Kia's brilliant take on lane departure warning. No bells, no buzzers, just a little icon that pops up either to the left or the right of your indicated speed reading when the car enters your blind spot.

This is critical for those bad dogs who forget to turn on their turn signals when they change lanes. The detection system on most cars is triggered by the turn signal. The Kia does have an audible alert when the turn signal is on, but the best part is that even if you don't, the HUD is proactive and front and center, right where your eyes are most of the time. Thank you very much.

contributors.bio:
When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: For her portrayal of author Cheryl Strayed in Wild, Reese Witherspoon earned an Academy Award nomination.

Cheryl solo-hikes the Pacific Crest Trail through most of California and all of Oregon in the hope of finding release from her torments. Chief among them is the premature death of her mother, Bobbi (Laura Dern), the free spirit who guided Cheryl and her brother through difficult circumstances.
Some scenes present the family car: a Volvo 245 wagon, perfectly cast for its role.
Flashbacks tell the story as Cheryl plods along under a heavy backpack, nicknamed Monster. Some scenes present the family car: a Volvo 245 wagon, perfectly cast for its role.

The real-life owner explains on Reddit that he had advertised the car for sale on Craigslist. A $500 offer would have sufficed, he wrote, but a movie scout made arrangements to use the car for a month, paying nearly $2,000. Recently, the car was once again going up for sale, with screenshots from the movie to be attached to the ad as “a fun selling point.”
In the United States, Volvo’s 240 models, introduced in 1974, have always been prized, especially as they became available in the used-car market.
Their reputation for safety was one draw, and for durability, another.

The 240 stayed in production until 1993. During those nineteen years, aerodynamic designs from Audi and Ford reshaped the automobile, yet the Volvo’s boxy styling spoke to people. How do kids draw cars? Three distinct sections—although even a child’s pencil might skid to a stop rather than make such goggling headlamps.

More than forty years since their debut, 240-series Volvos are still a regular sight on streets and highways. Individualists, nonconformists, former Deadheads, people trying to hide their wealth, and misfits with excellent automotive taste drive them. Many are dinged up (we mean the cars). Hipsters have started restoration jobs, though, and we think the final destination is the same garages with ratty, dropped-handlebar cafe racer motorcycles and Mercedes-Benz CLA sedans.

If the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences awarded an Oscar for Best Vehicle in a Supporting Role, the Volvo wagon from Wild would unquestionably be a nominee, keeping company with great film cars like the Joads’ 1926 Hudson Super Six from The Grapes of Wrath and the Brass Era replicar in Chitty Chitty Bang Bang.
The common thread among them is transcendence.

contributors.displayName: Laura Sky Brown and Molly Jean

pageElements.text:
2016 Ford Police Interceptor Utility

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive utility vehicle
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 304 horsepower, or turbocharged 3.5-liter V-6, 365 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with Pursuit mode
Most interesting option: Choice of 25 light patterns, including blinking white "wig-wag" function offered "in a nod to police vehicle nostalgia"

Media days at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show start tomorrow, but today, we strolled through the Concept and Technology Garage inside McCormick Place, following the sound of sirens, and there it was: the new 2016 Ford Police Interceptor, lights flashing, taking a slow parade lap.
Naturally, we wanted a ride. And we got one, but first, a little about the vehicle.

Ford's police cars have garnered great popularity among police departments, which you may have noticed in recent years. Ford's cop lineup has a dominant 55 percent market share in the U.S. But did you know that the sport-utility vehicle version, based on the Explorer, is the most popular seller? We didn't. In fact, the SUV outsells the sedan version two to one.
Ford spokesman William Mattiace told us that this Police Interceptor "has really changed the face of police vehicles from cars to SUVs."
It's also sold in 80 countries, but it's built 100 percent by Ford and 100 percent in the city of Chicago.

Mattiace invited us in to the cop car (Laura insisted on sitting in back, in the perp seat). We admired the surveillance technology, which uses sensors and the car's rearview camera to spot whether people are approaching the car and will raise windows and lock doors for protection. It was the idea of engineer Randy Freiburger, who was on site.

Chief engineer Arie Groeneveld told us about his team's work on the new model. "We put our heart and soul into the Police Interceptor," he told us. Ford stays in constant contact with a police advisory board and hold formal meetings twice a year, and then they fine tune based on suggestions. Groeneveld was enthusiastic about safety moves like a rear assembly that has been impact tested to 75 mph. "Nobody else does that," he told us. "We're at the top of our game on safety."

The seats are also made to accommodate police officers' weapons, handcuffs, and other items they carry on their bodies, with durability testing to make the seats both comfortable and durable for them. The interior of the Police Interceptor didn't look terribly different from a standard Explorer, except for a lot more controls in the center console. Up on the headliner, Mattiace demonstrated the red dome light that lets officers spend long evening hours in the car without having to get their eyes reaccustomed to the dark when they're done.

It was fun to ride in the car, but we didn't lose sight of the fact that the Police Interceptor Utility is more than just a ruggedly good-looking SUV with cool graphics. With its specialized equipment, all-wheel drive, and the choice of a 304-horsepower 3.7-liter V-6 or a 365-horsepower EcoBoost V-6 turbo, this is a vehicle with serious work to do. Which is why we were met with polite smiles but no comment when we asked where we could find the optional doughnut holder.

title: 2016 Honda Pilot
subTitle: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.
promoTeaserSmall: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.
promoTeaser: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.
metaDescription: A truly stylish Pilot takes center stage at the Chicago Auto Show.

pageElements.text: The 2016 Honda Pilot will bring something to showrooms this summer that the current Pilot lacks: style. It made its debut at the Chicago Auto Show, where it did something surprising for this previously staid product: It threatened to steal the spotlight from all other new-model introductions.

On the threshold of its third generation, the 2016 Pilot discards the trucky, two-box design of generation two for a more rounded profile, with a roofline that slopes away slightly at the rear, a strong character line below the windows, and LED running lights accenting LED headlamps.
The new sheetmetal surrounds new architecture, shared with the Odyssey minivan and the next-generation Honda Ridgeline pickup that's coming for 2017.
Honda’s Chicago show presentation was thin on specifications, but this much emerged: the 2016 Pilot is 3.5 inches longer, yielding more interior room.

At the same time, Honda says the Pilot will weigh up to 300 pounds less. The engineers say there's a greater percentage of high strength steel in the structure, as well as more aluminum and other lightweight materials. The high-strength steel also accounts for increased structural rigidity, according to Honda, although percentages of increase weren’t revealed.

The 2016 Pilot gets a new engine, a 3.5-liter V-6 with direct fuel injection, cylinder deactivation, and a start/stop feature. This V-6 is new to the Pilot, but not to Honda; it’s adapted from the 278-horsepower version in the Accord sedan. The current Pilot has a 250-horsepower 3.5-liter V-6.

Honda refrained from releasing power numbers for the V-6 in Pilot tune, as well as EPA fuel economy projections. But with a more efficient engine, those projections will be an improvement over the current Pilot’s 18 mpg city/25 highway (17/24 with all-wheel drive).
A new nine-speed automatic transmission with paddle shifters is offered in higher trim levels.

Like previous generations, the 2016 Honda Pilot is front-wheel drive, with the option of all-wheel drive. However, the 2016 AWD option is a new system, a six-speed automatic transmission replaces the previous five-speed, and a new nine-speed automatic, with paddle shifters, is offered in higher trim levels.

Interior design and materials move up a notch, and there are a number of new upscale options: a heated steering wheel; perforated leather front seats, heated and ventilated; heated leather second row seats; a panoramic power moonroof; second-row captain’s chairs; and LED map lights. There are also numerous new electronic features—five USB ports, four of them capable of recharging iPads and/or smartphones, as well as audio player jacks, an HDMI video game port, two 12-volt outlets, and a 115-volt power outlet.

There’s a new eight-inch touchscreen option, home for a new satellite navigation system with graphics that render images in 3D. And of course there’s enhanced connectivity, via the HondaLink infotainment system.

The current Pilot earned top safety ratings from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, and Honda expects the 2016 Pilot will duplicate that achievement, with a host of driver assistance features, including a new road departure mitigation system, and enhanced crashworthiness.
Pricing remains to be revealed. Current Pilot pricing starts at $30,750 for the basic front-wheel-drive LX, climbing to $42,500 for the top-of-the-line Touring model.

title: Kia Trail'ster Concept
subTitle: The hip'ster darling goes off-road. This Soul-based concept is begging to be built so I can buy one.

pageElements.text: Sitting two and a half inches higher off the ground than the Kia Soul it's based on, the Kia Trail'ster concept made its debut at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show. It looks a little like a Soul on its way to Outward Bound camp. It's only a concept, but Kia is looking for a positive popular reaction to help it decide whether a production version is in the cards. Count me as a "yes."

"We love the purposeful design of outdoor sports equipment," said Tom Kearns of the California Kia Design Center, the concept's chief designer. It shows in the anodized fire-red aluminum wheel details, the tough-looking grille and foglamps, and the use of aluminum trim elements inside and out, even on the floor mats.

A major difference from the current Kia is a full-length roll-back canvas top. Kearns told the assembled media that this not only reduces weight, it "brings the outside in." There's also a set of aluminum skid plates to protect the underside, with the bonus of giving the Soul a sexy athletic appearance.

The Trail'ster has an electric all-wheel-drive system. The vehicle is powered by a turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder engine making 185 horsepower that teams with a rear electric motor and a lithium-ion-polymer battery; at low speeds, you could run the Trail'ster on electric power only. Because of the efficiency of the so-called "through the road" hybrid power system, Kia says fuel economy could be as much as 30 percent better around town and up to 10 percent on the highway over the current gasoline-powered Soul (which gets 24/31 mpg).

The ambitious Korean automaker has graduated from its role as a budget brand and mastered the art of trendsetting design. (It's true, the the all-new 2016 Rio subcompact was also being introduced today, but it didn't get much fanfare.)

It's great that Kia has added rugged design elements to the cute Soul. I suppose if it goes into production (which I fervently hope it does), we'll see commercials showing backpack-toting, flannel-shirt-wearing hamsters. That would actually be fun.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- and all-wheel-drive luxury crossover
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 279 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 20 mpg city/29 mpg highway (front-wheel-drive model); 19/28 mpg (all-wheel-drive model)
Most interesting option: AcuraWatch (includes adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, autonomous collision mitigation braking, rearview camera), part of Advance option package

At a glance, RDX looks like initials you’d see on the little slip of paper from a pharmacist. In a way, that’s not entirely inaccurate—it’s Acura’s prescription for one of the most popular vehicles in its class.

That class is defined as “entry premium SUV,” and for 2016 Acura builds on the RDX’s best sales year so far (2014) with a freshening that includes styling, safety features, interior trim, and performance. Acura division boss Mike Accavitti calls it “ratcheting up the emotional content.”
Typical of mid-cycle updates, the exterior styling changes are confined to the front and rear of the RDX, plus a new wheel design.

Lighting is an important part of Acura design. The 2016 RDX gets LED projector headlights that Acura calls "jewel eye," already present on Acura models including the ILX and RLX sedans. In back, there are new LED taillamps ringed with "light pipes": LED-fired tubes that emit a neonesque glow.
Interior changes include a black color scheme highlighted by silver trim and standard heated front seats.

Interior changes include a black color scheme highlighted by silver trim and standard heated front seats. The optional Technology package adds eight-way power adjustability for the front passenger seat, a dual-screen multi-information display, a blind spot monitor, and rear cross-traffic alert.

An Advance package option adds keyless remote engine start, front and rear parking sensors, front fog lights, rain-sensing wipers, ventilated front seats, and an auto-dimming driver’s-side mirror. It also includes the AcuraWatch suite of driver assist features, such as adaptive cruise control, lane departure warning, lane-keeping assist, autonomous braking to mitigate collisions, a driver’s-side mirror with expanded view, and a rearview camera.

Based on information supplied by radar and a monocular camera, AcuraWatch is capable of detecting road hazards and pedestrians. The system includes a 4.2-inch TFT display screen, with customizable readouts. Included in the Advance package, AcuraWatch will also be available as a stand-alone option.
Acura’s navigation system, which features voice recognition, is a separate option.

Acura also enhanced the 2016 RDX's structure. Along with the safety technology additions, this should help it sustain top safety ratings from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. The 2015 model, first introduced three years earlier, has straight Good ratings from IIHS and the top five-star overall rating from NHTSA.

Like the 2015 model, the 2016 RDX is basically a front-wheel-drive vehicle with an all-wheel-drive option and a 3.5-liter V-6 engine. The chassis engineers have reprogrammed the all-wheel- drive system to deliver a higher percentage of the engine’s output to the rear wheels as needed.

The engine, which includes a cylinder deactivation feature for light load situations, provides what Acura calls an “important performance boost,” adding six horsepower (up to 279) and one pound-foot of torque (to 252), across a broader curve. Accompanying this all-but-intangible output increase is a 1-mpg improvement in EPA highway fuel economy ratings: 20 mpg city, 29 highway with front-wheel drive, 19/28 with all-wheel drive.
The 2016 Acura RDX is due to go on sale this spring. Prices weren't announced yet, but the 2015 model starts at $36,015 (including destination).

subTitle: The brute in black tie.

pageElements.text:
2015 Ram 1500 Laramie Limited

Type: Luxury pickup; trim available in 1500, 2500, and 3500 single- and dual-rear-wheel, four-wheel or rear-wheel drive, and short- and long-wheelbase models
On-sale date: Second quarter 2015; Ram Laramie Limited 2500 and 3500 models coming late 2015 as 2016 models
Engine: Several choices, including 3.0-liter "Ecodiesel" V-6, 240 horsepower
Transmission: Eight-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/29 mpg highway with Ecodiesel V-6
Most interesting option: Black Argento wood trim

Pickup trucks may be the spiritual descendants of the Wild West buckboard wagon, but we have long since outgrown our taste for bare-bones utilitarianism in these all-purpose vehicles, and the 2015 Ram Laramie Limited is the latest proof.

Introduced in the wide-open spaces of Chicago’s McCormick Place show facility, the Limited upstages the Laramie Longhorn as the Ram’s premier trim level, trumping the Longhorn’s cowboyesque theme with a hedonistic interior treatment and mass quantities of exterior bling, particularly in the heavy-duty Ram 2500 and 3500.

The exterior of the Laramie Limited 1500 is a little more restrained, with body-colored bumpers, rather than the glittering chrome of the HD models. But for those who rejoice in in brightwork, no worries—the chrome bumpers are available as an option.

Chrome also draws attention to the oversize Ram logos fore and aft. The one affixed to the tailgate, 20 inches wide, is particularly hard to miss. In addition to enough chrome to dazzle passersby on sunny days, the Limited is further distinguished by LEDs sprinkled around the exterior—marker lights, running lights, turn signals.

And check that grille. Besides all the bright trim, do you notice anything unusual? Right, the traditional gunsight grille is absent. This isn’t the first time, either—it was absent on the Ram Rebel off-roader, presented at the recent Detroit show. (See our video walkaround of that model here.)

The interior decor is a sophisticated black-tie black. The premium leather seats are picked out with fancy white stitching, the center console has a leather lid, and there’s leather in the inner door panels, on the armrests, on the door panel uppers, and around most of the steering wheel.
The portions of the rim that aren’t leather-wrapped are finished in glossy Black Argento, a dark wood shot with spidery silver lines. There’s also Argento trim in the door panels and on the dashboard. Very tasty.
Also tasty: Berber-carpeted floor mats. Practical, too—they’re removable, to keep them pristine when mud and slush find their way into the truck.

As you’d expect of a vehicle that calls itself Limited, the standard feature list is comprehensive, including premium audio, navigation, an 8.4-inch center dash display, Uconnect telematics, and instrument graphics and illumination with a sophisticated look.

The Limiteds will be offered with the full range of Ram powertrains, including the 3.0-liter turbo-diesel that allows the Ram 1500 to call itself the most fuel efficient half-ton pickup in the business.
And in Laramie Limited trim, it can add to that distinction: the most fuel-efficient half-tonner appropriate for a night at the opera.
Offered only as a crew cab, look for the Ram 1500 Laramie Limited to appear in showrooms this spring, and HD models next fall.

title: 2016 Toyota Avalon
subTitle: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.
promoTeaserSmall: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.
promoTeaser: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.
metaDescription: Subtle adjustments to a successful package.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive mid-size sedan
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 3.5-liter V-6, 268 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 21 mpg city/31 mpg highway
Most interesting option: Qi wireless charging, part of Premium Audio package with Navigation and App Suite (standard on XLE Premium model)

There's much to admire in the refreshed 2016 Toyota Avalon, which made its debut at the Chicago Auto Show this week. Looking at it, we're reminded of the days when the Avalon was an underappreciated player in Toyota's popular passenger-car lineup. Not anymore.

The Avalon has shed its former image as a ride for retirees, starting with a major make-over in 2012 when it was re-engineered and restyled. As Toyota says, it was the first product to "meet Toyota President Akio Toyoda’s challenge to create cars that spark people’s emotions."

In fact, with that 2012 redesign, the made-in-the-U.S. Avalon was really the opening salvo of a product renaissance for Toyota. With it, the brand started its move away from the bland designs of past generations. It added sophisticated good looks, more driver gratification, and quicker response.

The combination of standout styling and improved agility propelled the Avalon to tops in the premium sedan class, racking up higher sales than competitors like the Chrysler 300, Hyundai Azera, and Kia Cadenza. And it’s not unfair to say that it outshines even its own corporate cousin, the Lexus ES350.

So, for 2016, Toyota is applying the “ain’t broke, don’t fix it” rule to a very modest refresh. The trim levels grow from four to five: XLE, XLE Plus, XLE Premium, Touring, and Limited. The 268-horsepower V-6 and six-speed automatic transmission are unchanged, as are EPA ratings of 21 mpg in the city, 31 mpg on the highway.

The Avalon Hybrid continues, with a combined 200 maximum horsepower from a 2.4-liter four-cylinder gasoline engine augmented by an electric motor. It's available in XLE Plus, XLE Premium, and Limited versions. EPA ratings are 40 mpg in the city, 39 mpg on the highway.

Toyota made only modest cosmetic changes to the 2016 Avalon, among them the addition of LED headlights to the Touring model. The front end sports a wider grille, new headlamps, and vertical turn signals. The fog lamps have disappeared, and Touring models have a slightly different front end treatment to go with the LED lights. The Touring also gets a dark gray finish; like the other Avalons, it has 18-inch wheels and tires.
New taillights and chrome bumper trim distinguish the 2016 rear end from the current Avalon.

While nothing changes under the hood, the chassis team has tweaked the suspension for smoother ride quality in most models. However, Touring models have been subtly stiffened, to keep sportier-minded drivers happy.
You'll be able to find the 2016 Avalon in the Toyota dealership this fall.

title: 2016 Chevrolet Equinox
subTitle: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.
promoTeaserSmall: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.
promoTeaser: A tasteful update to Chevy's compact-crossover contender.

pageElements.text:
Type: Five-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive compact crossover
On-sale date: Fall 2015
Engine: 2.4-liter four-cylinder, 182 horsepower(L and LS models); 3.6-liter V-6, 301 horsepower (LT and LTZ)
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 22 mpg city/32 mpg highway (FWD); 20/29 mpg (AWD)
Most interesting option: 4G LTE Wi-Fi hot spot

The first thing to know about the Chevrolet Equinox is that it’s hugely popular. It’s Chevrolet’s second-best-selling vehicle, after the Silverado pickup. Chevrolet’s U.S. vice-president, Brian Sweeney, said there are more than a million on the road today, and you probably wouldn't argue that point, so frequent are Equinox sightings in mall parking lots and suburban streetscapes.
It's true; in the increasingly popular category of family-friendly SUVs, the Equinox plays a strong role.

So it's logical that the 2016 Equinox, making its world debut at the Chicago Auto Show this week, didn't mess with the winning formula too much. The changes involved a modest update to its looks, both front and rear.

There are now LED daytime running lights, plus new headlights and fog lamps; upper trim levels get LED headlamps, too. In the rear, Sweeney said the dual-element taillamps were “inspired by Corvette and Camaro,” but nobody will mistake this family-friendly vehicle for either of those.
The grille has been updated, but appropriately, resisting the current mania for enormous grilles, Chevrolet has kept the toothiness to a minimum on the 2016 Equinox.

More interesting to the crossover shopper are the numerous safety and technology features you can now get on the Equinox.  Rear cross-traffic and side blind zone alert are now options, and a rearview camera is standard on all trim levels. A seven-inch infotainment screen with Chevrolet’s MyLink is standard as well.

The Equinox has only been on the market since 2010, and this is the first update it has received. It faces off against tough competitors including the Honda CR-V,  Ford Escape, and Toyota RAV4. Chevrolet is determined to hold onto the number-four sales slot, planning for an all-new Equinox that's due in late 2017.
