Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive hatchback
Price: $19,625 (including destination charge)
On-sale date: March 2015
Engine: 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 173 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual (standard); six-speed automatic (optional)
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Most interesting option: Driver-selectable steering with Comfort, Normal, and Sport modes
Grand Touring—GT—is a badge that suggests a higher level of driving fun than other members of a vehicle lineup, and that’s the mission of the 2016 Hyundai Elantra GT.

A growing number of young drivers associate fun-to-drive with telematics, and electronic gadgetry is expanded on the freshened Elantra GT. But you'll also find more traditional features such as nimble handling, precise steering, and enough power to ward off boredom. Competitors in this class include the Mazda 3, the Ford Focus ST, and the Volkswagen Golf.

The GT’s 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine makes 173 horsepower, which qualifies as adequate among the compact hatchback hot rods, and the EPA forecasts fuel economy performance of 24 mpg in city driving, 33 on the highway. The ratings are the same whether the GT is equipped with a six-speed manual transmission (standard) or a six-speed automatic.

The suspension has been adjusted for less body roll in corners and a little more authority than the basic Elantra sedan. The GT also offers a Style package with a more aggressive suspension setup and stickier tires.
Hyundai’s swoopy Fluidic Styling has weathered well and didn’t need much updating.

Hyundai’s driver-selectable two-mode steering has Comfort, Normal, and Sport settings. Set it at Comfort for low effort around parking lots or city streets, or on Sport for an increased sense of feel on twisty back roads.

Styling updates are minimal. There's a new grille with horizontal slats, plus redesigned 17-inch aluminum alloy wheels. To be fair, Hyundai’s swoopy Fluidic Styling has weathered well and didn’t need much updating.
Standard features on the GT include heated seats, a cooled glove box, LED taillights, and leather seating.

The most interesting options are ventilated front seats (part of the Tech package), which Hyundai claims as a compact-class first; a new generation of Hyundai’s navigation system integrated with HD radio and Apple’s Siri voice recognition; and the latest version of Hyundai’s Blue Link system with remote start capability and Google-linked Destination Search function.
The 2016 Elantra GT will be on sale in March, with a base price of $19,625.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

Key Points

• The Toyota Camry has been the bestselling car in the U.S. for eleven of the past twelve years
• However, it has been described as “vanilla” by some
• For 2015, the Camry and Camry Hybrid get a thorough overhaul with significant changes, including exterior redesign, improved handling, and a revised interior with more equipment and better materials
• At all three trim levels (value-oriented LE, sporty SE, and premium XLE), the car is equipped with more standard equipment than ever before

title: Nissan 370Z Nismo Roadster Concept
subTitle: Ready for some fresh air? This concept looks very likely to see production by year's end.
promoTeaserSmall: Ready for some fresh air? This concept looks very likely to see production by year's end.
promoTeaser: Ready for some fresh air? This concept looks very likely to see production by year's end.

pageElements.text:
Type: Two-passenger, rear-wheel-drive roadster concept
Engine: 3.7-liter V-6, 350 horsepower
Transmission: Seven-speed automatic with manual shift mode and paddle shifters
Most interesting features: Nissan sport brakes, electronic brake-force distribution, and brake assist; black Recaro seats with off-white Ultrasuede inserts, red trim and stitching, and Nismo logo
Concept cars fall into two categories: dream cars showcasing new technology and radical styling ideas, or show cars that are destined for assembly lines in the near future.

Portrayed as a concept at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show—merely to “gauge market interest,” according to the carmaker—this Nismo-massaged Nissan 370Z Roadster falls into category two. And we’ll be astonished if this fresh-air hot rod isn’t ready for showrooms before the end of the year.

Nismo (for Nissan Motorsports International Limited) has been the company’s in-house go-faster tuning shop since 1984. It has already given the 370Z coupe its warmup treatment. The menu includes retuned (read: stiffer) suspension, a more aggressive tire package (Bridgestone), 19-inch forged alloy wheels, bigger brakes, cosmetic licks, and, of course, more go-power.
The standard Z-car’s 3.7-liter V-6 generates 332 horsepower, while the Nismo version has 350. The concept roadster also includes the coupe’s seven-speed paddle-shifter automatic transmission.
The Nismo roadster is roughly three inches longer overall. Put it down to the more aggressive front air dam.
Other Nismo touches: licks of red along the rocker panels and the side mirror backs, LED running lights, black headlight surrounds, and a carbon fiber rear spoiler that's unique to the droptop Z.
Also specific to the Nismo roadster: fancy black Recaro seats with light cream suede inserts, and leather-wrapped rollover hoops with red trim.

Pricing? Here’s foundation for a guess. At $42,800, the base price for a Nismo coupe is $12,000 above the basic 370 coupe. The 370 roadster opens at $42,630 with the seven-speed automatic. (Interestingly, with a six-speed manual transmission it’s $3,450 higher.) Nissan characterizes this concept as “the ultimate factory Z roadster.” And for those who like their fresh air on faster forward, this Z is a very tempting idea.
It’s also an idea whose time will come. Soon. Bet on it.

pageElements.text:
2016 Hyundai Veloster Rally Edition

Type: Four-passenger, four-door front-wheel-drive hatchback
On-sale date: May 2015
Engine: Turbocharged 1.6-liter four-cylinder, 201 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed manual with B&M Racing sport shifter
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/33 mpg highway
Most interesting feature: Rays 18-inch lightweight wheels

The Veloster is Hyundai’s iconoclastic four-door hatchback—one door on the driver’s side, two on the passenger's side, plus the hatch. It will roll into the 2016 model year with a variety of updates, including a limited-production version, the Rally Edition.

The Rally Edition is propelled by the same 1.6-liter direct injection turbo four as the standard Veloster Turbo—201 horsepower, 195 pound-feet of torque. It adds stiffer suspension tuning; Rays eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels that are five pounds lighter per wheel than the eighteen-inchers on the standard Turbo; a B&M Racing sport shifter; pseudo carbon fiber trim; black sport seats with the word "Turbo" in white on the blue bolsters; plus rally edition badging and floor mats. The only color available is matte blue, as shown here.
Limited edition means just that; there will be 1,200 built.

The regular Veloster Turbo rolls on slightly heavier alloy wheels. There’s a new seven-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission option, and there’s also a Turbo R-Spec special edition, with red seatbelts. Another interior option includes orange seat bolster highlights and interior accents, whose appeal may not resonate with anyone over twenty-one.
Other 2016 Veloster Turbo updates include new front bucket seats with more aggressive bolsters and a new electroluminescent gauge package with sportier graphics.

Enhancements to the standard 2016 Veloster include the family’s new grille and hood design, a new design for the seventeen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, plus the option of the Turbo’s eighteen-inch wheel/tire package.

Like the Veloster Turbo, the standard Veloster will offer a special interior trim package option that includes sport seats with black bolsters and yellow inserts and yellow highlights elsewhere around the interior.

The standard Veloster continues to be propelled by the normally aspirated, 123-horsepower version of Hyundai’s 1.6-liter direct injection four-cylinder engine. You can have a six-speed manual or an optional six-speed dual-clutch automatic transmission with this engine choice.

Infotainment on the 2016 Veloster is upgraded to include navigation, HD radio capability, Apple’s Siri voice command, SiriusXM Travel Link, and the company’s Blue Link telematics, all controlled on a new seven-inch touchscreen.
The 2016 Velosters will begin arriving in Hyundai showrooms in May.

pageElements.text:
2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country T5 Platinum

Type: Five-passenger, all-wheel-drive wagon
Base price: $41,940 (including destination charge)
This car: $45,590 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.5-liter 5-cylinder, 250 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy (estimated): 20 mpg city/28 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: In-car Wi-Fi hot spot
Option I can’t live without: Blind Spot Information System package ($925)
Notable standard features on this model: Adaptive Cruise Control with Queue Assist (part of Technology package, included on Platinum model)
Notable options on this model: Climate package (includes heated windshield, steering wheel, front and rear seats, windshield washer nozzles, $1,5500
You might also be considering: 2015 Audi Allroad ($43,325), BMW 328i xDrive Sports Wagon ($42,900), Subaru Outback ($25,745), Volkswagen Jetta SportWagen ($21,815) (all prices include destination charge)

The Volvo V60 Cross Country is based on the also-new-for-2015 Volvo V60 wagon, but with all-road, all-weather driving, enhanced ground clearance, and a look that says confidently (in a sexy Swedish accent), “We can go anywhere.” The idea of a sporty wagon was a new idea when Volvo introduced the first V70 Cross Country nearly twenty years ago, back when driving a Volvo wagon defined a certain soccer-mom segment of the American population.

Since then, the traditional wagon has become less popular while sport-utility vehicles and crossovers dominate the roads. The V60 wraps all the merits of a Volvo wagon—comfort, safety, and cargo room—into a sport-utility style that looks like a petite wagon but offers more ground clearance than some small SUVs.

I climbed into the V60 XC with my eye on a Tahoe road trip and quickly felt like I was already at my end-of-day comfort stop, as I settled into the comfortable heated seats and wrapped my cold hands around the heated steering wheel. They're part of the optional Climate package ($1,550). The car has a new honeycomb grille and lower skid plate, side scuff plates, and black fender extensions that house eighteen-inch Neso Cross Country alloy wheels. It looks sporty but elegant, definitely more glamp than camp.

The geek in me noted the in-car Wi-Fi hot spot with excitement. I have been waiting for a future with real in-car Internet. Here it is! (The car comes with six months of 3G data service, but you can use your own phone’s data after that if you don’t want two data plans.) Because the car is connected, I was able to send a Glympse right from the car—and would have if either of my teenagers had expressed any interest in tracking my whereabouts while I headed off on my adventure. And the navigation system told me me exactly what food and rest stops were available at upcoming exits. In fact, all the apps ran natively in the car, not requiring me to pair my phone.

The seven-inch center panel screen is not huge, relatively speaking, but the controls to operate it are. I had to sit in it parked for a few minutes to get the lay of the land on all those buttons and dials. But it turns out that learning just a few gestures gets most everything done. So I hit the road.
On a slippery road or a difficult downhill, the car will let you drive until you start to lose control, and then it will step in and correct.

This car is part of Volvo’s push to prevent anyone from dying or being seriously injured in a Volvo by the year 2020, so it does a lot to prevent a crash. And a good deal of that is in the handling. There's roll stability control, dynamic stability and traction control, hill descent control, and a 2.5-liter five-cylinder turbocharged engine with 250 horsepower and 266 pound-feet of torque. In short, on a slippery road or a difficult downhill, the car will let you drive until you start to lose control, and then it will step in and correct. In the city, it won’t let you accidentally rear-end that car in front of you because you got bored and looked at your phone. At speeds under 15 miles per hour, it brakes to stop the car if it sees a crash is imminent. (You are unlikely to notice this until that second though, since it doesn’t kick in till the very last moment.)

My favorite driving technology is the adaptive cruise control. Set your speed, point the car in the right direction, and it will handle the braking and acceleration, always looking for the speed you set but careful to maintain a comfortable distance (you tell it what that is) to the car in front of you. This made my drive home from the mountains a dream. In bumper-to-bumper traffic, I told the car to hope for 70 miles per hour. But we never got above 40 and mostly it was 20 or 25 miles per hour. That would have been a headache for me normally. But this time, all I had to do was steer. I had to pay attention but not completely focus and that made for a much more relaxing drive. It even gave me time to catch up with my abandoned family by phone without worrying too much that I’d lose driving focus.

All that safety and stability control coupled with plenty of power made for an enjoyable drive. And when I say enjoyable, I don’t mean for the Toyota Camry driver who was trying to obey the speed limits by setting his own standard cruise control. When I blew past him in my fun yet classy ride, I could see him question all his life choices up to that moment. In fact, I got a little too speed giddy. And eventually, I used the cruise control to help me keep the car from getting me in trouble with the law. It climbed every hill and took every turn at whatever speed I decided was the most fun. But I don’t think CHP and I would see eye to eye on some of those decisions.

Everything is new about this latest addition to Volvo’s Cross Country line. But some of this car shows a beautiful attention to detail that is worth noting. The self-leveling headlights look up or down when you're driving a hill and turn right or left with the steering wheel. The 7.9-inch ground clearance will get you through that washed-out road or steep driveway without a scraping noise. The adaptive cruise control will take much of the stress out of your commute. The Hill Descent Control controls the car's speed automatically when driving down steep inclines so you can focus on the sharp corners. And the astonishing control and sporty driving experience the torque vectoring technology and corner traction control bring to the ride make it feel like I could not only get away from the mundaneness of everyday life, but could probably also evade pursuers if somehow my life suddenly turned into an action film.

But my son Cole, is 6’3”. (That’s him pictured in the back seat with the driver’s seat adjusted comfortably for my 5’9” frame.) I’m afraid we need a bigger back seat, at least until he takes off for parts unknown.

There are two trim levels: the base T5 AWD Cross Country, which starts at $41,000, and the T5 AWD Cross Country Platinum, starting at $44,650. And you can choose from some add-on packages. The Climate Package includes a heated windshield, heated steering wheel, heated front seats, heated rear seats, heated windshield washer nozzles and Interior Air Quality System (IAQS). The Convenience Package (included with Platinum trim) – includes Keyless Drive, rear park assist camera, HomeLink integrated garage door opener, digital compass, grocery bag holder and power retractable outside mirrors. The Technology Package (included with Platinum trim) – features Volvo’s most advanced driver support systems including Adaptive Cruise Control with Queue Assist, Collision Warning with Full Auto Brake, Pedestrian and Cyclist Detection with Full Auto Brake, Distance Alert, Driver Alert Control, Lane Departure Warning, Road Sign Information and Active High Beam. And the Blind Spot Information System (BLIS) Package – includes Blind Spot Information (BLIS), Cross Traffic Alert, Front Park Assist and Lane Change Merge Aid.

The Verdict:

I thrill at the idea of a challenging mountain hike, can’t wait to jump out of a boat in SCUBA gear into a cold ocean, and have a section of my garage devoted solely to sporting equipment. My kids are proto-adults and I—sometimes with my kids but often without them—am a big fan of hitting the road and finding some sporty nature-enhanced fun whenever my schedule allows. For me, fun usually involves big sky, remote roads, and hiking boots, preferably followed by a spa, fireplace, and a glass or two of nice wine. I’m perfectly willing to risk the elements. But dying on the road in a senseless accident is of no interest to me at all. The 2015 Volvo V60 Cross Country was built to order for my lifestyle.

I certainly enjoyed this car. But is this the car I would buy to enable my own off-road adventures? At first glance, that cushy leather interior is too sweet for me. I would fret about water, dirt, and sand the way I fret about the carpets in my house. (Although the Volvo's treated leather is much easier to clean than fabric.) And the rear storage is a bit small. But ever since I handed the keys back, I’ve been rethinking that and considering some aftermarket rubber mats and the fact that the rear seats do a 40/20/40 flat fold for storage. The right roof rack for my kayaks? Maybe.

If you are looking for an adventurous vehicle that is not as big or bulky as an SUV, and especially if you don't need a lot of back-seat passenger space and aren't on a tight budget, this wagon has a lot to recommend it.

pageElements.text: Snow has not been kind to our efforts of late, but save your sympathy for the Northeast. They are welcome to our polar vortices, thank you very much. Though not as brutal as last year, the winter in Michigan has delivered a couple of mega-dumps of the white stuff and ugly mercury drops that make it difficult to videotape cars outside, make it impossible to shoot a good photo of a clean car (since it’s too cold to wash them), and make it an absolute wardrobe nightmare for moi. No one likes to look on camera like the Michelin Man’s dream date. As Bette Midler once said, I have standards. They’re low, but I have them.

It has been so cold that we've had to move the dogs into their winter kennel, a.ka. the deer camp. Ray's favorite position is always about five inches from the blazing wood stove. Bob just crawls up into the Pendleton-blanketed bunk. There has been so much snow that my husband can barely keep up with his big Kubota tractor. At the end of the day, Tim brings the dogs inside, wearing his full cold-weather camo snow-fighting gear and giant hunting boots, and Ray immediately sprawls out on his lap on the Italian leather recliner.

(A note about the leather recliner. When I brought it home, Tim whined about how all he wanted was a La-Z-Boy. Then he complained to his friends, who commiserated with him: "Why don't women understand that all we want is a La-Z-Boy?" So I bought him a La-Z-Boy for Christmas. Do you think he ever sits in it? No. He sprawls out with his dog every single morning and every single night in my Italian recliner.)

Another problem, in winter, is that not all test cars arrive with winter tires. This can lead to an overuse of the phrase “racing toboggan” in describing handling characteristics. (Here in Michigan, where roads are ravaged by ice, salt, snowplows, and criminal neglect by the state, we don’t even bother to describe ride quality. Any Michigander journalist who does is a lying sack.)

You can imagine my trepidation when the BMW 435i xDrive Coupe arrived in the driveway during the midst of a major snowfall (a foot and half!). Considering the total delivered price of $58,750, I didn’t want to find myself in the aforementioned racing toboggan. My fear was misplaced. The 435i was more like a luge—super-fast, super-controlled, super-hot-damn-fun! I headed out cautiously into the teeth of the storm, and after a couple of stabs on the gas and then brake pedals with nary a wiggle, it was all WooHoo Time!

Here’s what was working for me: xDrive, Dynamic Stability Control, Dynamic Traction Control, Dynamic Brake Control, and Cornering Brake Control (not Dynamic, for some reason). I was sure the BMW was shod with snow tires, but no. It had high-performance (and highly rated) Pirelli Cinturato P7s, one of the few all-season tires I could recommend for snow and ice. They gripped like cleats and gave me stupid confidence to wail along as if I was on dry pavement.

When I was on dry pavement, the bad Michigan roads suddenly dampened my enthusiasm for full-throttle accelerations. The Dynamic Handling package ($1,000) couldn't show off its mighty chops in this weather.

Our 435i test car was gorgeous. I assume it would still be lovely if you removed the $5,000 of optional pretties like the M Sport appearance package ($3,000), the Venetian Beige Dakota leather ($1,450), and the Glacier Silver Metallic paint ($550). The option list carried on into the absurd, jacking the base price from $48,000 to $58,750. You would think that a rearview camera might be included. You would be wrong. It’s an additional $950, and the touchpad nav system is $2,150.
If you have anything but your racing suit and your helmet to stow in the back seat on your way to track day, you will find it unusable for human habitation. But it was nicely trimmed. Just saying.
Me? I had the best driving fun I’ve had so far this winter in that BMW.  Too bad it was too crappy outside to take a nice clean shot of that pricey paint job.

images.caption: Tim and Ray on my Italian recliner.
Would your feet fit here? Are you 10?

title: 10 Car Interiors to Love
subTitle: Just for fun, picture yourself in the driver's seat of one of these beautiful rides.
promoTeaserSmall: Just for fun, picture yourself in the driver's seat of one of these beautiful rides.
promoTeaser: Just for fun, picture yourself in the driver's seat of one of these beautiful rides.
metaDescription: Just for fun, picture yourself in the driver's seat of one of these beautiful rides.

pageElements.text: What do you see around you when you're in the driver's seat of your car? Other than your living room recliner or office desk chair, you probably spend the most seat time behind the wheel of your own vehicle. If it's looking a little...utilitarian in there, enjoy a few minutes of fantasy in some of the best driving spaces created by automakers. We've arranged them in ascending order of price, all the way from totally economical to priceless.

1. 2015 Fiat 500 Lounge

Small really can be beautiful, as many people have learned who've found themselves attracted to the stylish interior of the tiny Fiat. This one is particularly nice: a blend of adorable lozenge-shaped headrests and an upmarket brown-and-tan color scheme. It's the top-end Lounge model with the optional Luxury Leather package ($1,700) in Rosso and Avorio, a.k.a. red and ivory. The package includes heated front seats and rear park assist, and the shift knob and steering wheel are leather covered as well. Total price of this Fiat is a reasonable $21,200 (including destination charge).

2. 2015 Jaguar XF 3.0 Portfolio

A gorgeous interior is par for the course if you're shopping for a Jaguar, of course. The leaping cat on the infotainment screen is the starting point. Then let your eye travel down to the shiny knurled aluminum and glossy burl walnut trim (a $300 option). Artfully mixed colors and materials are a large part of the charm inside this Jaguar sedan. The seats shown here are actively ventilated and heated, in Barley leather with Truffle contrast stitching, accompanied by a canvas suedecloth headliner ($525). Dove (gray) and Warm Charcoal are other possibilities. Add the Cold Weather package and its heated, leather-covered steering wheel, and the Jaguar XF 3.0 Portfolio jumps to $59,150 with this interior (including destination charge).

3. 2015 Mercedes-Benz CLS-Class

The Mercedes CLS-Class coupe gets the high-style treatment with the $4,500 leather and wood package you see here: black ash wood trim and quilted Designo semi-aniline leather. Total price is $78,625 (including destination charge).

4. 2015 Maserati Ghibli

For $79,150 (including destination), you can find yourself behind the wheel of this four-door Italian beauty. The Ghibli S Q4 comes with leather seating in Sabbia (sand) and wood trim in Ebano (black). Carbon fiber trim is $1,750. For lovers of excess, you can add extended leather surfaces for another $1,000 and heated leather and wood steering wheel for $1,000 more than that.

5. 2015 Infiniti QX80 Limited

Nissan's luxury division is known for a particularly understated form of excess, and here's a great example. Does this interior make you suddenly crave some good chocolate? The color is called Truffle Brown, after all. This semi-aniline leather with the subtle stitchery is part of the luscious Limited package, which can only be had if you also add several entertainment and technology packages. That boosts the price of the low-$60,000s SUV all the way to $89,945 (including destination charge). With it you get the quilted seats with contrast stitching and piping, an Ultrasuede headliner and pillars, and leather-covered steering wheel, grab handles, and speaker grilles. All that, plus burl walnut that is real wood trim, and looks like it.

6. BMW M6 Convertible

Its price tag says $119,150, but the price of this powerful (560 horsepower from a twin-turbo V-8) convertible includes $1,080 for wood trim and $8,500 for the buttery extended merino leather upholstery treatment. How about this Sakhir Orange extended leather treatment? Choose the color scheme of your driving clothes wisely.

7. 2015 BMW i8

At $137,450 (including destination charge), nobody will purchase the i8 electric car to save money on gas. Its owners will be fashion leaders, though. Accessed by scissors-style doors, the interior of the plug-in BMW features standard leather and cloth seating in Mega Carum Spice Grey (who comes up with these names?). The two-plus-two seating configuration will hold occupants snugly in place, BMW style, for a top speed of a very un-granola-like 155 mph (electronically limited).

8. Mercedes-Benz G-Class

Is it steampunk or Old Money? A little of both, I'd say, although you'll want a stash of Old Money to pay for this ultra-exclusive, delightfully boxy SUV on which even the engine is handcrafted. Inside, this G63 AMG model has the highest-end choice: the designo Exclusive Leather package (an extra $4,950 on top of the $7,900 base leather interior cost). They're AMG sport front seats with diamond-stitched designo nappa leather on the seats and door panels, giving you a "deeper embrace," as Mercedes-Benz calls it. The seats are heated and active-ventilated, and the trim is burl walnut. A half-mile of thread and 45,000 stitches went into the seating. Total cost: $150,925 (including the leather package and the destination charge).

9. 2015 Mercedes-Benz SL-Class

The SL is a dream car in so many ways, not just because of the roadster's iconic presence, not merely because of how crazy fun it is to drive one, but also because of brilliant innovations such as the Airscarf neck-heating headrest. Looking at this SL65 from Mercedes' high-performance AMG division, the eye hardly knows where to land. For $215,150 (including destination charge), you get this. Start with the IWC Ingenieur dash-top analog clock, and then admire the AMG-exclusive and very extensive dashboard instrument cluster and the quilted seating. The carbon fiber trim is standard. This car's overall look is desirable and timeless, if a bit intense.

10. 1951 Alfa Romeo Alfetta Gran Premio Tipo 159

This was a Formula 1 racing car back when heroism was heroism. The great Juan Manuel Fangio raced in a Tipo 159 with its less than cushy cockpit. It's not like they could go crazy on the upholstery; this racer got a mere 1.5 miles to the gallon. Imagining what it felt like to sit in this car is a whole other level of fantasy.

pageElements.text: I remember hearing that, when the television was first invented, many people scoffed. "We don't have time to sit around staring at that," they said. I remember when the microwave oven first came out and there were those, including myself, who gave them a wide berth, feeling it was just not right or natural to take this shortcut to food preparation.
Well, we got over those objections and integrated the technology into our lives.

And, I suspect, drivers are going to do something similar now that Volvo Cars has announced its "complete production-viable autonomous driving system." In other words, the self-driving car is no joke, not anymore.

To underline how close we're getting, Volvo announced today that it will put 100 regular people into quite normal-appearing Volvo XC90s. They will be driven on public roads around Volvo's world headquarters of Gothenburg, Sweden. By 2017, the project will be in full swing, and the cars will be able to take over "every aspect of driving."
It's part of Volvo's Drive Me project, now in its second year.

Hate the idea? Maybe you haven't been out on the highways and streets of southeastern Michigan this winter, as I have. Driver error, or sometimes just driver inattention, can and does lead to all sorts of trouble. Volvo stated an ambitious goal to make cars accident-free by 2020. These autonomous cars will be ready for production by then, or at least, Volvo Drive Me technical expert Henrik Lind says, that's "a realistic target." Who can deny that roads will be safer if the cars can offer more assistance?

The Technology that Creates the Autonomy

For now, the tech takes up a whole lot of trunk space, but Volvo says that by 2017, it will have "significantly shrunk the required space, allowing a vacation with a family." And by 2020, Lind says, all this tech will be so integrated into the car, it will be all but "invisible" as part of the vehicle.

This is just some of the on-board tech:

• Radar. There are seven in all, starting with one in front looking ahead. Four radar sensors, one on each corner of the car, sweep left and right, transmitting "waves that bounce off against signs, poles, and tunnels." And two long-range radars in the back bumper help out by detecting other vehicles coming up quickly from behind.

• Cameras. There's one under each outside mirror, one in the bumper, and one in the grille. These can adjust to changes in lighting conditions, and they're what keep track of lane markings. There's also a trifocal (three lens) camera behind the upper part of the windshield, which can spot pedestrians and "other unexpected road hazards," Volvo says.
• Lasers. There's a multiple-beam laser scanner. It is located below the air intake, and it can identify objects for 140 degrees in front of the vehicle. It can also distinguish between objects.

• Drivers. The 100 test drivers will be chosen based on customers who use the chosen roadways already. Volvo technical specialist Erik Coelingh says they'll be selected to create a mix of age groups, levels of driving experience, and attitudes toward autonomous driving: "early adopters and people that are [skeptical]." They'll be driving leased vehicles with no pay and no extra charge to participate in the study.

Where They'll Drive

The drivers will be able to act normally, and so will the XC90s, taking hands off only where autonomous drive is approved for the pilot project in the Gothenburg area. The driver will be able to choose "regular" manual driving, adaptive cruise control, or "highly autonomous" driving. The idea is to let drivers turn over decision-making tasks to the car in dull, uneventful driving such as commuting on the highway.
In the case of "really adverse" weather conditions, control goes back to the driver, thanks to the car's ability to monitor and make "decisions," Volvo's Lind says.

So, Let's All Get Over It

You can still read a hardcover book rather than watch a screen; you can still put your baked potato or frozen dinner into the oven rather than the microwave. And you will always be able to drive a car the way God intended, with your own brain and hands and feet making the decisions.

But isn't it great that Volvo is making driving safer and giving a hand to those who want or need it?

pageElements.text: Kenichi Yamamoto was the chairman of Mazda when the Miata was born, having been chief engineer for some years. At the time, he was more famous for being the godfather of the rotary engine, but there is no question that the Miata under his watch was his finest accomplishment.
We became friends immediately, bonding over our hometown baseball teams: mine the Detroit Tigers, his the Hiroshima Carp, which Mazda had a financial stake in.  We traded baseball hats.
I was in Hiroshima the night in 1984 the Carp won the pennant. There was free sake in all the bars, and a lot of salarymen lying in the gutters in their three-piece suits, stone drunk.

I brought home the front page of the next day's Hiroshima newspaper, celebrating the win, and I framed it. It hung for years in my office alongside the front page of the Detroit paper with the iconic photo of Kirk Gibson leaping in the air the night the Tigers won the World Series.

Based on our love of baseball, Mr. Yamamoto invited me to come to Japan in 1988 to see a new car they were working on. This was a big deal to me. I had been an automotive journalist for only eight years, and Automobile Magazine was only two years old. To be invited by the chairman of Mazda to come all by myself to Japan was pretty exciting.

They picked me up at the airport and took me out to the Miyoshi proving ground and test track. And then they brought out the Miata prototype. I was blown away. You have to remember that at that time, virtually all little two-seat roadsters had gone away, mostly because they were cute but crappy.

The Miata looked very much like a Lotus Elan, only it had an incredibly sophisticated suspension, double wishbones front and rear. So I quickly began to think of it as a Lotus Elan that was perfectly screwed together and wouldn't leak pools of oil in your driveway.
I will never forget that day. All by myself in Japan, no other journalists, no other cars, in this super-secret open-air roadster.

I was surrounded by engineers from every single department that worked on that Miata. That was a little nervous making. They asked me just to take it out on the track and then come back in and tell them what I thought about it. I will never forget that day. All by myself in Japan, no other journalists, no other cars, in this super-secret open-air roadster that had the tiniest, most perfect little shift lever. I couldn't believe I was there.

I discovered, as did more than a million Miata owners after me, that Mazda’s precious little roadster was a riot to drive without having to go 100 mph to have a good time. It instantly reset my brain about what made a car fun to drive. It had everything to do with how close my eye was to the front wheel. I could literally lean a little to the left and see the apex as I was going around it. I could almost touch it. The five-speed manual shifter was absolute perfection. It was a short throw and you could whip through the gears so precisely, you felt like a genius. The engine was a 1.6-liter straight four-cylinder. It didn't make a lot of horsepower (116), but because the Miata weighed only about a ton, the relatively low horsepower didn't really matter.

It was not a high-powered racing car. Not a Ferrari, not a Porsche, not a Corvette. It was a perfect vehicle for a perfectly twisty road on a sunny day when you didn't have a care in the world. Nowhere to go, nothing to do but look at the scenery.
The Miata was like nothing I had ever driven in my life, and it was about the most fun I had ever had.

It got less fun when I got off the track and was surrounded by the engineers, who led me to a small trackside building, filed in around me at the table, standing room only, and began to ask me questions about my experience. By the time they were done, I felt they had squeezed everything out of my brain. I begged them to stop and then they all bowed and apologized, and that was that.

When I came back to the States, I wrote the first review story for Automobile Magazine. We thought so highly of the Miata that we created Automobile of the Year for it, in 1990. It then won many, many All-Star awards in years to follow, and I wrote a disproportionate share of those stories. I always found something new to say. After testing Miatas over the past twenty-five-plus years, I want to reiterate what I once wrote (about the 2006 Miata): that gentle motoring has a place in our hectic world. It can even be alluring, depending of course on the transport.
My husband bought me a turbocharged Mazdaspeed Miata in 2004, and I became one of the many, many journalists who own their own Miatas.

Other journalists from each of the major automotive publications were also individually invited to Japan to drive that first Miata prototype in 1988, but a few years ago, when former Road & Track editor Thos. Bryant wrote a book about the Miata, he discovered and told me that I was the very first journalist in the world to drive it. Wow. Well, it's possible that I'm still its number-one fan.

title: 2016 Mazda MX-5 Miata
subTitle: The fourth-generation Miata is sexier and more desirable than ever.

pageElements.text: An all-new Mazda MX-5 Miata. Did you say so what? It’s not an unreasonable question. The original Miata was a clever blend of brilliant concept and common sense—a captivating and affordable update on the dear old British roadsters that added practicality, comfort, and reliability to the sports car tradition.Two successive generations added more improvements and amenities, including a brilliantly engineered folding hardtop.
So how could Mazda improve a car that seemed almost beyond reproach?
The fourth generation is the stuff of oohs and aahs—all new, sexier than any of its predecessors, and beautifully engineered.
Read This! The First Mazda Miata: The Car That Reset My Brain, by Jean Jennings / February 20, 2015

Here’s how. Appearing at the Chicago show, where the original made its world debut twenty-six years ago, the fourth generation is the stuff of oohs and aahs—all new, sexier than any of its predecessors, and beautifully engineered.
Pending a test drive, we’ll assume the dynamics will measure up to the new packaging. In the meantime, here’s the hardware story.

At 154.1 inches, the 2016 MX-5 Miata is 3.2 inches shorter than the third generation, on a wheelbase (91.1 inches) that’s shrunk by just over a half-inch. The new car is almost a half-inch wider (68.1 inches), and the only exterior spec that doesn’t change is height: 49.0 inches.

The sum of all these dimensions, plus static ride height that’s down by about a half-inch, is a tidier, more aggressive look, thanks to a wider stance and reduced overhangs—less Miata extending beyond the (seventeen inch) front and rear wheels.

There’s also less Miata at the scales. Reduced dimensions and extensive use of aluminum add up to a roadster that will weigh in some 150 pounds lighter, according to Mazda—about 2,330 pounds in base trim. Lower weight plus revised suspension, a slightly lower center of gravity, and improved weight distribution—Mazda makes it 50/50 front/rear versus 52/48, thanks to a slight rearward relocation of the engine—should result in a roadster that’s exceptionally quick on its feet.

Whether it will be quick when the light turns green remains to be seen. The new engine is Mazda’s Skyactiv 2.0-liter four-cylinder, making 155 horsepower. Nourished by direct fuel injection, it’s more efficient than the 2.0-liter four it replaces, with a slight edge in torque (148 pound-feet versus 140), and should achieve better EPA fuel economy projections (the 2.0 is rated 22 mpg city/28 highway). Ratings for the new Miata have not been announced.

But at 155 horsepower, it gives away 12 ponies to the current engine. That’s not much, but it works out to a less favorable power-to-weight ratio for the new car—15.5 pounds per hp for 2016, 14.9 for the current Miata.
Like the 2015 Miata, the fourth generation will offer a choice of manual or automatic transmissions, both six-speeds.

Despite its reduced dimensions, the cockpit of the new Miata will provide a little more room, a little more seatback adjustability, a slightly lower seating position, and improved forward sight lines, thanks to a lower hoodline.

Although the new Miata won’t be in showrooms until summer, Mazda is ready with an array of custom accessories, introduced at Chicago. The collection includes an aero kit (front air dam, rocker panel extensions, rear bumper skirt, and rear deck-lid lip spoiler); a Brembo brake package with snazzy red calipers; BBS wheels, seventeen inches like the standard  wheel but with increased offset; and a luggage rack.
With summer still some way off—Chicago in February makes summer seem to be a myth—Mazda wasn’t ready to announce pricing for the new MX-5. The current price model starts at a little under $25,000.
It’s a safe bet that pricing for the new car will start a little higher. It’s also a safe bet that it will still be by far the best sports car buy going.

subTitle: Dullness is the greatest sin. Don't be guilty.

pageElements.text:
1. 2015 Ford Mustang: Competition Orange

It's a color that defies winter—and humorlessness. Introduced in 2004, the car's 40th anniversary, Competition Orange has been back for a couple of years now, and it's available across the Mustang lineup for 2015. This citrusy color costs nothing extra but brings all kinds of added specialness.

2. 2016 Cadillac ATS-V Coupe: Crystal White Frost

Matte paint is not just for boy racers anymore. It looks extremely classy on this high-performance coupe, in a shade that Cadillac calls Crystal White Frost. Starting in late summer, you can get it. It will cost extra, although the automaker isn't saying how much yet. It will also take extra work to keep it looking good, but with looks like this, who cares?

3. Fiat 500L Vans Design Concept: Two-Tone and Checkers

This one was customized as part of a sponsorship of the Vans U.S. Open of Surfing, and we saw it at the 2015 Chicago Auto Show. The checkered roof is a nod to a classic Vans skateboard-shoe pattern. It's almost sad that this color and design scheme can't be bought. (No regrets, though, about the bizarre tilted-cupholder front end.) A little of the two-tone fun can be had in the production 2015 Fiat 1957 Edition, which comes in light blue (Celeste Blu) or light green (Verde Chiaro) with a white roof.

4. 2015 Ford Transit Connect Wagon: Solar

Since Ford advertises this as the "unminivan," it makes sense the automaker chose to feature an Uncola color for it. Does this yellow look to you like a urine specimen or a warm, smiling sun? That would make a good psychological test. Molly Jean of JKC thought the former; I strongly think the latter. Ford calls this color Solar, so (as usual) I'm right.

5. 2015 Chevrolet Spark: Lime Green

If you're going to have a tiny car, be joyous about it. This Lime Green version of the Spark, which starts under $13,000, is by far the most desirable shade. Among other choices are Grape Ice, Salsa, and Lemonade, clearly chosen to appeal to the sweet tooth of the youth market, but my money's on this one.

6. 2015 Range Rover: Montalcino Red Metallic

Candy-apple red is a color usually associated with sports cars. That's what makes it so appealing when it plays against type in the full-size Range Rover. The color name is Montalcino Red Metallic. Dark green is a fine color choice for a Land Rover product, but red is audacious, for those who remain practical when going through that midlife crisis. Where's Montalcino? Tuscany. Oh, let's go there.

7. Dodge Viper

Now this is frankly crazy, as if the Viper isn't already visually entertaining enough. On the show floor at the Chicago Auto Show, the Viper was certainly among the most photographed. It was done up to highlight the brand-new Viper 1 of 1 program, which lets Viper buyers order a truly individualized color and trim scheme. You have 8,000 hand-painted exterior colors, 24,000 hand-painted stripes, and sixteen interior trim choices to work with. And you can name it when you're done. Chances are, nobody is going to choose this. But can you stop looking at it?

title: 2015 Lexus NX200t Remote Touch
subTitle: Is a touchpad the best way to manage in-car infotainment? We checked it out.
promoTeaserSmall: Is a touchpad the best way to manage in-car infotainment? We checked it out.
promoTeaser: Is a touchpad the best way to manage in-car infotainment? We checked it out.
metaDescription: Is a touchpad the best way to manage in-car infotainment? We checked it out.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Love infotainment but hate figuring out how it works? You're not alone. The technology that gives you great music, mapping, and app choices in your car can also be confusing and complex.

Fortunately, auto manufacturers are looking for interfaces that make them easier to use. Some favor a dial, while other brands, such as Hyundai, Ford, and Chrysler, have opted for the more user-friendly touchscreen. Lexus has straddled these trends with its Remote Touch interface.

Lexus Remote Touch is a touchpad nestled in the center console that enables users to interact with the video screen mounted on the dash. I tried out this interface in a 2015 Lexus NX200t. It took only a few minutes, and I found it surprisingly intuitive to use while driving. But it’s hard to separate the usability of Remote Touch from the Lexus Enform connected services system and its voice control capabilities, and it's here where you encounter its shortcomings.
Another bonus: there won’t be fingerprint smudge buildup on your LCD. That means the screen is easier to read, and one less thing to clean. Who doesn’t love that?

On one hand, Remote Touch is a big improvement over the previous “mouse” interface. It’s sensitive and responsive, and limited to selecting active buttons, which makes it faster to use. On the other hand, there are times when you find yourself wishing for the touchscreen that you’ve come to know and love on your mobile phone, specifically when you’re manually entering an address. Enform’s navigation system is great at locating businesses, and for the more obscure points of interest, Bing and Yelp is available through the Lexus App Suite to help you find your destination and send it to your navigation system. When all else fails, you have the optional Destination Assist, which is the Lexus version of OnStar.

But you’re on your own when you need to enter a home address. Like most infotainment systems, Enform doesn’t integrate your mobile phone’s address book with the navigation system, which means you need to re-enter whatever can’t be found using Bing, Yelp or Points of Interest. With Remote Touch, you have to “double type” by first navigating to each letter on the video screen keyboard, and then tap on it. That gets old. There isn’t a way to alternate between the keypad and voice control, so you’re better off using voice command from the beginning, which has its own challenges. But mangling spoken addresses and other voice commands isn’t limited to Enform (Siri, I’m talking about you), and in the week of driving the 2015 NX 200t equipped with these features, it responded correctly about 80 percent of the time.
Tip: there’s a vibrating haptic Response Feedback setting buried in the preferences menu that panders to the BlackBerry crowd. This is a setting I preferred turned as low as possible.

There's no question that Remote Touch was an improvement; it's far more intuitive than a dial. Is it easier to use than a touchscreen? Sometimes. In the NX 200t, the head unit video screen is mounted high on the center console, which could put it out of easy reach for most drivers. The touchpad is within closer range and more ergonomic. Another bonus: there won’t be fingerprint smudge buildup on your LCD. That means the screen is easier to read, and one less thing to clean. Who doesn’t love that?

pageElements.text:
2015 Chevrolet Trax LTZ AWD

Base price: $20,995 (LS, including destination charge)
This car: $27,405 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 1.4-liter four-cylinder, 138 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 24 mpg city/31 mpg highway (all-wheel-drive model); 26/34 mpg (front-wheel-drive model)

My favorite standard feature: Rearview camera
Options I can’t live without: Cruise control (standard on LT and LTZ, not available on LS), heated seats (on LTZ only)
Notable standard features on this model: Remote start, rear park assist, OnStar with 4G LTE wireless hot spot, heated front seats
You might also be considering: Honda CR-V ($24,325); Jeep Renegade ($18,990); Mazda CX-5 ($22,425) (all prices include destination charge)

When you head out to the dealership to test drive new cars, it’s critical to drive only the level of car you can afford. Take the 2015 Chevrolet Trax, for instance. My tendency would be to go straight for the awesome Orange Rock Metallic Trax LTZ on the lot without noticing that it was the highest of the three trim levels and, at $26,530, almost five grand more than the base Trax LS ($20,995).

I would then find out that all the coolest features included in the LTZ model—Bose audio, power seats, remote start (a must-have), rear park assist, that flamboyantly awesome orange paint, and cruise control—are not even available as options on the base car. And then I would have to steel myself and pay the extra dollars. Because I at least need cruise control.
I found this out during my three-day test drive.

If you’re fond of slamming on the accelerator when you want to giddy-up (as I clearly am), be ready for the tortured roar of the 1.4-liter turbocharged four-cylinder engine followed by a slow trot as acceleration climbs, until the turbo kicks in and things smooth out. With only 138 horsepower on tap, the Ecotec four-cylinder engine would prefer you feed in your request for power with a lighter foot, thank you. It will climb well past the speed limit, but each time you sneeze—unless you set the cruise control—you’ll find yourself going ten miles an hour slower.

Did I mention you can’t get cruise control on the Trax LS? Right. In fact, its minuscule options list offers not much beyond a handful of cargo area upgrades. I would get the heavy-duty cargo tray ($110). A notable exception is all-wheel drive, a $1,500 option on any of the three models and well worth every dollar.
Chevy clearly wants you to step up to the LS or LTZ. Do that, and the glittering array of standard luxuries and desirable options will be revealed.

Buzzing down the Interstate, the Trax feels much less prone to a crosswind than you might imagine of a vehicle that is basically square; it undoubtedly prefers being your city car. That useful square also delivers less fuel economy (24 mpg city/31 mpg highway for the all-wheel-drive model; the standard front-wheel-drive model gets 26/34 mpg) than you might expect these days. But it offsets that disappointment with a sterling 2015 five-star overall safety rating from the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (a.k.a. the Government). The Trax also received a coveted 2015 Top Safety Pick rating from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

I actually like its funky shape and exceptionally well-screwed-together interior. Even in cloth trim, the Trax’s fit and finish are impeccable. Bezels surrounding air vents, cubbies, and the six-speed automatic shift lever (manual function button is on the shift knob) are plastic with galvano chrome, chrome, or liquid platinum finish. They look for all the world like metal, and are perfectly fitted in place. The instrument cluster is a clean, easy-to-read, yet cheerful array of bold colors, and the MyLink touchscreen works well if you take those gloves off, sir. The front passenger’s seat on all Trax models folds flat, allowing the already useful cargo area to swallow up longer items.

There is one major league feature that even the smallest and most Spartan of Chevrolets delivers on a silver platter: an AT&T 4G LTE wireless hot spot that will handle seven Bluetooth devices when the car is on.
I actually like that even better than cruise control.

pageElements.text: The Honda CR-V is a five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sport-utility vehicle, but it’s more appropriate to call it a crossover vehicle. It’s today’s version of the family station wagon, facing off against numerous others in a very competitive category that includes the Toyota RAV4, Ford Escape, Mazda CX-5, Chevrolet Trax, Buick Encore, and Hyundai Santa Fe Sport. Last year, the CR-V was the sales winner. If you’re interested in this category, you are probably looking for safety features, ground clearance, visibility, and the possibility of all-wheel drive. These are not exciting vehicles; they’re eminently practical, though. The CR-V is powered by a 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine making 185 horsepower, teamed with a continuously variable automatic transmission. It’s priced starting in the low $20,000s, although the top model, with navigation and all-wheel drive, costs above $30,000.

pageElements.text: Did you miss me?
Because I’ve certainly missed you!

Now that the dust has cleared on the relocation of Jean Knows Cars (from the owners of Automobile Magazine to my newly established LLC, and from Ann Arbor to Chelsea, Michigan), I would like to welcome you to life in bucolic Chelsea. It is the home town of the wonderfully versatile Jeff Daniels (Arachnophobia, Fly Away Home, Dumb and Dumber 1 and 2, The Network) and his Purple Rose Theatre, and home of the Chrysler Proving Grounds where I worked for three amusing years. Classic shot-and-shell joint Seitz’s Tavern is just around the corner. The gleaming white grain silos of Jiffy Mix are hard by the railroad tracks, towering over the cozy Jean Knows Cars office.
Please don’t drop in.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/lSyBOIQdJzM" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

We have returned (not tanned, hardly rested, but certainly ready), we being Jean, executive editor Laura Sky Brown, and creative director Molly Jean. Having plotted our comeback all summer, we launched ourselves into the breach—covering the Los Angeles Auto Show in November, filming video reviews until Jean’s Driveway was buried in snow, and marching right on through the Detroit Auto Show in January—working from kitchen tables. We secured the office, desks, and computers just in time to hit the Chicago Auto Show, where we also took a day to bond with our new partner, Tribune Publishing, which will be syndicating our work across its vast network of print and digital properties.

Basically, we’re working our asses off in between multiple trips to Ikea and sweet-talking AT&T for a free microcell to turn 318 North Main Street from a cell-free zone to a full five bars on the iPhones. That, and having a great time plotting Internet domination. Be part of our march to the sea! Find us, follow us, Like us, LOVE us here on JeanKnowsCars.com and at Facebook.com/JeanKnowsCars, Twitter.com/JeanKnowsCars, and Instagram.com/JeanKnowsCars.

pageElements.text:
2015 Hyundai Sonata Sport 2.0T

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive sedan
Base price: $23,985 (base Sonata Sport, including destination charge)
This car: $29,510 (including destination charge)
Engine: Turbocharged 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 245 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic with paddle shifters
Fuel economy: 25 mpg city/32 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Hands-free smart trunk
Options I can’t live without: Heated front seats (standard on Sport 2.0T)
Notable standard features on this model: Rearview camera, lane change assist, blind spot detection, rear cross-traffic alert
Notable options on this model: None
You might also be considering: Ford Fusion ($22,835), Honda Accord ($22,925), Toyota Camry ($24,460) (prices include destination charge)
If you’re still someone who hears the word “Hyundai” and thinks “cheap car,” you will be blown away by the 2015 Sonata, one of Hyundai’s most important vehicles.

Yes, it’s a reliable ride at a reasonable price. But if you’re looking for a gorgeous and lavishly appointed family sedan, state-of-the-art safety technology (forward collision, lane departure, blind spot, and cross-traffic warnings), a choice of two great four-cylinder engines, a flawless six-speed automatic transmission, and a reasonable price, the 2015 Sonata ought to be front and center on your shopping list.

Hyundai Motor America colonized the United States in 1985, sending its first car—the 1986 Excel—forth to prosper. It helped that it had a rock-bottom price, because it was a tad, shall we say, crappy.

The Sonata came in late 1988, designed by Ital Design in Turin, Italy, and built on a Mitsubishi Galant platform, a clever strategy by the fledgling Korean carmaker to play catch-up with the Japanese invasion. Do not be fooled. Hyundai’s price strategy kept the company in business while design and engineering raced furiously forward.

Twenty–seven years later, now in its seventh generation, the Sonata has been one of the brightest lights in a growing brand, first setting a record with more than 200,000 Sonatas sold in North America in 2010, and winning awards from major enthusiast magazines, consumer websites, and safety agencies along the way.

The Sonata played a role in helping Hyundai supplant all of its competition on the 2014 J.D. Power Initial Quality Study, ranking an impressive fourth behind Porsche (#1), Jaguar (#2), and Lexus (#3). Perhaps most satisfying: Hyundai ranks ahead of Toyota (#5), Honda (#8), and Ford (#16).

I took a 2015 Hyundai Sonata for a test drive, which just happened to be a round-trip from Michigan to Louisiana and back. My first concern was, would there be enough room for the luggage, the presents, the hunting gear, the fishing gear, and the variety of outerwear to cover every possible weather condition? What about the cooler full of pheasants to be swapped out with all the fish I was planning to catch? And a second cooler big enough to hold the wild boar my husband planned on bagging?

No problem whatsoever, other than that there would be no wild boar. There was, however, a cooler packed with ice and speckled trout. Ahem. Not only does the Sonata have best-in-class interior volume, it has a deep, wide trunk with a tall, wide opening. You’d be surprised by how many cars I’ve tested with a trunk opening too narrow to take a biggish piece of luggage.

I knew the Sonata would be fun—even in the more mountainous sections of our 2,100-mile round-trip drive—because we had the Sport 2.0T model. It’s the most fun-minded of the Sonata’s five trim levels, thanks to an impressive 2.0-liter four-cylinder turbo engine and a six-speed automatic transmission so competent that we never noticed it.
The standard features list includes my three safety must-haves: blind spot detection, cross-traffic alert, and a rearview camera. All three have saved my bacon out there.

Rather than digging us all into a hole trying to explain the multiple sub-levels of equipment packages available among the five trims (SE, Sport, Limited, Sport 2.0T, and Eco), I just won’t go there. Instead I’ll use my brilliant orange (“Urban Sunset”) 2.0T as an example. The base price is $29,385. There is exactly one item on the options list: a carpeted floor mat for $125. The impressive list of standard features includes my big three safety must-haves: blind spot detection, cross-traffic alert, and a rearview camera. All three have saved my bacon out there.

More standard delights are the hands-free trunk opener that reads the key fob in your pocket, heated front seats, and lots of leather. You can spring for the $4,950 Ultimate package if you need a panoramic sunroof and heated seats for your back-seat guests. The package also contains about fifteen other technology wonders.

Back to where we began. The Sonata has been one of the pillars of Hyundai’s U.S. success, and the 2015 model has reached new heights of engineering excellence. It’s also just flat out beautiful, one of the most important determining factors in the hotly contested family sedan class.  As one of the great unsung brands, Hyundai deserves its due.

pageElements.text: There isn’t a chance that I’ll ever forget the Studebaker Avanti, one of the first test cars that my automotive journalist father, Bob Lienert, brought home from his city job at Automotive News to our little country house stuffed with kids. Up to the point of writing this sentence, I thought that that lemon yellow Avanti was the first one ever made. Actually, I thought every test car my dad brought home was not only the first one ever made, but also the only one of its kind ever made. That may also have been true of the copper-colored Chrysler turbine car and a big red Mercury with little hand grips and thumb holes instead of a steering wheel, that he also brought home.
But those are stories for another day.

This lemon yellow Avanti may have been one of those first ten off the line in 1962, or a later version built in 1963, but even my Cray supercomputer-brained brother, Paul, doesn’t remember. He does remember that it was equipped with a Paxton supercharger, which made it insanely fast.
This is what we remember.

Our dad was the only driver in the family until our mom threatened to leave him if he didn’t teach her how to drive. Every night after dinner, he would drive over to Kret’s Garage and hang with the guys, or to Grandma’s to play cards and drink a little blackberry brandy. On special occasions, he’d drop all of us at the library.

On Saturdays he would go to the bank and then mail the bills at the post office.
On Sundays, he would drive us all to church, and sometimes for a ride in the countryside.
Rinse. Repeat.
Except the night he brought home the Avanti.

It looked like a spaceship that had landed from Mars. He must have been as excited as we were about it, because he asked us kids if we wanted a ride. There were two babies in the house, so that meant my older brother Paul, my younger brother Teddy, and me. I was seven.
We piled in. It felt really low to the ground compared to the family station wagon. I don’t remember if it had those orange seats, but that would have added major excitement to the experience.
Someone called shotgun, and I’m sure it was Paul. Teddy and I would have been in the back.
My dad turned left and shot down a smoother, wider dirt road and really let himself have at it, much to our thrill.

We lived on a rutty dirt road that ended at a stop sign facing the Catholic cemetery. Dad left the driveway and headed north, gathering a head of steam as he barreled up the hill to the stop. He turned left and shot down a smoother, wider dirt road and really let himself have at it, much to our thrill.

I think he may have been surprised by a tee junction coming up suddenly over a blind crest. He threw the wheel to the left, and the Avanti’s rear end slewed across the slippery graveled road surface. He spun the wheel hard right, but the entire car car slid off the road and into the ditch. He never lifted and somehow managed to drive it right out of the ditch and onto the road. And he kept going, even though Teddy and I were screaming in the back seat, “Daddy! Daddy! Stop! You’re going to kill us!”
But he went only far enough to make a slow U-turn and drive straight home.
“Don’t tell your mother,” he said. I don’t remember any other test rides after that.
Photo: 1963 Studebaker Avanti, courtesy of CZmarlin/Christopher Ziemnowicz

When Automobile launched in 1986, my byline appeared on a sidebar to the cover story written by our founding editor David E. Davis, Jr. Yet it wasn’t inevitable that I’d write for the magazine, even though my childhood was heavily automobile-flavored: my father raced jalopies and late-model stock cars on the oval tracks around Omaha, Nebraska, where we lived, and my favorite uncle liked drag racing and hot rods.

After earning a B.A. in English from the University of Nebraska, I moved to Los Angeles to become a screenwriter. Instead, though, I ended up holding cue cards on TV shows, including the soap opera Days of Our Lives. My first magazine story, the inside scoop on how we prepared those cue cards, appeared with my own photos in Soap Opera Digest.

In my freelance career, I’ve written for Bon Appétit, the Wall Street Journal, and many others. I started corresponding for the Automobiles desk at the New York Times in 2010, which is proving to be a great relationship. As a change of pace, my historical column for DBusiness (“Detroit’s Premier Business Journal”) has run since 2006. But while a food-and-wine tour can get boring after a couple of days, nothing beats a call from Automobile. I’ve been behind the wheel of everything from a Ferrari 458 Italia (“Blood Red to Goodwood,” March 2011) to the Fiat 500 Abarth. On assignment for “Three Zero Heroes,” I co-drove the winning BMW X3 in the 2004 Alcan Winter Rally. Teaming again with the same navigator, we won the 2006 Carolina Trophy, bulldogging a 1951 Chrysler Saratoga to the finish for “Substance over Style.”

Other assignments have placed me not only in the driver’s seat of a Porsche 911 Targa for the 2002 Targa Newfoundland, a plummy nod that seemed to indicate my editors’ favor, but also in the co-driver’s seat of a Class 1 buggy for the 2003 Baja 1000, suggesting they wanted me dead.

As you might guess, there’s no regret about failing as a screenwriter. And now I’m beginning something new: teaching automotive journalism at Art Center College of Design, in Pasadena. My workshop, Creating Content for Automotive Media, launched in 2012 and will be offered twice a year. I look forward to helping students along on their way to incomparable automotive adventures and working with the best editors in the business.

pageElements.text: “Love these.”
“One of the coolest cars ever, and way ahead of its time.”
“The most beautiful car ever.”
The Studebaker Avanti drew such comments on Facebook when I posted this photo from the Palm Springs Modernism Week car show.

You’d think Studebaker Corporation, which introduced the Avanti in 1963, would have won big with its sporty coupe. The independent automaker’s first all‐new body style in ten years solved an image problem.
I was eight years old when the Avanti came out and I found Studebakers no more appealing than my grandmother’s orthopedic shoes.

But Studebaker’s answer to the Chevrolet Corvette Sting Ray was definitely ahead of its time. Given the overwrought automotive shapes we were accustomed to in those days, it was actually a bit hard for some of us to understand.

The Avanti made a daringly distinct Modernist design statement. Strong lines bounded the surface volumes, yet within the overall simplicity there was voluptuousness. The extended front fenders created a kind of cove, and without a radiator grille, the headlamps’ roundness was exaggerated. (Fresh air was taken in below.)
Above all, ornamentation was limited.

Also read: My Father's Avanti Test Drive, by Jean Jennings

February 26, 2015

Inside, the spareness echoes that found inside custom homes in Palm Springs. In fact, for the design, Studebaker had turned to Raymond Loewy, from whose drawing board had sprung Coke bottles, locomotives, the Coldspot refrigerator, and the Lucky Strike cigarette package. Loewy’s Palm Springs house—the work of architect Albert Frey, a disciple of Le Corbusier—featured a swimming pool that flowed into the living room.

With a fiberglass body, the Avanti was relatively cheap to produce. A supercharged V-8 engine and Flightomatic automatic transmission were available to ensure lively performance. The supercharged 1963 example seen here belongs to our friend Bob Merlis.
The base price in 1963 was $4,445, and some 3,834 copies were produced. Sales dwindled to just 809 units the next year.

And then Studebaker, which had a long history in South Bend, Indiana, closed its factory there. Studebaker's Avanti line was discontinued after the company’s production was concentrated in Hamilton, Ontario. By 1966, Studebaker was finished.
An independent effort was responsible for production of a few Avanti II models into the mid-1970s, and the brand continued in various incarnations, under various owners, into the late 1980s.
Much rarer than it should have been, the Avanti still surprises and pleases after more than fifty years.
Photos by Ronald Ahrens

pageElements.text: If you have kids, you already know that you have to adapt your choice of vehicle to the needs of your family at different stages. Just as important as finding a car in which your children’s safety seats fit, you should consider their needs for personal space. If they’re comfortable and feel a sense of ownership of their place in the vehicle, your commutes and road trips will be a lot more fun.

When you shop for a car, it can't be stressed too strongly: Ensure that each of your children has  some personal real estate in the back seat. Here are four things to consider that will make the ride better for them back there.

1. Territory.

Have you ever heard of “proxemics”? It’s the science of personal space. You may not know the word, but if you have kids—or ever were a kid—riding in the back seat with siblings, you’re very familiar with the concept of territory. Apparently people in the Western world like a “personal distance” zone of eighteen inches to four feet around them at all times. Any closer is defined as “intimate distance” and makes people uncomfortable.
Short version: Don't make kids sit squashed together, and let each child have a place that is his or her own space. That's what you would want, and they deserve it just as much.
If you have two kids in the back seat, let them each have a side that is “theirs.” If you have more than that? The people who sell three-row SUVs and crossovers are your friends.

2. Security.

You're told this all the time, but it bears repeating: strap your children in properly and use the right size of car seat. Go to a child seat installation clinic to make sure seats are installed snugly and properly. This is not only for safety but for comfort, security, and right-sizing of your child's body to the seat. This photo of three kids strapped in? Only the one on the left is the right size for her seat. The others should be in booster seats where their heads are on the headrest properly.
Beyond that, strap their things in properly. Put heavy items in the trunk or behind the seats, not rolling around loose, in case you have to slam on the brakes.
Some of the time, your kids should know how to be bored in the car; it builds character. It also leads to the ability to imagine, think clearly, and just decompress.

3. Storage.

Get seatback holders for books, papers, and toys if your vehicle doesn't come with them. Clutter, and a feeling of being temporarily plopped into a messy space, are not conducive to a peaceful drive. For you as the parent, the ability to just get into the car without first gathering up a supply of toys and accessories is very freeing as well. If your child has a comfort object such as a stuffed animal or a blanket, consider having one that's just for the car. (My youngest had a "vacation blankie" that was meant specifically for car trips. Works great, and you don't have to remember to pack the regular one.)

4. Electronics in Moderation.

It is very tempting to hand each child a tablet or iPhone or to drop in a DVD in the rear-seat entertainment system. That's one of the advantages of modern life in cars. It's also a trap. Some of the time, your kids should know how to be bored in the car; it builds character. It also leads to the ability to imagine, think clearly, and just decompress from an overpacked life of ballet lessons, school, sports, and play dates.

If you have crayons or markers, paper, books, and other creative supplies in the car, your kids can occupy themselves with these. Sure, screens have their place, but so does quiet time. Make your kids' rides in the car into an oasis and a respite, not a continuation of the constant plugged-in state they're already in.
Center photo: Thinkstock
