title: 2015 Volkswagen Golf SportWagen
subTitle: Goodbye, Jetta wagon, and hello to a snappy-looking new Golf. Is a wagon for you?
promoTeaserSmall: Goodbye, Jetta wagon, and hello to a snappy-looking new Golf. Is a wagon for you?
promoTeaser: Goodbye, Jetta wagon, and hello to a snappy-looking new Golf. Is a wagon for you?
metaDescription: Goodbye, Jetta wagon, and hello to a snappy-looking new Golf. Is a wagon for you?

pageElements.text:
2015 Volkswagen Golf SportWagen TDI

Type: Five-passenger, front-wheel-drive compact wagon
Base price: $33,955
Engine: Turbo-diesel 2.0-liter four-cylinder, 150 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 31 mpg city/43 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: XDS Cross Differential System
Options I can’t live without: DSG dual-clutch automated manual transmission
Notable standard features on this model: Eighteen-inch aluminum alloy wheels, touchscreen navigation system, panoramic power sunroof, Fender premium audio, heated power side mirrors, chilled glove box, rearview camera
Notable options on this model: Lighting package (ambient interior lighting, LED daytime running lights, bi-xenon adaptive headlights that swivel in the direction of a turn)
You might also be considering: 2015 Subaru XV Crosstrek 2.0i Premium ($24,145), 2015 Subaru Outback 2.5i ($25,745), 2015 Toyota Prius v Two ($27,500) (prices include destination charges)

You might wonder why a model line composed entirely of hatchbacks would be adding yet another entry with a liftgate at the rear. After all, any 2015 Golf can swallow as much as 52.7 cubic feet of cargo, far more than any compact sedan. So what’s the story?

The short version: size matters. The slightly longer version: VW’s compact wagon has worn Jetta badges in three previous incarnations dating to 2001, when Jetta and Golf had a lot of structural commonality. But this time around, the wagon shares the same architecture that‘s the foundation for the rest of the Golf lineup, whereas the Jetta won’t make that transition until its next renewal, at least two years down the pike.

So what’s the SportWagen advantage? Well, for those discerning few who still prefer a station wagon to an SUV (we salute you!), the new SportWagen (if you want to sound authentic, say “ShportVagen”) is a very snappy-looking ride—a little longer, lower, wider, and lighter, with less wagon protruding beyond the front and rear axles.
Wagons, though a distinct minority in the general U.S. sales mix, are still loved by a loyal few.

For another, like other wagons it manages to sidestep America’s mystifying prejudice against hatchbacks. In the U.S., the Jetta sedan outsells the Golf by more than five to one, whereas in Europe it’s just the reverse. Wagons, although a distinct minority in the general U.S. sales mix, are still loved by a loyal few.

But most important, the SportWagen’s cargo hold is 30.4 cubic feet behind the rear seats, 66.5 with the seats folded flat, a gain of 13.7 cubic feet in maximum capacity. VW points out that this is comparable to a good many compact crossover SUVs.

The interior has an upscale appearance, with pebble grain vinyl that’s pleasant to the touch, if not exactly soft. The overall décor, gray and black, is a little somber but has the look of quality. Like all the Golfs, instrumentation is straightforward and simple white on black. A 5.8-inch touchscreen, standard on all trims, dominates the center dash, serving as home for the optional navigation and audio systems.
Leatherette is the upholstery of choice in all models, with leather-wrapped steering wheel and shift knob in the higher trim levels. Leather is not an option, a measure aimed at keeping costs down.

VW has tweaked the location of the foot pedals and shifter, to optimize the driver’s relationship with the controls, and the center stack angles slightly to the left, a little easier for the pilot to see and reach.

There’s an optional immense new sunroof, stretching from the windshield header almost all the way to the rear hatch. VW calls it Panoramic, and it’s big enough to see all phases of the moon simultaneously.
The rear hatch has been widened (to 40.6 inches), with a liftover height of just over two feet. Unfortunately, a power liftgate is not on the option list, another cost-cutting decision.

Powertrain choices are all from the current Golf inventory. The base engine is VW’s 170-horsepower 1.8-liter turbocharged four, and the option is a redesigned edition of the company’s excellent 2.0-liter turbo-diesel four. Transmission choices include a five-speed manual, a six-speed manual, a conventional six-speed automatic (with the 1.8), and a six-speed dual-clutch automatic.

The 1.8-liter gasoline engine is a big improvement on the previous 2.5-liter five-cylinder, with EPA fuel economy ratings of 25 mpg city/36 highway with the manual transmission, 35 mpg with the automatic. But TDI is the star, with ratings of 31/43 (42 with the automatic).

It starts building torque—236 pound-feet, which is a tidal wave for a 2.0-liter engine—not far above idle, peaking at 1750 rpm; it’s quiet; and it’s eminently civilized. The TDI is at its thrifty best with the manual transmission, but the DSG automatic is a little more fun to operate, delivering lightning up- or downshifts via steering column paddles.

Fun is a word that applies to the rest of the SportWagen driving experience. Like the other members of the Golf family, the wagon has a firm suspension setup, mitigated by shock absorber tuning that irons the sharp edges off pavement warts. Cornering attitudes are level—very little rock and roll here. Directional changes are eager, and the steering is quick and accurate, with more tactile information than most contemporary systems.

As for pricing, the new SportWagen rolls into showrooms in April. The base S model starts at $22,215 and  pricing ranges through two more trim levels (SE, SEL) and variations between 1.8-liter gasoline and 2.0-liter turbo-diesel engines, culminating with the TDI SEL with DSG automatic at $32,265, exclusive of option packages. Automatic transmissions add $1,100 in most models. Our test subject was equipped with two option groups, totaling $1,690, for a bottom line of $33,955.
VW will add its 4Motion all-wheel-drive system to the SportWagen’s option list next year.

As a footnote, for those who like the compact wagon concept, but want all four wheels contributing to traction, patience: VW will add its 4Motion all-wheel-drive system to the SportWagen’s option list next year.

The Verdict:

The 2015 Golf SportWagen is stylish and roomy, with a high level of fit and finish, augmented by the kind of agility and stability typical of cars developed for the demands of the German autobahn. Its turbodiesel option delivers exceptional fuel efficiency, which is why VW lists the Toyota Prius v among key competition. But the reality is that in its price segment, the new SportWagen doesn’t really have any direct competition, certainly not with this kind of fun-to-drive index.

title: 8 Flavors of Pi
subTitle: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).
promoTeaserSmall: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).
promoTeaser: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).
metaDescription: We carry our favorite flavors of car to eight decimal points, all in honor of Pi Day (3.14).

pageElements.text: Geeks everywhere appreciate Pi Day (March 14, or 3.14) so much more than, say, New Year's Eve. The celebratory food of choice is, of course, pie. With that in mind, we made our list of favorites and found their equivalents in the automotive world. Flavorful, we think you'll agree, starting with the upper-crust Ferrari California you're admiring in the photo above.

1. Apple: Aston Martin Vanquish

The grand tourer looks great in Selene Bronze, one of the Contemporary collection of shades from the British carmaker. If you want to continue the apple theme, go with the full Spicy Red interior. The Vanquish and its 565-horsepower 6.0-liter V-12 will help keep the doctor away. The Vanquish starts at $287,820.

2. Banana Cream: 2015 Lamborghini Huracán

In shiny Giallo Midas Pearl Effect, as shown here, or in the matte Giallo Horus, you have two choices to color this car yellow, as it ought to be. The Huracán starts at $241,945.

3. Blueberry: 2015 Chevrolet Corvette Z06

The world is full of blue cars, but blueberry is blue with a bite. The Corvette qualifies in Night Race Blue Metallic, a standard color for the Z06. Pricing starts at $79,995. For a more blueberries-and-cream look, you'd go with the lighter Laguna Blue Tintcoat, a $995 option.

4. Key Lime: 2015 Dodge Challenger R/T

The best thing about muscle cars is how meta they are: their sense of humor, referring back to the Sixties with no historical portentousness, is so very American. You can find lots of cute little low-cost cars in green, but this? This is the best use of lime green out there. The Challenger R/T in Sublime Green Pearl Coat starts at $32,490, or get serious with the Hellcat version, starting at $60,990.

5. Pecan: 2014 Porsche Cayman

Cognac Metallic is the shade shown here, but comparing it with the deep, brooding color of pecan pie is not a stretch. Brown is a popular color for the German performance-car brand, with the deeper Anthracite Brown Metallic and Mahogany Metallic also on the menu. The Cayman starts at $53,595.

6. Pumpkin: 2015 Nissan 370Z Coupe....

The 2015 Nissan 370Z Coupe's seats: go ahead and spill that pumpkin spice latte. Or, actually, don't drink latte and drive this exhilarating car. It starts at $30,800.

....and 2015 Hyundai Veloster Turbo

Prefer your pumpkin on the outside? This 2015 Hyundai Veloster Turbo (below) is right with the current trend, seen everywhere at the Geneva Auto Show earlier this month, for electric-orange paint jobs. This one's called Vitamin C. (Pumpkin is better known for prodigious amounts of Vitamin A, of course.) The Veloster Turbo starts at $22,600.

7. Raspberry: 2015 Alfa Romeo 4C Coupe

Bright red is the Italian racing color, never more fitting than on this sinuous Alfa Romeo, which starts at $54,195. There's a choice of two shades of red: Rosso Alfa, as shown here, and Rosso Competizione, just a little riper-looking.

8. Rhubarb: 2015 Subaru WRX

The WRX and its more sporting sibling, the WRX STI, both come in this bright but not flashy shade of Lightning Red. Like rhubarb, it's comfortable in cold temperatures, and like rhubarb, it is very much appreciated among the cognoscenti and mistakenly overlooked by others. The WRX starts at $27,090 and the WRX STI at $34,290.

contributors.bio:
Jean Knows Cars is not just the name of this website; it's a true fact. I have been writing about cars and the car business for more than 30 years, having learned about cars at the kitchen table from my late father, Robert Lienert, who was the editor of Automotive News. At age eighteen, I bought a used car, painted it yellow, installed a toplight and a meter, and joined the Yellow Cab Company in Ann Arbor, Michigan, as an owner/operator. Five years later, I got a job at Chrysler’s test track as a test driver, welder, and mechanic in the impact lab. In 1980, I was hired as a writer at Car and Driver magazine after getting laid off at Chrysler, and in 1985 I left to establish Automobile Magazine with David E. Davis, Jr. I was the magazine’s first Executive Editor, became Editor in Chief in 2000, and added the title of President of Automobile Magazine in 2006.

I’ve been profiled in The New Yorker and have been a guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno. I was a guest on the Oprah Winfrey Show, teaching Oprah and her studio audience how to change a tire and to jump a battery. I was Good Morning America’s automotive correspondent from 1994 to 2000 and then did the same thing for the Oxygen network.

 I have won awards for feature writing, car reviews, and my monthly Automobile Magazine column, “Vile Gossip,” including the 2007 Ken Purdy Award for Excellence in Automotive Journalism.  I’m a regular on-air contributor to Fox Business Network; CNBC’s Closing Bell, Squawk Box, Behind the Wheel, and Power Lunch; MSNBC; CBS This Morning and Evening News; and CNN’s American Morning and Headline News. In fact, I would almost call myself a TV slut, but I’m proud to say that I turned Geraldo down.

All of this has taken place in a male-dominated automotive space, where I’m all too frequently the only woman in the room. I know the secret handshake, but JeanKnowsCars.com is going to be a place where you don’t have to. 

I live in the Michigan countryside with my husband, Tim, and the entire food chain. You’re going to get to know my driveway and my dogs really, really well. Just keep reading.

pageElements.text:
2015 Toyota Yaris SE

Type: Four-passenger, front-wheel-drive subcompact hatchback
Base price: $17,645 (including destination charge)
This car: $18,724 (including destination charge)
Engine: 1.5-liter four-cylinder, 106 horsepower
Transmission: Five-speed manual
Fuel economy: 30 mpg city/37 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Smart Stop brake assist technology
Options I can’t live without: Navigation system ($899)
Notable standard features on this model: Brake assist, rear spoiler, leather-trimmed steering wheel
You might also be considering: 2015 Ford Fiesta SE Hatchback ($16,420); 2015 Honda Fit LX ($16,470); 2015 Kia Rio LX ($17,815); 2015 Nissan Versa Note SV ($17,155) (all prices include destination charge)

Can you buy a decent new car and pay less than $20,000 for it? Yes, in fact, you can, and here’s the big news: You won’t have to steel yourself for a total hose-out special. Increasingly, you can get a small car laden with many features that used to be reserved for higher-end vehicles.

A case in point is the Toyota Yaris. Once a tiny, boring box, the Yaris in 2015 has a new, modern, and attractive appearance—that is, if you approve of the angry-mesh-grille look that is so popular these days. Which I do. Toyota pretty much had to update; the city-car category is jammed with little hatchbacks at small prices. The new Yaris has to elbow its way through Ford’s Fiesta, the Honda Fit, the Kia Rio, Chevy’s Sonic, and the Mazda 2, all worthy competitors.

The Yaris model we tested was the top-end SE five-door hatchback, equipped with a five-speed manual transmission, which comes in at $18,724. (The base model, the three-door Yaris L, is priced at $15,670.) But if you were expecting an el strippo look for an el strippo price, you would be pleasantly surprised. Remarkably sophisticated-looking for such a small car, the Yaris SE has projector-beam headlights with an LED light bar, LED daytime running lights, a black grille with piano black accents, a rear spoiler, and sixteen-inch alloy wheels (versus the standard fifteen-inch wheels). Compare the 2015 Yaris to the ones from 2014 or earlier, and you’ll appreciate Toyota’s leap of faith in overhauling this small car’s appearance.
Looks would certainly be one reason to buy a new car, instead of used, at this price point. Another would be modern conveniences on the inside.

Looks would certainly be one reason to buy a new car, instead of used, at this price point. Another would be modern conveniences on the inside. Our Yaris SE had a 6.1-inch touchscreen, navigation (an $899 option), and Bluetooth connectivity. Cruise control, a leather-trimmed steering wheel and shift lever, and power windows and locks are all there, as is remote keyless entry. Having said that, don’t look for luxury or coziness: there’s no center arm rest, the seats are narrow and stiff—although not uncomfortable, even on a 100-mile highway run—and the overall feeling is still somewhat...economical.

Missing is a rearview camera, something you’ll find on the Yaris’s arch-competitor, the Honda Fit. Thinking about the number of young, inexperienced drivers who are likely to own a Yaris, this is disappointing, but in fairness, most cars in this class don’t have one. It would be a welcome option, though.

Also missing is the kind of capacious rear storage the Honda Fit has so much of. The Yaris has 60/40 split-folding rear seats, but the amount of rear space you get when you fold them down doesn’t approach the 52.7 cubic feet the Fit can boast. Having said that, the rear seating area is surprisingly comfortable. I wouldn’t go so far as to call it “spacious,” but it’s no mere package holder; you could put kids back there, at least kids up through elementary-school age, and adults could stand it for short drives, at least.
The Yaris may not have the latest and greatest under the hood, but it’s reasonably competent, especially as an around-town errand runner.

If you think the Yaris seems like it’s much better suited for use around town than on a road trip, you’re not wrong, but a couple of hours on the highway, including a spate of rush-hour traffic, showed that it is capable enough and feels bigger than it is. You can push 70 mph comfortably, although you won’t forget you’re in an economy car. The SE model has upgraded suspension and brakes, and it shows. Wind noise was manageable, turbulence was minimal, and the 1.5-liter four-cylinder was reasonably competent. This is an older engine, teamed with a five-speed manual transmission versus the six-speed you’ll find on the Fit. Other competitors, including the Ford Fiesta and the Chevrolet Sonic, also have five-speed manuals as standard. The automatic transmission is an old-school four-speed. Today’s newest transmissions are much smoother and quieter. I would at least stay with the manual so I could get every last drop of shifting fun available. So, the Yaris may not have the latest and greatest under the hood, but it’s reasonably competent, especially as an around-town errand runner.

Subcompact shoppers are also concerned with fuel economy and safety. The Yaris bests its competitors with an impressive 30 mpg in town and 37 mpg on the highway. By comparison, the Chevrolet Sonic gets 26/35 mpg, and the Honda Fit gets 29/37 mpg. The 2015 Yaris did well in Insurance Institute for Highway Safety testing, rated Good in all but the small-overlap front crash rating. Here again, it’s outgunned by the Honda Fit, which got Acceptable on the small-overlap test and was named a Top Safety Pick for 2015.

The Verdict:

Why would you choose the Toyota Yaris? You might choose it if you’re a Toyota loyalist, or want to be one. You might like its styling better than that of its more prosaic-looking competitors. But there’s no doubt that you will have lots of other cars to check out before you make that decision.

Peanut Gallery:

Laura Sky Brown: I invited my nineteen-year-old son, Henry, in to the passenger's seat of the Yaris and asked him his thoughts. "Why wouldn't you just get a used Honda Civic for this same money?" he asked. He has a point, and a lot of people on a budget might prefer a three-year-old car that's more conventionally sized, to get more horsepower and more space. Personally, I saw the appeal of the Yaris as soon as I had to back into a parallel parking space downtown. You just feel smart when you are zipping around in something this neat and compact. On the list of things I loved: the single front wiper, the topstitching on the seats, and the edgy front treatment, sort of a micro-Lexus look. Would I want to drive cross-country in it? Not today, but when I was still in the youth demographic? Sure.

Molly Jean: The driver's seat in the Toyota Yaris is oddly high. I am five foot seven, and my seating position was so high that I don't think I would ever need a visor to keep the sun out of my eyes. I can't imagine someone any taller even being able to sit in the car without hitting their head. That aside, I also agree with Laura's son Henry that, although $18,000 is a low price for a brand-new car, I can do without the new car smell to get a few more luxuries in a used car for the same price. Specifically, how about a telescoping steering wheel? It was fun to zip around with the manual transmission, but I assume most buyers of the Yaris will opt for the automatic. I personally take a pass on the Yaris.

pageElements.text: With the Geneva Auto Show behind me, I lined up a flight to Fort Lauderdale by way of Amsterdam and Atlanta, to spend a few days warming up before the 20th Amelia Concours d’Elegance, my favorite. I fell asleep, tightly bookended between two businessmen, the second I boarded in Geneva, and never stirred until we touched down. I thought I was in Atlanta and it took a second to realize that I’d only just begun my long, arduous day in the great prison ships of the sky.

You will perhaps be surprised that I really like Delta. KLM, not so much. I might actually hate them, but that would imply that I once loved them. This trip, I had to rush to get to the surly security and the world’s worst X-ray line—the only one I’ve experienced that has you unload not only your computer, but also your power cords, headphones, Flip cameras, iPhone, iPad, camera, electric nostril hair clippers, while the agent on the other side of the conveyor harangues you out of your hat, your coat, your belt, your watch, your shoes, and your dignity. It looked like a Buster Keaton movie.
Champagne, slipper socks, lip balm, a gourmet lunch. A perfect flight attendant named Tom who looked exactly like former Ford CEO Alan Mulally, whom we all miss terribly.

The Delta crew welcomed me into the comfort of business class. Champagne, slipper socks, lip balm, a gourmet lunch menu to consider. A flat bed with fluffy down comforter. A perfect flight attendant named Tom who looked exactly like former Ford CEO Alan Mulally, whom we all miss desperately.

We were rudely awakened from the near-swoon of privilege by the captain who announced that there had been a security breach—a door to the unsecured concourse was open during the entire boarding process. We needed to put down our champagne, crawl out from under our blankies, and leave the plane immediately with all of our belongings. Stop it.

Back to the wrong side of the X-ray bureaucrats we went, while security tapes were scrutinized, only to discover that the KLM snotwads hadn’t secured the door. Of course we had to once again surrender our power cords, our clothing, our shoes, our dignity, et cetera, to reboard. Tom/Mulally was waiting our return with fresh champagne, but the thrill was gone. Of course, my connecting flight was also gone, the next flight had fifty people waiting standby, and my luggage had fallen off the radar. Kind of a quad-fecta of bad luck.

But things picked up significantly from there. The temperature in southern Florida was approximately 113 degrees warmer than when I’d left Michigan, give or take a degree or two. That, and the fact that a Hermosa Blue 2015 Infiniti QX60 3.5 with ventilated front seats was waiting for me and my next adventure—the road to Amelia Island.
Who could bitch, right?

Love,

title: 3 St. Patrick's Day Reminders
subTitle: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.
promoTeaserSmall: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.
promoTeaser: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.
metaDescription: Drivers, you can embrace the fun and tackiness of this holiday and still be safe.

pageElements.text: St. Patrick's Day may be in the middle of the week this year, but chances are there are still people out there making poor choices about drinking and driving. We know you aren't among them, but take this reminder to be an example for others, not least to your own kids, teenagers, and other young adults in your life.
Here are three things you should do on this and every celebration-oriented holiday (actually, every time you go out).

1. Always have a designated driver.

Before you (or your kids) go out, agree on who that person will be.

2. But have a backup plan, too.

If you don't have a sober driver on hand, get a taxi or call a friend for a ride. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration offers an app for that called Safer Ride. It's on Google Play and the iTunes Store. Set up its uncomplicated interface, and have it ready when you need it. Ensure your kids do the same.

3. And find some non-drinking ways to have fun.

St. Patrick's Day is one of the dangerous holidays, both for good taste and for good behavior. If you're having a party, serve plenty of food and non-alcoholic drinks, stop serving alcohol a few hours before the end of the party, and don't let underage people drink at all.
St. Patrick's Day can be the most sincere, yet the most tacky of holidays. Go ahead, embrace the whole Erin Go Bragh theme and the silliness of it all. I mean, why not? And you don't have to be drunk to do that.
NHTSA reminds you that there were thirty-one deaths in drunk-driving crashes in 2013. Don't be a statistic, and don't let the people around you be a statistic.

title: 5 Ways to Make Your Car Spring Forward
subTitle: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.
promoTitle: 5 Ways to Make Your Car Spring Forward

promoTeaser: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.

metaDescription: Your car is a hot mess; admit it. Here are some ways to fix that.

pageElements.text: There’s nothing as wonderful as a bright spring morning, alive with the promise of melted snow and budding trees. Even in the warmest parts of the country, March brings with it the certitude that summer, and vacations, and vacation trips are not far away.
Your car is a hot mess, isn’t it?
That’s probably a bit how you feel after the long season of cold and darkness. With that in mind, here are five things you can do right now to help it spring forward.

1. Change the wiper blades.

If you live where there’s a lot of snow and ice, the blades have had a brutal winter. Even if you don’t live where there’s ice and salt ripping up the rubber, you probably haven’t gotten around to this in a while. It’ll change your view of the world.

2. Ditch the junk in your trunk.

Some people think it’s a jinx to take shovels and ice scrapers out of the trunk too soon. Be an optimist and remove kitty litter, gloves, boots, and whatever other winter things you have in your car. Leave in jumper cables, work gloves, tire iron, flares, and emergency triangle. Keep them corralled in a duffel or box. And leave in the emergency granola bars unless you’ve already eaten them at the first long traffic light.

3. Clean and vacuum.

Neat trick A: Wet down the removable floor mats with warm water, then wet-vac them, to get the maximum amount of road salt and grime off. Neat trick B: When vacuuming out the interior, use a stiff-bristled paintbrush to clear dirt out of the cracks and crevices. (I know, Martha Stewart-y, right?)

4. Get the insides of your windows clean.

REALLY clean. This is the most important improvement you can make to your quality of life inside the car. When I drove a cab, I kept automotive glass cleaner and a roll of paper towels in the trunk. Avoid using household glass cleaners with ammonia, which can interact badly with tinted car windows.

5. Don’t forget your tires, the only contact your car has with the earth.

Tire pressure is battered when temps soar from negative numbers to the balmy climates of spring. You can improve your gas mileage by up to three percent with properly inflated tires. Check yours monthly, and obviously change from winter to summer tires if you’ve put snow tires on your car. Spring, like fall, is a good time to find sales on new tires.

subTitle: The five best things we spotted on cars at the Detroit auto show.

contributors.bio: I am a freelance writer in North Carolina, and I have been covering technology --including the technology in automobiles--since before Bill met Melinda or any of us met Google. I also write about education, parenting, family travel, and gardening. I currently write the Family Tech column in Family Circle magazine and Family Tech with Christina at FamilyCircle.com, and I blog on the Geek Girlfriends site. Clients--past and present--include Better Homes and Gardens, Popular Science, This Old House Magazine, USA Weekend, PC Magazine, PC World, Jaguar, Saks Fifth Avenue, and many others. I am thrilled to be a part of Jean Knows Cars.

pageElements.text: I walked the floor at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit this week, in search of the coolest car technology I could find. I let the car guys talk torque and RPM. This girl nerd was looking for the smartest innovations, the stuff that’s most wanted by a smartphone-sporting average human with a lot on her mind. I found some awesome treats hidden in those automobiles. Here are five of my favorites.

Wireless Charging Pad

This is the feature every social media nerd or smartphone-addicted human in the world has been waiting for, and I found a few cars at NAIAS sporting it: A dedicated place to set your phone that charges it without wires. Yes! Finally. It’s called an inductive charging pad. And your phone has to support it, too. (The Nexus phones from LG can do it out of the box. Other phones need a case that adds the capability.) I saw one in the 2016 Chevrolet Volt, the GMC Yukon, and the 2015 Toyota Camry. But I, for one, am hoping this turns up as standard in every car starting ASAP.

Ford AppLink 3.0

You connect your phone via Bluetooth to your car so you can talk and drive, right? (Isn’t that the only place we actually talk on our phones now? Since e-mail and text are out? Eyes on the road!) Once you’re connected, the telematics system offers up a tempting “Apps” section. You go there, hopeful, only to find a fraction of your apps represented. Disappointing, right? That’s because the app developer has to modify its app to work with every car’s various telematics systems and wait for the car company to look at it and approve it and bla, bla, bla. Too slow!

Ford aims to fix that with AppLink 3.0. The company has made the source code freely available to developers so that any developer who wants to can make its app work with your Ford. (That’s called "open source" in Nerdville.) AppLink already has more smartphone apps live in its Apps section than other cars. But you can expect to see that proliferate at this rolls out through 2015. Geek heaven! And not too shabby for the non-geek with a few must-have apps on her phone.

Volvo's Got the True Meaning of "AutoPilot"

The Volvo XC90 comes with a driving assistant! You don’t have to get out of the driver’s seat to let it take over. Just turn on the adaptive cruise control to match the car’s speed to that of the cars in front of you. But this uber-smart car will also take over the steering. It follows the car in front of you, matching both direction and speed to the traffic. It also looks at the lane markers on both sides of the car to keep you on the straight and narrow. You still have to pay attention to the road – you never know what’s going to happen – but you can relax a little and let the car take care of the mindless steering and braking.

A 3D Printed Car from Local Motors

This isn’t technology that’s in your car. It’s a technology that creates your car. Local Motors brought its state-of-the-art massive 3D printer to NAIAS to demonstrate printing a car right on the floor. It takes a couple of days for the machine to print the car. But, the result is drivable and slick and very science fiction future. To this I can only say: Wow.

Chevrolet Puts Your Phone in the Dash

How great would it be if that in-dash screen looked just like your phone? You know how to use the phone. It’s set up just as you like it, right? Well wait for it! That very thing is coming this year to the Chevrolet Sonic and Spark, named Phone Projection. Plug your Apple or Android phone in (or connect via Bluetooth), and the phone will be projected onto that screen using Apple CarPlay or Android Auto. The apps have to be tweaked a bit for in-car safety so it might take a while before you see everything on your phone in the dash, but this is a very auspicious beginning.

title: Do You Need Wireless Internet in the Car?
subTitle: How hot is the 4G LTE rolling hot spot? We tried it out on the 2015 Buick Encore.
promoTitle: Do You Need Wireless Internet in the Car?
promoTeaserSmall: How hot is the 4G LTE rolling hot spot? We tried it out on the 2015 Buick Encore.
promoTeaser: How hot is the 4G LTE rolling hot spot? We tried it out on the 2015 Buick Encore.
keywords: Do You Need Wireless Internet in the Car?
metaTitle: Do You Need Wireless Internet in the Car? - JeanKnowsCars.com
metaDescription: How hot is the 4G LTE rolling hot spot? We tried it out on the 2015 Buick Encore.

contributors.bio: Liane Yvkoff dipped her toe in the pool of automotive writing five years ago and fell directly into the deep end. Since then, she has written about cars for CNET.com, AutoUSA.com, Babble.com, and, oddly enough, Hustler. Residing in the Seattle area, she obviously drives a Subaru Outback.

pageElements.text: Connectivity is the next frontier in new cars, and General Motors has gone there in a big way, putting 4G LTE wireless connectivity inside most of its lineup. GM is betting you want to be able to use the Internet in the car the same way you do at home. At least you want passengers to be able to, especially those of you with children in the car.

But it's not just GM. Look at any brand, and you'll realize that infotainment platforms are becoming more complex in cars across the industry. Although most drivers are leveraging their smartphones for navigation and entertainment, we're betting more manufacturers start making the car itself the rolling hot spot.
You can connect multiple devices to the car’s Wi-Fi and not have to worry about your phone’s data plan or battery life being abused during road trips.
The question is, Do you really need a car that is a rolling hot spot if you have a mobile phone? I checked it out in a 2015 Buick Encore equipped with OnStar 4G LTE Wi-Fi.

In-vehicle Wi-Fi uses a dedicated SIM card that is embedded inside the car and an antenna that's mounted up high, such as on the roof of the car. You connect to the Internet through a mobile carrier, such as Sprint or AT&T. Some manufacturers other than GM, including Audi and BMW, also offer 4G LTE connectivity. Others, such as Chrysler, are still operating on the older and slower 3G networks. And then there are manufacturers, such as Ford, who are skipping this feature, although you can get connectivity by using a broadband modem you supply yourself that plugs into Ford's Sync USB port.

The advantages of 4G Wi-Fi connectivity are clear: you can connect multiple devices to the car’s Wi-Fi and not have to worry about your phone’s data plan or battery life being abused during road trips. Drivers who have phones with unlimited data plans may not be so easily swayed, but a smartphone-as-hot-spot means that you can’t use your device for voice calls, so the second you have to answer the phone, that movie your kids have been streaming is paused.

In the Buick we tested, you can run Wi-Fi on as many as seven devices (tablets, phones, computers) at a time. It seems like a lot until you fill a crossover with an entire family and their gadgets for a road trip.

Then there is reliability. Of course, compared with your smartphone in your hand, the car's antenna is larger, mounted in a more prominent place, and has a bigger power supply, which means it should have a stronger signal reception. That said, an antenna is only as powerful as its service provider’s availability, so there are times when a smartphone’s carrier may have better or faster connectivity than the vehicle’s, or vice versa.
Any parental guilt I had about using Disney as a babysitter was abandoned the second my two-year-old started screaming, “I DONE....I DONE,” a scant hour into the trip.

I tested this technology on a four-hour road trip from Seattle to Portland and saw the usefulness of a dedicated hot spot. I am typically a data hawk and rarely stream video on my phone since I do not have an unlimited data plan. As a parent of a two-year-old, I’m mindful of screen time and had never used a device for videos in the car. But any parental guilt I had about using Disney as a babysitter was abandoned the second she started screaming, “I DONE....I DONE” a scant hour into the trip.

With OnStar 4G Wi-Fi, I had no problem handing my toddler a Kindle to stream Frozen and Ratatouille from Amazon Instant Video. It also could be argued that this was a safety feature that enabled me to stay focused on the road during inclement weather instead of entertaining a toddler. And for the parents in the front of the car, it also repeatedly seemed the faster hub than Verizon during unscientific tests measuring speed of Google searches and Yelp queries.
At the end of the day, whether or not I would use this option comes down to money and the question, how much would I be willing to pay to stream movies to the car?

Most manufacturer plans are somewhat flexible, with a subscription and pre-pay model. GM also offers current OnStar customers a discount on plans, and there's a “mobile share” option that enables AT&T customers to burn data off their phone’s plan for $10 a month.

As a parent who never remembers to download a movie onto a device until it’s too late, I could see myself willing to pay daily rates (competitive to what is available in airplanes), but not a monthly $10 to $50 monthly subscription since I’m not that much of a road tripper. Luckily, nearly all 2015 GM vehicles, even entry level models, from Chevrolet, GMC, Buick, and Cadillac have this 4G LTE Wi-Fi hardware as standard, so the option to turn on this service as needed is always there.

The service is free for the first three months when you lease or buy. After that, you are paying a monthly fee of $10 per month for 200 MB of data, up to $50 per month for 5 GB. Buick offers a handy online data calculator to help you plan.

$10 day pass ($5 for OnStar subscribers) doesn’t buy much data--only 250 MB, which won’t get me a single episode of Dora the Explorer. A 10-GB prepay is available for $200 ($150 for OnStar subscribers) and is good for a year, but that is a significant amount of pocket change that could buy me a lot of downloadable movies.

For a lot of people (perhaps yourself), this will be another expense, like satellite radio, that you get in the habit of paying for. As for me, until I have more money than time to burn, I'd better start planning ahead or freshening up my I Spy car game strategy.

title: 2016 Kia Sorento SX AWD
subTitle: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?
promoTeaserSmall: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?
promoTeaser: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?
metaDescription: A solid utility player in a crowded crossover marketplace. Is it the one for you?

pageElements.text:
Type: Five- or seven-passenger, front- or all-wheel-drive crossover vehicle
Base price: Sorento SX: $38,965 (including destination charge)
This car: $40,595 (including destination charge)
Engine: 3.3-liter V-6, 290 horsepower
Transmission: Six-speed automatic
Fuel economy: 17 mpg city/23 mpg highway
My favorite standard feature: Navigation system (standard on SX)
Option I can’t live without: Infinity premium surround sound audio system
Notable standard features on this model: Panoramic power sunroof, navigation, heated leather seats, premium audio, power rear liftgate
Notable options on this model: All-wheel drive ($1,800)
You might also be considering: 2015 Ford Edge Titanium AWD ($38,415), 2015 GMC Acadia SLT-2 AWD ($45,020), 2015 Mazda CX-9 Sport AWD ($32,455), 2015 Nissan Pathfinder SL 4WD ($38,635), 2015 Toyota Highlander LE AWD ($33,710) (prices include destination charges)

Like its Hyundai parent, Kia is a car company that has come a long way in a remarkably short time, and the 2016 Sorento is yet another manifestation of its steady climb. Attractively styled (by SUV standards), solidly assembled, handsomely appointed, and dynamically competent, this third generation of Kia’s mid-size crossover is an appealing package in a market crowded with appealing packages.

So where does the Sorento stand out from the crowd? The short answer is: nowhere in particular. The Sorento is like a baseball major leaguer who can play any position on the field, none of them at an all-star level, but all of them pretty well.

Fundamentals: This is a substantially roomier Sorento. Thanks to a 3.1-inch wheelbase stretch, to 109.4 inches, and a small increase laterally, there’s more space for second-row passengers to stretch their legs, as well as more cargo space behind the rearmost seats. The Sorento is available in both five- and seven-passenger versions. In the three-row version, those wayback seats are still pretty tight and really best suited to young kids. But this criticism is not unique to the Sorento.

Structure and assembly are impressive strong suits, qualities that communicate themselves to the driver on gnarly pavement and/or washboard stretches of gravel, such as Forest Service roads en route to a vacation cabin. Never a quiver, never a shudder, never a buzz, squeak, or rattle. This is attributable to a unibody composed of a much higher percentage of high-strength steel, yielding a sense of reassuring solidity.
The development team invested heavily in noise reduction, which pays off with one of the more serene interiors in this class.
A new electric power steering system amplifies the overall sense of competence, and the suspension offers respectable responses complemented by supple ride quality.

Keep in mind that we’re talking about a large vehicle with substantial mass and substantial height, along with enough ground clearance to make off-pavement travel plausible. These are not sports car specifications, ladies and gentlemen. Do not expect sports car performance and/or agility. But you probably knew that already.

There are three engine options for the 2016 Sorento. The standard engine in the base version is a 2.4-liter four-cylinder, with a performance upgrade for the new Sorento, to 185 horsepower. Optional powerplants include a 290-horsepower 3.3-liter V-6, carried over from the previous generation, and, new to the inventory, a 2.0-liter turbo rated for 240 horsepower.

The turbo delivers a lovely torque surge, but the V-6 has substantially more grunt, to handle the mass of a Sorento seven-seater with all-wheel drive, and also to raise the towing capability from 3,500 to 5,000 pounds.

All Sorentos are equipped with a six-speed automatic transmission. This crossover comes as front-wheel drive or, like our test car, all-wheel drive. You also have a choice of five- or seven-passenger models.

As you’d expect, fuel economy suffers slightly with the more potent engine—the V6 is EPA rated for 18 mpg city, 23 highway (we averaged a drop or two over 19 mpg in a week of suburban and rural travels).

Consistent with an overall strategy of moving Kia vehicles steadily upscale, the new Sorento’s interior is distinguished by meticulous workmanship, quality materials, soft touch surfaces, elegant stitchery, attractive instrumentation, and, as noted, more room for first and second-row passengers, as well as small increases in cargo volume.
It’s also distinguished by exceptionally quiet operation at all speeds. The development team invested heavily in noise reduction, which pays off with one of the more serene interiors in this class.

Our SX test unit was one rung below the top of the Sorento price ladder, so its list of standard features was extensive—heated perforated-leather seats; user-friendly navigation, accessed on a large (eight inch) center-dash touchscreen; telematics galore; high-end Infinity audio; giant power moonroof; power rear hatch; all-wheel drive; nineteen-inch wheels; and a respectable (though not exactly outstanding) array of safety features.

There’s a lot of content baked into that trim level. But if $40,595 sounds a little steep, the bidding starts well south of there: $25,795 for the Sorento L, a basic front-wheel-drive five-passenger version with the 2.4-liter four-cylinder engine. And basic isn’t very basic at all.

The Verdict:

Like other Hyundai-Kia products, the Sorento comes with a goodly array of standard features, even on the base model, and content becomes increasingly comprehensive going up the price ladder. The price-value index is near the top among competing vehicles, and there are many to choose from: L, LX, EX, SX-Limited, all with a four-cylinder engine; and LX, EX, and SX-Limited models with the V-6.

We suggested competitors for the seven-passenger Sorento—the Ford Edge (also new for 2016), GMC Acadia, Mazda CX-9, Nissan Pathfinder, and Toyota Highlander. There’s also a five-passenger version of the Kia crossover, and in that category you might also consider the Jeep Grand Cherokee, Nissan Murano, and Volkswagen Touareg.

The Sorento does everything well, and it is close to the top of the charts in terms of one all-important metric: quiet, roomy comfort.
